[b]ðŸ¤” Ambiguous Storytelling[/b] INSIDE's storytelling is intentionally ambiguous, leaving much open to interpretation. While this approach adds to the game's mystique and atmosphere, some players may find the lack of explicit narrative exposition or closure frustrating. ðŸ“œâ“

As a gamer that has played Portal, Portal 2 and the Witness , I was intrigued to find a similar game that would test my problem solving skills. Given that the sale price was a whopping 2$ , I figured there wasn't any harm in trying it out for a bit. Boy was I surprised. The game has a unique level of immersion as controls and verbal commentary are not provided throughout. However, the game appears so atmospheric with unique music that not only captures the position of your character, but also of every other individuals stuck in their mindless trance.

What sets this game apart for me is the variety of different problems thrown at you and how you must think outside the box to get to the solution. This clearly differentiates the game from Portal which generally has fairly linear thinking ( although still challenging in its own right). If you are interested in playing a unique puzzle game for 4-5 hours that will make you think about society, freedom, and indoctrination, then this is the choice for you.

One of the most immersive and atmospheric games this side of Halo: ODST and Mirror's Edge. Controls are simple, yet each chapter offers a new challenge/puzzle that isn't too easy nor difficult. 

The visual cues are are balanced enough to not warrant hand-holding. You'd think a game that offers a minimal soundtrack and super simple controls would turn out boring and repetitive, but Inside is everything but that. 

For less than a dollar price tag, this is an absolute steal and must-play. I only wish it was a bit longer and that the story offered a bit more of a cathartic ending.

Inside took everything about Limbo and somehow made it better. The simplistic control scheme make this pseudo-2D platformer intuitive to learn, but it still allows for a variety of puzzles that continue to test the mind. 

The horror elements and gloomy set design somehow convey a meaningful story without depressing or scaring the player. The story is conveyed well without words, and even though it may be lacking in specifics, it remains engaging throughout the game. This is bolstered by the stellar score that creates an appropriate ambiance in each area, making the game extremely immersive.

I'd recommend playing with the lights off and headphones to get the best experience from the game. If you haven't played Limbo yet, please do. It's the spiritual predecessor to Inside and definitely helped me appreciate it more.

Inside is a game that will undeniably stick with you for some time after you've played it. The atmosphere is one of the most dense I've seen in any game ever, with visuals and audio that will astound you. The world it creates is incredibly intriguing from the beginning to even after it's over. You'll still be thinking of theories long after the credits roll.

In terms of actual gameplay, the simple yet clever puzzles are intuitive and satisfying. It has great pacing, with some calm moments to balance out the heart-pounding tension you'll experience. This isn't necessarily a horror game, but it will put you on edge more effectively than most.

Overall, I'd say you should definitely give Inside a try at least once. It's not long, and it has an ambiguous story and ending. Even if you aren't usually a fan of that, though, this might be one that you'll appreciate. You WILL be confused, but just remember that it's part of what makes this game so special.

Title: A Mesmerizing Dive into the Depths of Intrigue

Review:
INSIDE is not just a game; it's an experience that transcends the boundaries of conventional storytelling. From the moment you step into its hauntingly atmospheric world, you're drawn into a narrative that's as enigmatic as it is captivating.

Playdead, the masterminds behind Limbo, have once again crafted a masterpiece that defies expectations. The seamless blend of minimalist aesthetics, haunting sound design, and intuitive gameplay creates an immersive journey that lingers long after the credits roll.

The beauty of INSIDE lies in its ability to convey a compelling story without uttering a single word. Every frame is meticulously crafted, every puzzle meticulously designed to propel the narrative forward. As you navigate through its eerie environments and encounter its unsettling inhabitants, you'll find yourself constantly questioning the true nature of the world you inhabit.

But INSIDE isn't just about solving puzzles or unraveling its mysteries; it's about the emotional impact it leaves on you. From moments of heart-pounding tension to poignant moments of reflection, every twist and turn is orchestrated to evoke a myriad of emotions.

Moreover, INSIDE isn't afraid to challenge your perceptions and leave you pondering its deeper themes long after you've finished playing. It's a game that rewards curiosity and encourages exploration, inviting you to peel back its layers and uncover its hidden truths.

In conclusion, INSIDE is a tour de force in interactive storytelling. It's a game that demands to be experienced, not just played. So, if you're ready to embark on a journey unlike any other, I wholeheartedly recommend diving into the enigmatic world of INSIDE. You won't regret it.

A very good platformer/puzzle game, very much similar to LIMBO. The player deaths are varied and surprising the first time each happens, and the environmental changes and storyline are excellent. Game is a bit shorter than I'd like, but what it does in its 2.5-3hr length is very impressive. 

I don't want to spoil the themes too much, but the setting is top notch, and the graphics/animations are perfect for its genre. The puzzles are not exactly mind benders if you've played any puzzle/platformers, but I only had to be frustrated back-tracking a couple times. Just challenging enough to feel like you solved something.

Full price is maybe not worth it for its length, but any sale, especially the 90% off that got me to play it makes it a must buy.

If you enjoy arthouse cinema, you'll like this game. If you don't, you probably won't like this game.

Given the length (~3h on your first playthrough) and the steep discounts this game is offered at this point, it's hard not to recommend it. I don't quite know what to think of it, the plot remains a mystery open to interpretation even after all these years. The gameplay is basically just run left or right and interact with some light puzzles.

I was not really immersed, but given the critical acclaim of this game, it seems I'm one of the few. it's definitely very atmospheric though. I wouldn't buy it at full price though.

Beautiful and haunting. An excellent little piece of interactive science fiction. The puzzles find the perfect balance of being challenging but accessible. The tone throughout the game is eerie and mysterious. A very unique story and setting, which just gets stranger as the game progresses. Beware of some body horror elements though. The player character is a small child who undergoes some disturbing deaths. While uncomfortable, I feel like those deaths add to the overall hopelessness and danger in this dystopian world. At only 3.5 hours, I urge everyone to dive into this bite sized masterpiece.

[h1]Disturbing, memorable and unsettling[/h1]

Inside is a 2.5D puzzle platformer set in a dark and surreal dystopic world. As was the case with Playdead's previous entry Limbo, you are provided no context regarding your surroundings or your character (an unnamed boy) upon starting the game. Unlike Limbo, however, Inside has some colour to its backgrounds and more realistic human models, which helps set it apart and helps lead to some extremely eerie moments. The art direction is unique, and the atmosphere is without a doubt one of the most entrancing I have ever come across in a video game. There's definitely a tone of horror, but there were also numerous times when I needed to stop and take in how stunning the game looked too.

I found the puzzles to be more interesting and innovative compared to what came before them in Limbo, and without spoiling anything, there is a reason for that, as you have more elements to work with. Apart from occasional musical cues, the game for the majority is silent. The boy can meet his demise in a multitude of ways, which are presented realistically and, more often than not, are graphic. This is to a degree more seen from Limbo's teen rating, as Inside has an M rating. 

Some might say Inside is short, but I honestly felt like it was the perfect length, and I'm positive it's longer than Limbo was. An alternate ending even exists by deactivating all the glowing orbs in hidden rooms, which is a welcome addition. There is a chapter select which makes this easy to do if you wish not to play through the game a second time. While I very much enjoyed my time with Limbo and that is a strong experience in its own right, Inside built upon the formula it set, and I would argue it's even better than its predecessor. It's practically a perfect narrative sidescroller, one of the highest quality experiences I've had in gaming and the ending alone made me feel a certain way. Give it a try. I promise it's worth your time.

[b]INSIDE is a masterpiece![/b] 

The gameplay is fantastic: the controls are all incredibly intuitive, simple and fluid. All of the puzzles are incredibly well-designed. The tension in many sequences keeps you on the edge of your seat, contrasted with fragile moments of respite. The emotion the gameplay conveys is unmatched, and the ending to INSIDE is pure catharsis. 

Additionally to the main story, there are also optional achievements to get throughout the game, which consist of solving a small puzzle or exploring the environment to complete a challenge and disable a piece of machinery. They are incredibly enjoyable and worthwhile seeking out. 

Compared to LIMBO, I would say that INSIDE is much easier to finish, but I think that is part of what makes it good. LIMBO's difficulty was challenging due to the nature of its puzzles combined with strenuous platforming elements. However, INSIDE combines puzzles and platforming seamlessly to where it is always enjoyable to traverse, and the puzzles naturally seem to intertwine with the environment. Because of this, they feel less like contrived contraptions and more like natural problems to overcome. 

The visuals work themselves very well into the gameplay - it never leaves you guessing at what you can and can't interact with. All puzzle components are well-displayed and clear. Additionally, there is no doubt that the art direction is simply phenomenal. I love the soft, muted and solemn colours. And of course, the soundtrack to INSIDE carries huge emotions on its shoulders. The game is a splendour for the eyes and ears. 

The worldbuilding in this game is incredibly intriguing too - there's an underlying meaning that, whilst never truly giving you answers, doesn't leave you in the dark about what's going on either. Which I think is the perfect balance for a mysterious, unusual, abstract story such as this. 

[b]I cannot recommend this enough. Play it. Play it now![/b]

[h1] Why you should or should not play INSIDE [/h1]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2915798127

[b] What is INSIDE? [/b]

INSIDE is a side view story game where you go through different obstacles to make your way through the story. It is more horror themed and makes you kind of question things during the story. It is psychological horror mostly, and some of the puzzles that you will experience will be so anxiety inducing that you may or may not pi$$ yourself. 

[b] Initial Thoughts: [/b]

-"Okay, okay cool controls."
-"OMG PIGGIES AND ANIMALS YAY"
-"oh no...."

[b] Beginner Player Friendly?  [/b]

This game has very basic controls, though if you are not ready for a intense psychological horror with a lot gore and death. (So if you are sensitive to that I would not recommend this game for you as a beginner game.) If you are into the psychological horror in movies and such then this game may be for you! It definitely has an intense story. THOUGH some parts are kind of mentally challenging to get through and the puzzles can be very confusing at times, so if you are not ready to be mentally challenged then maybe this game is not beginner friendly for you.

[b] Game Play: [/b]

The game play involves a side view of your character and loads of puzzles you have to get through as you consistently move forward to reach your destination. You don't really fight anyone or thing and its more you run away a lot of the time. You do have to swim, climb, jump, and bolt your way through this story in order to stay alive and get to the end.

[b] Graphics: [/b]

The graphics are really interesting, as you will notice right away none of the characters have any faces really. It makes for an interesting plot line. The graphics are beautiful but still maintain pretty simple. This game will not run your computer/console to the ground if you play it for hours on end so that is also cool!

[b] Community: [/b]

There is not much of a community, though the steam community for this game seem pretty friendly and have loads of helpful guides for the game!

[b] How long can you play? [/b]

The story itself is around 3 hours long, maybe 4 at most, then if you would like to achievement hunt it may take you a little longer. Realistically you can play as many times as you want and for as long as you want.

[b] My Opinion: [/b]

In my opinion this game is really nice if you want a quick story horror game. Though it may not be good if you want a game that will make you go into the 100+ hours and meet people and such. 

[i] Any major edits that are made with this review will be added here: [/i]

Inside is a beautiful game with a great ambiance and simple but effective game mechanics.
The visuals are fantastic, the narrative is engrossing (even if it doesn't make a whole lot of sense), and that last hour of the gameplay is truly something else. 

If you liked Limbo (also a great game), Inside is somehow even better. It's a bit less difficult than Limbo (a good thing, as I had to look up solutions to a few of Limbo's puzzles) and it has a very different but even more beautiful art style. The real star of the show is the cinematography combined with the sound design. The way each shot is framed is breathtaking, creating an atmosphere that I've never seen in any other game.

All in a tight 4-5 hour package.

Inside is absolutely worth playing. I was tempted to score this game over 9, but I had to hold back because of its very nature as a 4.5 hour game with little replay value. But it's one hell of an experience during its short runtime.

Beautiful minimalist story telling. Fantastic short game.

I really have to say, I've never felt sadder for a character in an indie game that doesn't even communicate in any way. Since the first minute, you have started to care about the boy. You don't know why they are trying to kill him; you actually don't know anything about what's happening, yet you still care about him. This is the most depressing game I've ever witnessed.
This has been made by the same team behind Limbo, and I didn't really like that game. I thought it had some good aspects but ended up with more failures than great parts. However, I truly believe that they have understood the critics of Limbo and made this game perfect. The whole game, I didn't think once, "This would have been better if it were this way."
This game will make you feel scared for someone you don't know anything about; it will make you feel uncomfortable and sick; confused and delighted; and lastly, it will make you think about social classes in society.
The story-telling is better than most of the AAA games and will truly make you get goosebumps.
The music is good and fitting, but nothing memorable, and I think that's better, because after playing this, no one will want to think about music after seeing the ending.
Unlike Limbo, the puzzles are really good, and a death feels challenging and not punishing. The secrets and achievements are also great, and this is the first time I have actively tried to get all achievements, not for having them but for knowing what the secrets area looks like because this game loves to hide lore elements everywhere.
10/10 I recommend it to everyone, and don't let the art style deceive you; this game isn't scared to show gut-wrenching moments.



Edit: Im writing this part a month after i wrote this review and i have to say that this game lives in my head, in moments where i least expect it i remember parts of this game and get goosebumps when thinking about the visual story and gut wrenching aspects and i cant stop thinking about this masterpiece. It isnt a horror game, but the story and atmosphere is more horrifying than most horror games. Masterpiece.

When you are told to "show not tell" in media the end result can be something amazing. Sadly, when it comes to video games its rarely executed at all. But Playdead's INSIDE proves it can be done. INSIDE is quite simple in structure, but the puzzles and narrative give it wings. Some might not call it a horror game, but play this at night alone in the dark and you'll see the scares.
INSIDE has an incredible amount of replay ability, with its atmospheric environments, hidden objectives, and multiple ways of analyzing the story. 
The praise has been sung for INSIDE but it need to be regarded as the artistic masterpiece it is. Pick it up and immerse yourself in the oppressive world of INSIDE.

Takeaways:

-  An immersive, tense experience that will get your heart pounding/palms sweating and leave you craving more. There were brief moments of intense violence, which was challenging for me at times, but I had to remind myself that it was part of what immersed me in this world they created.

-  It took me just over 6 hours to complete my first playthrough. So, not a long game, and one that I am not itching to play again right away, but the experience was easily worth the sale price ($1.99). However, I'd argue it is easily worth buying on sale for only 50% off. 

-  Do not watch any video previews of the game before you play--it gives some things away and slightly diminishes the experience.

-  Resist the temptation to look up hints to solve a puzzle (you'll regret it--all of the solutions are attainable with some outside-the-box thinking). The puzzles are outstanding and varied, but taper off in the final stages of the game.

-  I'm generally not a fan of puzzles, platformers, or horror games, all of which this is, but something about this game drew me in and I'm very glad it did, because it was phenomenal!

[h2]The Good:[/h2]
[h3]Great lighting tech[/h3]
[h3]Smooth animations[/h3]
[h3]Challenging puzzles that are just right: not too hard to force an online guide, not too simplistic either[/h3]
[h3]Pretty scary at times with the lighting effect and underwater levels, especially with the brutal deaths as consequences of failure[/h3]
[h3]Underwater sections are super-immersive and exciting[/h3]
[h3]Mowing down evil scientists with a massive blob of naked bodies has to be most crazy fun ever made since GTA and running over pedestrians.[/h3]

[h2]The Bad:[/h2]
[h3]Disturbing disgusting death scenes[/h3]
Like getting your neck ripped out by rabid dogs, or blown to pieces by a Panzer maybe? (I dunno what the hell that thing was, but I HATED that section of insta-GIBBING where your character blows up into 10,000 chunks of meat and blood)
[h3]Lack of explanation of anything at all that happens in the game[/h3]
What's with the zombie-people, people acting like zombies, evil experiments and WHAT THE HELL is with the blob of naked bodies in the end? Also the ending makes it seem like the developers just gave up creating levels for the game suddenly and called it release time. What? Where? How? Why? The End, bye bye :) No! It feels incomplete, somehow.

If you'd like to watch my reactions to this crazy gut-exploding adventure, then check out my playthrough here:

Inside is the type of game that leaves you thinking about for days after playing it. The entire game is told through unbelievably good and effective world-building and story telling through the environments you play in. Every ten minutes you'll come across something that just makes you ask, what is that for, why did they make that, who am I, who are these people? Very few games can effectively do this without it feeling forced or cliche, and I believe Inside does it perfectly. Just buy the damn game it goes on sale for 2 dollars monthly.

Inside is an exceptional game that captivates players with its unique blend of platforming and puzzle-solving. The visual style is simple, yet incredibly effective and meticulously crafted. The game immerses you in a dystopian and enigmatic world, where horrifying events unfold. Prepare yourself for numerous deaths, each more violent than the last. The narrative is minimalistic, leaving ample room for your imagination to fill in the gaps.

Despite its brevity, Limbo manages to leave a lasting impression.  Both platforming and puzzles are accessible and enjoyable. It can be completed in just one or two sessions, but those few hours will be filled with an unforgettable experience. The game possesses an unparalleled atmosphere that lingers long after you've put down the controller. Limbo is a must-play for anyone seeking a thought-provoking and haunting gaming experience.

Good little puzzle platformer with a lot of care and polish put into it. Like LIMBO the atmosphere is unsettling/disturbing and it doesn't really have anything in the way of an explicit narrative, so may not be everyone's cup of tea. If you're ok with all that and want just want to chill with a short-but-sweet artsy game, though, this is the ticket.

there is no doubt that the game is good, and I sincerely recommend playing it, especially if you like Limbo, but let's take a closer look.
1. the game is magnificent, all locations are drawn in detail and really appealing, creating a truly immersive atmosphere.
2. the game has many mechanics and locations. the main feature of the game is controlling other people, which made puzzles more intriguing. like in Limbo (perhaps even better), the physics are decent and feel realistic (except some magic parts with gravity in a couple of places). you have to not only run looking for solution, but also swim underwater and even sail on a submarine in different levels to complete them, and the last part of the game is even more fun, but I don't want to spoil it.
3. imo, the plot is average. while the game has some story inside, most of the parts are omitted and we can only guess. it's fine when something is unclear, but not such a large portion of the narrative.
4. the puzzles are also average. I won't say they are bad; all of them are interesting, but the difficulty is noticeably lower than in Limbo. some of them are clever, but the majority is fairly straightforward.

This was a beautiful and intriguing game. This game was made by the same people who created the game LIMBO, which was a game I played before this one, which had the same puzzle-solving concept with a mix of unsettling and dark imagery. I enjoyed the interesting turn this game takes, from start to end I wasn't quite sure where the protagonist would end up. I also enjoyed the fact that there were two endings (the main one and a secret one which you can obtain by doing specific things, I recommend looking into that if you own this game). The way the puzzles are constructed is so creative, which is honestly one of the main reasons why I enjoyed this game. It was easy to follow and I didn't have too much of a hard time figuring out what my next objective was throughout the game's entirety, despite there being hardly any guidance (which, I applaud to the creators of this game). Overall, I recommend this game for people who like a weird, yet interesting look into a puzzle adventure game!! : )

This is a short but sweet puzzle-platformer. There is no written or voiced dialogue -- the story is solely told through visuals. I haven't finished LIMBO yet (the previous game by this developer) but maybe I will go back to that at some point.

This is a spiritual successor to Limbo and is similar in a lot of ways - itâ€™s a short, 2D puzzle-platformer with an arthouse horror vibe. Where Limbo was simply eerie, INSIDE goes further. I donâ€™t want to describe too much of the setting or gameplay, as going in blind makes the experience better.

I can say without spoiling anything that this game is a visual feast. Limbo was all shadow art, but INSIDE goes all out, with top-tier lighting and water effects along with a hauntingly anonymizing stylization. Every frame is a work of consummate skill, immaculately constructed. It's incredibly immersive.

The only black mark would be the price - 30 bucks for 3 hours is reeeeeeeally pushing it. Still, itâ€™s frequently a sale candidate, so you can probably pick it up for something more reasonable if youâ€™re patient.

I'd highly recommend INSIDE. It's a huge follow-up on Limbo and an impressive piece of art.

Like these indie puzzle games so much! Compared to the other release by the developers, Limbo, this added a story to the game-play while keeping the sort of 2.5 D puzzle theme. This one also has better art, moving to more detail and colour! Really liked how the story played out, although since there is no speaking it is very much observational inference to what is happening and a little open ended, something enjoyable to me. Also, horror elements were not just in your face. More so unsettling tone that leaves you disquieted rather than shocking you with gore and such like other horror media does. When those classic narrative pieces - gore, body-horror - are used, it is sparingly and feels in place. Would love to see more of these games from the developers, because I think this was well done for the genre. If the reader liked Little Nightmares I & II, this would be something that emulates that.

This game achieves more with its minimalist design than most AAA games achieve with all the bells and whistles.

Initially the game seems like a simple platformer but as you play you begin to appreciate the attention to detail that the developers have put into the game:
- the way the story unfolds in the background independently of your actions, until it intrudes into your actions and presents an imminent danger,
- the innovative puzzle mechanisms, the low key audio that portrays a sense of dread
- the shock of seeing the no-holds-bared death animations of a young boy
- the way that background actors react to you

Everyone should play this game!

[h1]Inside: A Haunting Journey Beyond the Veil[/h1]

[i]Inside isn't just a game. It's an experience.[/i]

From the moment you step into the shoes of a nameless, red-shirted boy, you're plunged into a world that's both unsettling and beautiful, a surreal dreamscape where shadows dance and danger lurks around every corner.

[b]Visually Stunning[/b]

Every frame of Inside is meticulously crafted, a masterclass in minimalist beauty. The stark contrast between light and shadow paints a world on the edge of collapse, where:
    Towering, oppressive structures scrape the sky.
    Grimy factories belch black smoke into the ashen air.
    Sunbeams pierce through abandoned buildings.
    Lone fireflies twinkle in the twilight.
    Gentle waves ripple on a murky shore.

[b]Mind-bending Puzzles[/b]

Inside's puzzles are seamlessly integrated into the narrative, challenging you to:
    Manipulate levers
    Control minds
    Navigate treacherous environmental hazards

[b]A Story Whispered in Shadows[/b]

Inside's story unfolds through environmental storytelling and fleeting glimpses of nightmarish imagery. There are no cutscenes or explanatory dialogues. Instead, the game invites you to piece together the narrative yourself, asking questions like:
    What is this nameless boy running from?
    Who are the masked figures that seem to control his every move?
    What lies at the end of this dark and dangerous path?

[b]An Ending That Will Leave You Reeling[/b]

Inside's ending is a gut punch, a twist that will leave you questioning everything you thought you understood. It's a culmination of the unsettling tension and cryptic imagery that has been building throughout the game.

[b]More Than Just a Game[/b]

Inside is a game that defies categorization. It's a puzzle-platformer, yes, but it's also:
    An art installation
    A psychological thriller
    A philosophical treatise on free will and control

[b]Step Inside, If You Dare[/b]

If you're looking for a game that will challenge your intellect, your emotions, and your very perception of reality, then step inside Inside. Just be prepared for what you might find on the other side.

Awesome game!

This was a very interesting game.

I bought it on sale because I thought it looked like it had a similar play style to Little Nightmares, a game I thoroughly enjoy. It was not as similar as I expected but it kept me engaged and I was able to complete the game within a day (with the help of a walkthrough every now and then ðŸ˜…)

I'll start with what I liked. The little chick creatures at the beginning of the game were the highlight of my day, I want to carry them around with me everywhere to be my little helpers :3 I also enjoyed the [spoiler]mind control concept of using the people around me to do things I wasn't able to do; the mind control inception/recursion was particularly amusing and a clever mechanic.[/spoiler] The colour scheme, the unexpected allies that came from enemies, and the atmosphere were all very engaging. The utter fear I felt from some of the chases had my heart leaping out of my chest!

One thing I wasn't a fan of was the controls. The arrow keys + the control key directly to the left of my left arrow button made it difficult to play as both my hands were on the same side of the keyboard. I attempted to change the key mapping in the settings but it wouldn't let me. I don't know if I'm just too silly to see how to change them, because if changing them is possible then this whole comment is now irrelevant, but if there is no way to change the keys then I maintain my opinion that the controls were my least favourite part of the experience. EDIT: I played the game again and figured out how to change the controls. I was just and idiot first time around (ãƒŽ_<ã€‚)

Anyways, that ending was so unexpected my face was gaping for a full five minutes as I was processing what the heck was happening. I'm not saying this was a bad part of the game though, if anything, the unpredictability was comical for me personally! I wish I knew more about the deeper meaning of this game, but it is up to the player to draw their own conclusions. There was a lot of symbolism I could pick up on, but ultimately the ending left my brain scrambled and less sure of what I originally thought was going on.

So, do I recommend this game? Yes, but be prepared for a wild ride! I am going to attempt to find all the collectables so I can play through the secret ending and see if I can form any new opinions or thoughts on the meaning behind Inside. EDIT: I completed the secret ending. I must say, for me, playing the game a second time through was much more enjoyable than the first for some reason.

Thanks for reading my review!

It's one of those rare game where you can write a literature analysis on. The game purposefully story tells in a way that you can interpret the story and meaning in a plethora of perspectives, from a literal sense of view to a metaphorical or philosophical standpoint. Every details in the art and background, coupled with the puzzled gameplay successfully narrates the non-dialogue story in such that what you observe, and the hidden details, is the narrative you, yourself build up. In essence, the story of the game is what your imagination tells you, and there is no one true interpretation, only theories to be made up.

Building on the strength of the predecessor, Limbo, while avoiding its design flaws, Inside is a very well-made game. This 2.5D side-scrolling puzzle platformer has stunning 3D graphics, minimalistic but atmospheric sound effects, excellent animation filled with details, realistic and satisfying physics, puzzles with good variety and pacing.  These elements are sewn together seamlessly to tell uncanny stories which are open to many interpretations in a cinematic and immersive way without resort to text or dialogues.

Puzzle lovers might be disappointed to learn that Inside does not offer any hard-core puzzles to solve. As a matter of fact, the puzzles in Inside are not, in my humble opinion, intellectually engaging or challenging. Most of them are based on trial and error, well-timed sequence of actions, or mundane physical manipulation of objects. However, Inside is much more than a conventional puzzle game. Rather, it is justifiably deemed to be an exemplar of video games that can be regarded as interactive art. Just see for yourself!

This game is incredible. It's such a huge leap in every area from the dev's first game Limbo. The art direction and visual storytelling is masterclass. It makes me wish more 2D/2.5D games elaborated on their worlds in the background. The puzzles were also consistently inventive (a trait shared by it's predecessor) .

 I love exploring large and foreign/alien environments that are interesting enough to feel like they have a lot of history. Some games seemingly try to have a world like this but it can still be boring if what the player is doing isn't engaging and the window you have into that world is pointed at the wrong place. Despite being only ~4 hours long, this game hooked me into it's setting immediately and never loosened it's grip the entire time. The setting is just that good. It's a masterpiece. 

Play this game if your tastes align with any of the following:
- weird scifi
- puzzle platformers
- giant megastructures
- belief in the strength in numbers
- fear and respect of deep and dark spaces 
- speculative narratives
- having 4 hours of free time

INSIDE is a very interesting little disturbing game. The story has been very nice so far. i havent beat it just yet but i have gotten all achievements. INSIDE is a very special experience. You start off in a forest as a boy that seems to be running away from or towards something. That's it, that is all you know. There is no dialogue, no writing, no tutorial nor any explanation as to what the hell is going on. The game uses environmental storytelling and visuel set pieces rather than words to convey the story.  The same minimalist approach can be seen in the gameplay, with only a jump button, an interact button and directionnal inputs. Yet the puzzles remain engaging and appropriately challenging. Finally, it is, in my opinion, a masterclass in atmosphere : the sound design and visuals are phenomenal.

Even though it is very short (approx. 4 hours to complete), I have continued thinking about INSIDE long after reaching the end credits.  

9/10

Inside is a puzzle-platform game about a kid in a dystopian world where big robots are watching, people are zombified and controlled, and the kid is trying to solve environmental puzzles and avoid death. This is from the same developers as Limbo, a game that I really enjoyed but havenâ€™t finished, so I genuinely wanted to play this for a long time while keeping myself away from spoilers. Compared with Limbo, this is a completely different game with a new set of styles.

The graphics are on another level that focuses a lot on the atmosphere that tells the story of whatâ€™s going on through background that never uses a single line of dialogue. It gives off that sense of ominous feel that you donâ€™t know whatâ€™s going on at first until you dive further into this dystopian world. The puzzles in this are challenging, but ultimately rewarding and make you feel legitimately smart when going through them and not feel frustrated over them. The controls are so tight that even when I was playing it on my potato PC, I didnâ€™t get any issues with the frame rate or the gameplay that was too slow or lagging.

I also genuinely like the story surrounding the atmosphere that gives you enough details where you get a glimpse of what itâ€™s about, but not too much where itâ€™s just absolutely spelled out to you as the gamer and dive into your interpretations of the deeper levels of this game. The ending completely shocked me that I honestly didnâ€™t think it was going to head in that direction and kept myself out in the open. I wouldnâ€™t say it changed the whole game, but it definitely changed some aspects whether it be the story that starts to add up or the gameplay style thatâ€™s a bit more fast-paced. The game is relatively short, took me over three and a half hours long, but thatâ€™s honestly for the main game because Iâ€™m sure if I go back to it just to 100% complete it, itâ€™ll be like five to six hours long. Which is pretty good for a game that has the right balance thatâ€™s not rushed or dragged. Inside is a masterpiece thatâ€™s up there as one of my favorite games that I definitely would like to revisit it just to 100% the game and see the new details that I missed out on from the main game.

The game setting is similar to Limbo where you solve puzzles and the colourful graphics look stunning with amazing lighting effects. I would recommend the game just to experience its great visuals. 
The game does a good job in keeping you in suspense... even after the end of the game. It tricks you into believing that your main objective is to escape, until you get shot with guns. The game is about survival, you need to hide and timely solve puzzles, and not get captured. 
The only lacking part is the story. You would think the story would slowly be revealed as you play, but it is still unclear what happened to the world, why the boy needed to escape, what the ending meant, or what was the game trying to achieve at the end.
Overall, the stunning visuals and smooth controls were great, but the story felt very lacking and the ending very disappointing.

Ah, the intricacies of video games, a realm where one can escape the banalities of existence, if only for a fleeting moment. Now, let's dissect the enigmatic gem that is "Inside." Brace yourself for a cerebral journey through the digital abyss.

"Inside" is not merely a game; it's a contemplative odyssey that transcends the boundaries of conventional storytelling. Its minimalist aesthetic, a chiaroscuro symphony of shadows and light, mirrors the starkness of existence in a world devoid of empathy. The protagonist's journey, shrouded in ambiguity, becomes a metaphorical descent into the abyss of the human psyche.

The gameplay itself is a delicate dance with despair, as players navigate the desolate landscapes, each puzzle a metaphorical obstacle mirroring life's ceaseless challenges. The puzzles are not mere brainteasers; they are existential conundrums, a reflection of the absurdity that permeates our daily struggles. The sheer elegance of the design belies the underlying nihilism that echoes through the corridors of the digital realm.

As you guide the faceless protagonist through this Kafkaesque nightmare, the ambiance is not just haunting; it's a symphony of existential dread. The oppressive silence punctuated by sporadic sounds amplifies the void, a stark reminder of the hollowness that often defines our human interactions. It's a commentary on the superficiality that you so disdainfully observe in your surroundings.

Now, let's delve into the narrative, a tapestry woven with threads of ambiguity. "Inside" doesn't hold your hand; it invites you to interpret its enigmatic tapestry. The narrative's elusiveness is not a flaw; it's a deliberate choice, a provocation to engage your dormant intellect. It's a mirror reflecting the banality of concrete reality, challenging you to discern meaning in a world that often seems bereft of purpose.

In the end, "Inside" is not a game; it's a meditation, a contemplation on the futility of our pursuits, a stark reminder of the hollowness that permeates our existence. Embrace the nihilistic embrace of "Inside," and perhaps, in its digital corridors, you might find a reflection of the cynicism that courses through your veins.

Before this game I played Limbo from the same studio. I definitely liked the tension and vibe it created - it was a good mix between fast chase elements and slow challenges. The puzzles were well thought out and weren't repetitive. Overall I would say it was well spent couple of hours. The only think I would add is some narration.

Reminded me a lot of Another World. Did have more mechanics, twists and puzzles, but felt similar. For the sale price, I highly recommend. The 18 year's age restriction for violence is also very correct.

The first thing I want so say is that I watched somebody play this game before playing it myself, which made my experience very different than somebody doing a blind playthrough.
This game is very well done, but it is also very linear. I couldn't see myself playing this a second time, doing everything I just did again with a tiny bit of new gameplay just to get the second ending. Even though I enjoyed this game, I wouldn't pay the full price for effectively 3-4 hours of gameplay.

INSIDE is a masterclass in visual storytelling, perfectly combining its unsettling, dark mood with an immersive sound design. From the opening scene, the game draws you into its monochromatic world, painted in shades of gloom and mystery. The absence of explicit dialogue makes the rich, detailed environments and the subtle animations of the protagonist and his adversaries speak volumes, crafting a narrative that is both haunting and compelling.

The sound design in INSIDE is nothing short of brilliant. Each footstep, ambient sound, and the distant echoes contribute to a soundscape that envelops the player, enhancing the eerie, often claustrophobic atmosphere.

One of the most appealing aspects of INSIDE is how it evokes a sense of dread and curiosity simultaneously. The game's pacing is impeccable, with each new area presenting a unique set of challenges and visual marvels. The use of lighting and shadows not only adds to the visual appeal but also plays a crucial role in the gameplay and storytelling.

In essence, INSIDE feels like a Roy Anderson (a Swedish movie director) film transformed into an interactive medium. It's a haunting journey through a dystopian world that stays with you long after you've put down the controller. The game is a testament to the power of visual and auditory storytelling, proving that games can be as artistically profound and emotionally resonant as the best films.
Very" recommended,what a masterpiece game.

Atmospheric puzzle-platformer horror game with a beautiful art style. You start off knowing nothing, learn as you go, and end... well, that'd be spoilers. I strongly recommend going in without spoiling the story for yourself.

My only complaint is the price point. It's too short to be $20-worth of game play.

one of the most cinematic games ever, seriously.

even playing through it after watching a playthrough on YouTube years ago was an awesome experience.

the visuals and sound design are so tight and crisp, and the only thing I can think to say is that $20 is pretty fair as a price for the quality, however I wish it was longer (it's about 2-3 hours to get through the whole thing, more time if you go back for collectibles, if the puzzles get tricky for you, etc.)

nonetheless, it's highly rated for a reason and if you don't know what happens, try your best not to look at anything online and just try your best to get through it without any guides.

I literally squealed as the water creatures chased me, they didn't leave a whole lot of buffer on the time but that made it more exciting but not too hard once you spotted where to go next! 

As for the story, I think it's a 'make of it what you will' situation and in fact I think it urges you to form your own opinion on the story rather than just blindly agree to others.

This game was such a massive disappointment to me considering how many "Indie Games to Play Before You Die"-type lists I've seen it on. I love the concept of a wordless narrative and I think it's possible to do it very well, but it's not done well here. The story leads you to believe you're part of some Orwellian landscape and you're confronted with all these different challenges and evils that seem so completely disconnected it ruins any possibility of intrigue. There was very little in me that was interested in finding out why things were the way they were. What kept me going through the game and enduring the brutalization of this nameless little boy was the hope that it would finally get interesting but it just... didn't. The main climax of the story is predictable. And the secret ending is even more of a predictable cop-out than the regular ending. 

Overall it just feels like an overly-brutal waste of time.

The visuals and audio create an atmosphere that pulls you in. The puzzles have just the right level of difficulty and I liked that progress is saved at frequent check-points, which allowed me to work through  in small bite-sized chunks and not forcing me to replay parts that I'd already solved. Inside worked perfectly on the Steam Deck and is a neat little piece of art.

Interesting horror atmosphere ruined by slow, tedious gameplay and a completely unsatisfying ending. All of the puzzles are trivial to solve but take a long time to do and any mistakes mean you get to restart the entire thing. I wish I had just watched someone who already knows the solutions play through it instead so I didn't have to waste so much time running back and forth. The ending is just...[spoiler] nothing. It resolves nothing. You get turned into a body-horror monster, which is interesting, but then the rest of the game is escaping, and when you finally do, you just plop down on the ground and stop moving while the camera slowly zooms out and credits roll. I guess you die? It sure makes everything feel completely pointless.[/spoiler]

if you liked Limbo, you will definitely like this game even more, since this game steps up even more on what did Limbo great. 
INSIDE has really great visuals and a great art direction, with a twisted, dark and apocalyptic feel to it, it's a masterpiece of the genre, specially on its atmospheric and world build up, with a really interesting way of telling its story without utilizing any dialogues or specific clues, thus, by this means giving the players the choice of thinking about the story and interpret it the way they want.
The story and the universe of the game itself is abstract, but is very deep, dark and dystopic, and the game nails in the visual aspect and exposure of this twisted and diseased world even without any piece of dialogue, what most got my attention was the visuals, fluid gameplay and the creativeness of the art direction on the scenarios and ambiances, with every ambiance being really well thought out and the attention to details on all of them its actually a work of art, all of that accompanied by a great BGM. 
INSIDE is more focused on the experience by itself, so the game is not hard at all and the puzzles are quite easy, but that's not a bad thing by any means, since they still managed to have really creative, interesting and fun puzzles to do. Definitely a classic, and a must have experience.

I continuously pray for more content from indie games like this, I thoroughly enjoy the environment and challenges they throw in; but I also crave lore, mystery, and a little bit more time into a playthrough for enjoyability.

Worthy of recommendation on atmosphere alone, but It's got far more than atmosphere. It offers plenty of interesting puzzles with novel mechanics, tight controls, and an ambiguous, unspoken, but likely deep story that ventures into meta commentary about gaming and society.  Even if you're looking for a casual experience, uninterested in analyzing the subtleties of the environment for plot, you'll likely find the game pleasantly creepy, and its ending funny and cathartic. it's a masterpiece of platforming in a small package.

It's December 2023 and the year has had so many wonderful game releases. Yet here I am playing Inside and thinking that there's not a lot of games that had such a powerful tone and affect. And this is compounded when I think of how Inside has no dialogue, no mission markers, no weapons, etc. It's the way the characters are animated, the use of lighting and sound to create a strong sense of place, the way the game moves you forward effortlessly. Honestly, it's an amazing game (and also plays wonderfully on my Steam Deck). I easily and highly recommend!

Really great experience, despite some rather big flaws.

On the positive side, the atmosphere is excellent. I really felt like I was fighting for survival (the immediate respawn upon death didn't undermine the tension for me). The art direction is perfect; simple textures with de-saturated colors, but the environment has so much depth and scale to it. The water that you frequently must swim through also looks incredible, with all the particulates floating in it, and the way the light diffuses through the murky depths. On that note, the lighting is perfect in this game. Sound design and music are good, if a bit understated.

On the negative side, so many of the situations involve tedious back and forth: baiting enemies one way so you can do a little bit of a task, then baiting them back the other way, rinse and repeat. These often felt like they took ages, and were uninteresting after I saw what needed to be done. The story is also ambiguous for ambiguity's sake. Although that type of thing normally bothers me, it didn't in this case, it felt like it fit. But if you're the type of person who likes clear explanations for everything, this probably isn't for you.

One more positive. The animations in this game are incredible! They flow so seamlessly and bring so much life to your character. Normally, movement that's driven by animation feels sluggish to me (as opposed to animation driven by movement), but here it felt perfect. It was like there was no barrier of translation between my hands and the character; he did everything I wanted him to. The controls feel effortless, and I can't stress enough how impressive that is.

Yeah, everyone talks about how to interpret the ending or the story, but I will not. The "story rich" tag is a joke that people like to attach games that deliberately don't give a story, let the ends loose and trust it to the gamer to interpret in this case. I don't have a problem with games like this but I will rate the game solely on the gameplay experience. 

Inside gives you joy for around 4 hours if you play the first time, and 2 hours if you know the resolution to the puzzles. But what a 2-4 hours! The gameplay is polished to the end. The motions are fluid. The camera angle of the 2.5D is just perfect. All. The. Times. The mechanics are simple since you have only directional buttons and 2 action buttons (by default jump and interact). Yet the game provides a great learning curve to explain your possibilities one by one, and at the moment you explored all the options it can offer, the game changes. It's just perfect, the puzzles never get old, notorious, and since you have only a few options any given time you never get stuck for too long, hence inciting you to look the answer up. The time-based puzzles are not requiring you to millisec precision, neither too easy to destroy the tension. I love these kind of polished, short games, they are the perfect "rebound" games between long ones. And Inside is almost perfectly polished, one rarely witness so few graphical glitches (sometimes happens when you interact with moving objects) and zero bugs, or a game that can keep up the attention for its whole length (even if its just a few hours). 

I could guessed the creator is the same as the creator of Limbo, even without looking it up, they are really similar, but Inside is more polished. Buy at a price you find worthy for a few hours of playtime, but buy it, you won't regret it.

[h1] My Honest Reaction: Playdead's [b]INSIDE[/b][/h1]

Short and bittersweet, [b]INSIDE[/b] is a dark interactive puzzle experience, following a boy escaping a gloomy dystopia obsessed with control and subjugation.

The minimal stylistic art-choice paired with the eerie soundscape, as well as the grandiose yet empty backgrounds makes grounds for a constant unsettling experience. Each section of INSIDE actively takes you to the edge of your seat, in fear  and in anxious warning of the unexpected.

I've played the entirety of INSIDE twice now, the second time just for the sake of 100% and reminiscing how this is such a good example of a short linear narrative-driven game this is, when I first played it years ago. Although some might disagree, its conclusion is fitting considering the consistent tone this game exudes and establishes strong thematic intent when exhibiting the world it is attempting to portray. The world is unfair and its environment is aware of that notion.

[h3][b]8.5/10[/b][/h3]

Great game! I love the limited story so you can interpret for yourself what is happening or what the symbolism is. This is like a dark version of Super Mario mixed with atari's Pitfall games & some light puzzles.

I think this game's template has limitless potential and I hope to see more from the game developers. Some other ideas that can be used for future games is an open world / metroidvania feel or even some light fighting. For example, imagine a boss fight where instead of hacking/slashing at it (which can still hurt them), you instead need to do some light puzzle in the game's arena to defeat it (like getting something to fall on top of the bad guy).

Great Job, Team! Can't wait to see what you make next!

"Inside" marked my inaugural gaming journey, and as a fan of brainteasers, this choice proved satisfying. The game's captivating atmosphere and the pursuit of glowing achievements enriched my experience. The ending, while intriguing, left me grappling with the intricacies of the plot until its final revelation.

Though the narrative eluded me during much of the game, its essence became clear in the concluding moments. The message, "it can be hard when you're alone, but when you work in a group, it gets easier," resonated deeply. The thematic exploration of collaboration as a means to ease life's challenges added a layer of significance to the overall experience.

"Inside" not only satisfied my puzzle-solving cravings but also provided a thought-provoking reflection on the importance of teamwork. As a first-time gamer, the atmospheric allure and meaningful message of unity in "Inside" have left an indelible mark on my gaming initiation.

I just had to drop in and share my overwhelmingly positive experience with Playdead's INSIDE. Seriously, if you haven't played it yet, stop everything you're doing and get on it! This game is an absolute masterpiece that deserves all the praise it's been getting.

Let's start with the environment - breathtaking doesn't even begin to cover it. INSIDE's world is like a visual symphony, with every frame carefully crafted to create a hauntingly beautiful experience. The attention to detail is mind-blowing, and the atmosphere sucks you in from the first moment. I found myself just standing there, in awe of the dystopian beauty that Playdead has created.

Now, the puzzles - they are the epitome of perfection. Playdead has this magical ability to design puzzles that are challenging enough to make you feel like a genius when you solve them but not so difficult that you want to throw your controller across the room. Each puzzle feels like a work of art, seamlessly woven into the narrative, making the entire experience feel like one cohesive masterpiece.

And let's talk about the sound design - pure genius. The ambient sounds, the haunting music, the lack of traditional dialogue - it all comes together to create an audio landscape that elevates the game to a whole new level. It's not just background noise; it's an integral part of the storytelling that adds depth and emotion to every moment.

INSIDE is more than a game; it's a journey, an emotional rollercoaster that leaves you thinking long after you've finished playing. Playdead has outdone themselves with this one, delivering an experience that is not just overwhelmingly positive but overwhelmingly brilliant.

Have you played INSIDE yet? What blew you away the most - the mesmerizing environment, the mind-bending puzzles, or the impeccable sound design? Share your thoughts, fellow gamers, because INSIDE is a game that deserves to be celebrated!

A bit like a Black Mirror episode became a platformer game.

I was just looking for a story somewhere. I played for 40 minutes and I feel like they gave us nothing meaningful. I know there's some kind of mind control thing but that's it. So if it doesn't use story to drive engagement then it must be using excellent platforming mechanics since the art and music is described as "dark and moody" (not a plus in my book), right?

No.

The character feels about as good at running and jumping as you expect and somewhat better than expected at falling (slightly longer falls still insta kill you though). The puzzles weren't too bad, but a little hard to figure out at times while generally easy to execute. I prefer easier to figure out the answer and harder to execute for platformer games.

Over all I would say I was just bored, bored, bored! Boring story, boring graphics and music, boring platforming. I need at least one of those categories to interest me if you want more than half an hour of my time.

It was never too challenging or frustrating and I enjoyed the rate of progress through the game. 

It was very atmospheric and beautiful to look at despite the dystopian feel.

I did play it again to find all the orbs, but using a walk-through as I do not have much patience for covering old ground. I'm not sure that was worth bothering with. It didn't offer much that was new or interesting.

The attention to detail is unparalleled in this indie masterpiece. There are areas where the camera pans out, the music builds the tension and all the sound effects are stopped while you just sit and experience an emotional part of the game. Little details like this make it stand out from other mechanically well-done games that lacks the emotional and artistic experience that this game offers.

Watch the differences in the characters as you progress, the animations of the boards when you pull them or drop them in the water. There are no despawn animations, no cheesy power-ups or anything else to suggest you are playing a game; making it feel quite real despite the low-poly models.

Okay a few warnings: this game is quite graphic and I do not recommend it for children. There are also a lot of deep water scenes and a horror creature that will bother some people who have water-based phobias. The ending is also a little jarring and abrupt and there are almost no answers to many of the questions you accumulate as you play.

Overall, cannot recommend it enough. Limbo started the genre. Inside perfected it.

Splendidly superb. Playdead just nails the atmosphere, sound and visuals in their games.
you know its good when the water sections are good too

Inside is a 2D puzzle platformer game that has a simple, but gloomy art style defined by muted colors and faceless figures. Its mystery filled dystopian world is brought to life through its grim atmosphere and remarkable sound design. The game displays a subtle attention to detail, the animation is fluid, and the puzzles are direct, but sometimes perplexing. Inside is downright uncanny throughout. It is a short-lived game, but it brings astounding set pieces and a memorable final sequence.

Really awesome. Go in without knowing ANYTHING.
It feels like a movie wherein you are the main protagonist and the length kind of feels that way as well. The pacing is done very well and the visual storytelling is nicely done.
The puzzles are also designed well, the trial and error from Limbo carries over but here it feels less frustrating.
Nothing else much to say, but this is a game that will always stick with me with how crazy cool, and crazy crazy it is.
GOOD
Absolute banger!

An Atmospheric, engaging platformer, at times felt more like an interactive short story. It's strength was the pretty simple controls let you to experience the 'Inside' of that world rather than interact at a distance, good twist at the end, it's quiet and dark so you find yourself leaning in with an eyebrow raised as it develops you're making 'ooo --ahh --eeekk' noises especially at the beginning when you are listening/looking for clues attentively.

My interest did wane in the final 3rd act, I feel it could have done with more immediate threat, time pressure sequences, more interesting chases or maybe wack in a few timely jumps scares and that would have kept me on my toes. Just as the game was becoming a tad predictable the story ended not in the climax I expected but with a surprising discordant tone, and loose ends which leaves the user with some room for interpretation which I liked a lot and of course you can go back to get the 100% achievements to add more depth to the yarn. 

If there was to be a sequel it could do with some expansion in game-play, some harder puzzles or a Co-op feature in this universe what with the 'mind control puzzle bits' that would add to what is a pretty cool creation. So basically that was good... now do more.
perfect amount of creepy, meets puzzles.

Great game with totally briliant visuals and unspoken, yet sad story behind our adventure. 

It is actually hard to describe it. It is a bit of a puzzle game, but puzzles are bit different to what we usually have in adventure games or classical puzzle games (like Myst, Uru ect). Inside also looks like a standard side-scrolling game. We move from left to right. Puzzles dont require running around and spending time on stupid traveling - most of the solutions can be found on the very same screen we are at. Sometimes it is a matter of moving few screens around, which is actually very good. I never enjoyed spending most of the time in adventure games just walking between points. Most of the puzzles are pretty easy - once you learn how simplified mechanics works in this game, you just know what to use, and how to use. Most difficult puzzles require bit more thinking, but again: if you understand how game works, you will solve them relatively quickly. Funny thing is that while puzzles are not very hard, or even very easy at times, they are not stupid. They all seem to be a proper element of the world we see.

Game is very short - it can be easily finished within some 5 hours, plus some more time to deal with achievements (I guess these are most difficult part of the game). While 5 hours dont sound as a lot of fun it is really okay. This game is bit more than just a side-scroller or puzzle game. It really has this something inside. It is grim, dark, sad game, even bit emotional at times. Those 5 horus were pretty much okay for me - I enjoyed them fully and loved the game.

One more thing - game doesnt communicate with us. We get no introduction, no story is told. We start just like that... and we also end just like that. Everything is just shown to us, but in most cases it is our imagination that has to build a full picture. While Inside is one of the shorters adventure/puzzle games I've ever played, it is also one of the best.

Really liked this game, not too short (I completed in 7 hours) great visuals and atmosphere. The puzzles were good nothing too hard, quite easy once you've tried one way and then the other. Some puzzles took a little more time to figure out but didn't get stuck for long. 

The controls are really simple too (left, right, up, down, jump & grab) so really simple for all ages to get to grips with.

Overall I'm very impressed and look forward to playing something similar, this must have taken the developers ages to create as so smooth and atmospheric.

This game is a masterpiece of atmospheric storytelling. Its wordless narrative, eerie world, and clever puzzles kept me hooked from start to finish. This game is an unforgettable experience that leaves a lasting impression. Highly recommended.

Completely and utterly dark, brooding and despondent. You're constantly feeling oppressed from the overpowering moodiness of the visual and sound design, but hypnotised by the story which is told entirely in the desolate industrial labyrinths that you traverse. I thought some of the puzzles were too trial-and-error or tedious for my taste, but INSIDE is definitely one of the most interesting games I've ever played.

Playdead's follow-up to LIMBO takes everything that made its predecessor great and heavily expands it. Despite this being a voiceless and text-deprived puzzle adventure, this game absolutely nails storytelling in level design, sound design, and the dark atmosphere always looming throughout.

Who you are and what your purpose is, is unknown. As you explore the bleak and post-apocalyptic lands around you, filled with dangers of many kinds, you ultimately end up in a giant construct that is who knows for what purpose.
It's all up to interpretation about what exactly is going on in the world around you, which could either be a good or a bad thing, for better or worse, whichever you prefer, but the game does show a recurring theme throughout early on, which I won't spoil.

The game is relatively short, consisting of only 2-3 hours worth of gameplay, with maybe 4 in total including the secret ending, but it will remain in the back of your mind for a long time.

This game is an incredible achievement. It's essentially a left to right scroller with a jump and an action key - that's it. You will complete it in between 7 & 8 hours game time - that's it. There's no spoon fed narrative, only the one you build yourself and a not totally defined ending. But IT IS BRILLIANT!

The developers have produced a wonderful, pathos filled game, which builds towards the game's surprising final chapter. The visuals are dark and foreboding - recognisably similar to our world but chillingly 'wrong'; like something from Simon Stalenhag's mind.  The puzzles are compelling and the scenery and gameplay are surprisingly varied given the practical limitations of the setup (up, down, left, right, & action is all you get!). They all combine to build an eery suspenseful narrative arc; the story however is completely, unapologetically, defined by the player. Whatever you take from it; how much is metaphor, literal, allegory, post-apocalyptic, dystopian, a fever dream, a coma patient, the insides of the mind of an amorphous blob...whatever you take from it is simply the developer holding up a mirror - you the player do all the narrative work. And I am 100% ok with that.

I understand the destination won't please everybody, but you sure should enjoy the journey.

There's something unusually compelling about this game. The controls and premise are simple. There's no dialogue or narrative or story besides what you see and interpret for yourself. And yet the style and vibe have an beautiful yet... oppressive urgency. You have to move forward. You have to see what's next.

For stripped down controls (4 directions and an action button) and a straightforward premise (the platforming standard: "go to the right"), the challenges can be refreshingly inventive. A praiseworthy feat for a gaming genera that's already been so thoroughly explored.

It all comes together for that rare, no BS, Truly Complete Gaming Experience right out of the box. The physics work perfectly with the sound direction and art style and make for some grisly yet hilarious deaths. The game isn't long, but there's no fat to trim. Everything was as it needed to be. The controls are simple and yet just the right amount of strange. Almost like trying to run in a dream.

I would rate this game Excellent and highly recommended. I look forward to more games from this developer.

Playdead's Limbo is a classic, but its spiritual successor Inside is even better. Much like the Danish developer's debut game, Inside is a wordless trek fraught with tension, tight puzzle-platforming, and incredible sound design. The animations are so fluid and natural that at times the game beggars belief that it's being played in real-time.

Despite its refusal to give any answers, Inside never comes across as pretentious. Its unconventional plot is still spawning interpretations to this day, but more important than what it tells you is what it made you feel. Where the gameplay feels alternately thrilling and satisfying, the story felt melancholic and profound.

Inside is a short game, clocking in at just over three hours, and it lacks immediate replay value because of the kind of game it is. Yet I don't think the value of a game lies in how many hours of your time it ate up, but rather how long it lingered inside your heart. And in that respect, this game is triumphant.
The puzzle makes you engaged with little to no explanation. The feels when you solve the problem to make your way is so thrilling. You should try it.

[h1]Alta Subreale Experientia[/h1]

[i]There will be a TL;DR at the end[/i]

~

There is a place between the lucid confines of deep sleep and the twilight shallows of a waking mind. Imprisoned between is that lurid realm where thoughts coalesce into elements both theoretical and physical, metaphorical and literal. An inescapable tempest of pure representation and pandemonium where all aspects derive a deeper meaning, yet oblivion seizes truth from its otherwise lambent display.
Beneath the heights of joy were your electrochemical source dazzles your memory in a display of beauty beyond human comprehension - and above the mire of doubt and loathing that wreaks a toll of destruction by conjuring the deepest and most unpalatable horrors and discomforts to be tested.

It is here where the surreal thrives.
Beneath the weight of an unburdened moon and bubbling up from the bile of a restless soul.

Lost in the shifting tide of sleep and thought.

This is where [i]INSIDE[/i] resides.

I played this game three times. Twice on console and once here. And it has never failed to impress me.

This is more than a simple puzzle game. It is more than a fragment of entertainment. This is art.
It captures the fire from beyond the veil of forgotten experiences and brings it to the forefront like Prometheus to humankind.

It transcends the prospects of adventure, it is more than political commentary, it is above a simple tumble through a new dystopian world, it is beyond horror.

[i]INSIDE[/i] is [b]art[/b].

It evokes a powerful emotion, a recollection of things that were and yet never will be.
It is a portal to those itinerant visions that taunted your lucid tumbles through the catacombs of your own mind - yet so easily forgot after the sun washed away those perilous journeys in waking.

What does it mean to be alive?
What does it mean to be a slave?
What is my purpose?
Is there such a thing as free will?

There is no way of telling how you will walk away from the experience, but it will evoke an emotion out of your hardened heart regardless of direction. Frustration, curiosity, despondence, hopelessness, empathy, joy, envy, pride, doubt, and anywhere in between. It is a potent and powerful experience that concisely delivers a digital display of didactic poetry.

It is a moving masterpiece, it is a picture of a thousand dreams, and it is an insular whisper held in the back of your mind begging to be remembered.

I enjoyed having the existential dread teased to the forefront of my mind. Seeing things surreal and abstract yet so real and clear moved me back into lost memories spanning decades of dreams and ambitions long buried. Demanding and commanding emotions in addition to curiosity make for a potent experience.

~

[h3]TL;DR[/h3]
[b]8.5/10[/b].
[i]INSIDE[/i] is an [b]Excellent[/b] experience.
It leaves you with more questions than answers, but the questions alone are the unique gift that only a piece like this is capable of delivering.

This is probably one of the most abstract, surreal games I've ever played. From the makers of Limbo, I would expect nothing less. I know I'm mega late with this one but I just played through and finished it and wanted to give this game yet another glowing review. 

This game has a lot to offer, but its all very subtle. There's no dialogue, no action per say, you spend the entire game running from things trying to kill you and its kind of scary. It plays on a lot of suspenseful fear rather than unrelenting jump scares that plague the horror game community right now and I much prefer this style of fear since it more closely mimics how we experience fear in the real world. 

Say what you want about games like Five Nights at Freddy's or The Mortuary Assistant for example, but when the jump scare is over, I never felt any sort of fear, and once you play through the game over again and you have experienced every jump scare there is to offer, its pretty underwhelming, at least for me. Very rarely does the average night guard find himself attacked by rogue robots or the average mortician surrounded by a demon infestation. Its hard to immerse yourself into a genuinely terrifying experience with that. However, fear comes to us in much more subtle ways. Like a sound at the end of the hallway that is too dark to see whats out there, or a sudden shift in the energy of a room that makes the hairs stand up, THAT is fear. 

I'm not even sure if Inside does this on purpose, but they do this very well. I wouldn't necessarily call it "subtle" however, its definitely very obvious what is going on and why you should be afraid. To avoid spoilers I wont necessarily go into detail but most of the fear comes from running and hiding from things that are trying to kill you and where the fear comes in for me personally is how brutal it is if you fail. If you fail to run from things or hide successfully or if you zig when you need to zag, its really dark and the child that you are playing as gets brutally murdered in front of your eyes. Other than the horror however, the game is pretty much just a basic platformer and puzzle game, which is pretty fun. None of the puzzles felt really impossible and incredibly challenging, but the platforming and puzzles don't really feel like the point of the game. This is definitely a more story focused game. 

The story itself however is super confusing. This is one of those things where you will play the game and be combing through the game in your mind to try and come up with a likely answer as to what has just taken place on your screen. Its interesting, but I guess the only criticism i have is that its too shallow. I dont feel like there is enough world here for the story to be incredibly entangled in mystery. 

To be incredibly clear, I think the reason this game is so "mysterious" in its current state is simply because nothing is explained. Which, yes, thats how a mystery works, but Its like trying to make a riddle about a flat tire and saying it was a mystery when in reality, you just got a flat tire. Yes, it could be a mystery to someone who doesn't know what happened, but in reality its an extremely basic and simple occurrence that could be easily explained with a 10 second conversation. To sum up my critique here, this game is purposely left really open ended as to what the plot is, What exactly is the boy running from, what the ending means and so forth and trys to display how evil the opposition (to keep it vague for spoilers) is so that the player can draw their own conclusions and their own lore. But I think the game is so shallow in its current state and the mystery isn't deep enough to really come away with many conclusions. For instance, imagine watching American Psycho and you watch the scene where Bateman kills Paul Allen, and then you skip right to the scene were Bateman talks to his lawyer in person. While its not clear what is really happening, the only real two outcomes is that Bateman did kill Allen, or his lawyer is covering for him. Its not really that deep. 

I think the story COULD be one of the most enthralling mysteries in gaming if they put a little bit more world building and effort into it, but thats not to say what we have here is bad necessarily, it just feels like a smidge of lost potential. 

Putting my basic, super nit picky takes aside, I think this is a great game and I loved Limbo and I think this is definitely a step up from that game. Especially since you can get this game for literal couch cushion money these days, definitely pick this game up and give it a play.

INSIDE is like that game you stumble upon when you're browsing, and then it totally blows your mind. I

It's a side-scrolling game that feels like a really eerie dream. You play as this kid in a red jacket, and the whole world is just plain weird. There are puzzles, but they're not the math kind; more like figuring out how to get past creepy folks and avoid getting squished or drowned.

The graphics are top-notch. Everything is dark, but in a way that's super cool.The music adds to the spookiness, and it's almost like you're in a suspenseful movie.

The story? Well, it's a mystery. You won't get a manual, but that's kinda the point. You're supposed to piece it together, and the ending...whew, it's a twisty one. When you finish, you'll probably go, "Wait, what just happened?" But in a good way.

INSIDE is short, like a good book you can't stop reading. It's not a big, open-world thing, but it doesn't need to be. It's an experience, and it's totally worth the ride. If you're into dark and mysterious stuff and don't mind a bit of head-scratching, give it a shot. You won't be disappointed.
