I played Limbo a few years ago but was disappointed. It took me some time to trust the developer again and try INSIDE - Glad I did.

There is no cutscene, no introduction, not a single word presented in the game, but it gets the meaning straightforward using graphics and music. A horizon-scroll horror game, where you control a boy solving well-made puzzles, always running forward and into the unknown. Can't say I'm a horror game lover but I enjoyed the early and recent RE games, Outlast franchise and so is this one, as long as there's no jump scares nor disturbing gore it's alright.

The puzzles are well-balanced both in difficulty and in quantity, keeps me interested all the time, and the way of presenting is impactful, things give me an immersive feeling. The favorite goes to the part where you mimic mindless people walking forward, jumping and facing the right rhythm and direction to fool anyone to believe that you are one of them, then escape. It's smart as well as creepy. INSIDE is not always about survival, you also gotta appreciate the arts like the bodies floating in water like kites in the sky, or in that anti-gravity place where everything is upside down. It's interesting to look at the world from a different angle and INSIDE showed me.

The last part of the game was unexpecting, I liked the idea of making the protagonist into [spoiler]what people feared and seeing everyone scared and fled[/spoiler], brilliant the game also asked the player to go from right to left after the change, in chaos I panicked and picked whatever path that was open. There's no boss fight nor difficulties I can't pass - a bit challenging for the water witch, the walkthrough feels smooth, creative, and gives insights.

Would love to see more games like this one.

Fresh off my disappointing experience with LIMBO, I apprehensively jumped into INSIDE. I found the puzzles to be much more accessible than LIMBOâ€™s. There were still a few that had me thinking, â€œwhy would I ever think to do that?â€, like when you jump out of a barn window into a cart of dead pigs. Aside from the couple of times this occurs throughout the game, I didnâ€™t feel like I had to die 10 times per puzzle to understand what they were wanting. The puzzles are still engaging, just not infuriating.

The atmosphere of the game drew me in. The visual storytelling that occurs in the background really sets the mood as you try and understand why these people are after you, what did these people do, and what are they doing now? Itâ€™s jarring to see faceless masked people watch streams of mind-controlled humans slowly walk by. In one scene to see adults, children, and even a newborn wearing a white mask covering their faces. Itâ€™s creepy and adds to the world.

As to the â€œstoryâ€, itâ€™s up to interpretation and the ending leaves with more questions than answers. As for my interpretation, I felt that at certain points in the story you are being controlled by one of two entities, the scientists, or the experiment. The sirens unplugged you from the â€œMatrixâ€ only to have you under something elseâ€™s control. Unplugging all orbs in the game unlocks a secret ending that does seem to indicate this as well.

Was I blown away? No. Did I enjoy the time I had with the game? Yeah. More than LIMBO? Absolutely!

Inside is a spiritual successor to Limbo, which I did not enjoy much at all. I am happy to say that Inside made big improvements for me in nearly every way. 

First of all, the game once again feels beautiful, especially on a smaller Steam Deck screen. It's not completely black, white, and grey like Limbo is, but the colors are still pretty dark and cold for the most part. The environments and the animations pulled me into its moody world. It's a very long shot to say that there is a story here, since there is no dialogue, text boxes, or explanations of any kind, but there are enough things going on in the backgrounds of the levels that give you hints at what's going on. You play as a young boy again, and this time you're on the run from what looks like the government, or maybe some kind of corporation, who is doing sinister experiments. For whatever reason, they are after you and your job is to escape. You need to piece together much of the story yourself in your head and fill in some blanks, but things get pretty twisted and even disturbing towards the end.

The controls are similar to Limbo. You can move from left to right, jump, and grab on to things to push/pull/turn them. This time the puzzles revolve more around stealth. Usually I don't like stealth in games, especially when its an automatic fail if you don't do it perfectly, but in this game I didn't mind it. You don't need to sneak up on anybody or turn off alarm systems. You mostly just need to hide behind pieces of the environment and time your movements correctly. There are a few parts during which you are chased by things trying to kill you, mostly dogs. I hate being chased in video games, it absolutely terrifies me, and in this game it was no different. Every time I heard the dogs barking I got mini panic attacks. There are some clever puzzles that force you to distract these enemies while you try to break pieces of wood that block your path, and things of that nature. A large portion of the game also takes place in a vehicle under water which adds variety to the gameplay.

Unlike Limbo, in which I felt that the game never really established it's puzzle rules very well, I felt much more comfortable with the puzzles in Inside. The game has a mechanic in which you attach yourself to some kind of head gear that allows you to control people/corpses in the background or around the level, and these puzzles are as simple to understand as they are challenging to complete. I very rarely thought "wow, I didn't know that I could interact with this thing" like I often did in Limbo. The game does not hold your hand, but it also doesn't waste your time by being too cryptic. 

Overall Limbo was a fairly enjoyable and not very long game. I completed it in 3 sittings over the course of one day. It didn't blow me away and I didn't exactly have a blast playing it, but it made me scratch my head a few times as I tried to figure out the puzzles, and it was a cozy experience on a rainy day.

Playdeadâ€™s Limbo and Inside are two sides of the same coin. Both are fantastically well-received indie puzzle-platformers where you play as a nameless young boy in a nameless world, with unique art styles and zero spoken dialogue (other than grunts and whatnot). The story is told through atmosphere, sound design and visual cues. 

Iâ€™m hard pressed to choose between the two. For me, Limbo is more instantly recognisable, and whilst it has some fantastic unique mechanics such as rolling the world through degrees, Inside takes the pip, with gorgeous visuals, more story, a real feeling of dystopia and more memorable mechanics such as the mind control, stealth scenes and one particularly memorable section where you imitate one of the mindless zombies. 

Puzzles strike that perfect balance between challenging and requiring thought without ever feeling unfair. Limbo would often require you to die first to understand what to do, but Inside never does this. Some of the larger puzzles still require trial and error, but more in a way where you will have to walk back and rethink rather than being killed. The puzzles which would kill you can be figured out on the spot before you die, and add to the tension. 

Sound design is once again sparse but a triumph, using dynamics to really make you notice it. Headphones are recommended to really suck you in. 

Inside is one of those games that everybody should experience once. At three and a half hours to finish and grab all of the achievements, it isnâ€™t a significant time investment, but it will stay with you.

So much nostalgia for this game as well as the similar Little Nightmares series, it's one of my favorite games and it's under 3 hours long. You can get it on mobile too, and it's a great experience, that's actually what I first played it on. If you like games such as little nightmares then give this a shot, because this is the game which refined limbo's game design, and both limbo and inside were some of the core inspirations for the little nightmares franchise. After playing Inside as well as Little Nightmares 1 and 2, in my opinion Inside is the better game because the simplicity works in its favor.

Excellent level design meets some of the greatest sound design in any game. Visually stunning and very atmospheric. One of my favourite gaming experiences ever.

This game lives rent free in my head.

This is one of the only games for me that has transcended the medium of video games and become art.

I have played this game multiple times on multiple platforms. Even if you are not interested in the art of it, it plays well are as puzzle platformer. The visuals are gorgeous and stand the test of time. It is very short at about 3 hours if you take your time. Buy on sale if you only want a puzzle platformer.

For me though the real value is in the lasting experience of the game. The themes that pop up in the journey of this boy in the 3 hours of game play are immense and heavy. Without giving too much, themes of sentience, free will, fate, authoritarianism, corporeality, loss, death, youth, ignorance and capitalism are all explored without saying a word. Even the player is a character, in what is possibly the only non-cringe forth wall break in history.

Inside reminded me of the movie "Mad God" by stop motion artist Phil Tippet, both in its atmosphere and mood as well as the grotesque, depressing overwhelming setting. An other way of describing this game is that Inside is like a nightmare, one  of those that you know your in a dream but you can't get out. 

Gameplay wise it is a basic but fun puzzle adventure platformer game only one time did I get stuck and had to look up how to go forward. But to be fair, it is the setting that draws you in and that ending oh gosh that ending.... anyone into grim sad totalitarian settings with a pinch of cronenburg  should give this a go. 

I did not however find the secret ending and having looked it up, yeah that is really cryptic, if you want to challenge yourself be my guest but not for me.

Inside, developed by Playdead and released in 2016, is a video game that stands as a testament to the power of minimalist storytelling and atmospheric design. Much like its predecessor, Limbo, Inside captivates players with its hauntingly beautiful world and thought-provoking narrative. With its understated brilliance, it's a game that lingers in your mind long after you've put down the controller.

One of Inside's most striking features is its visual design. The game's dark and monochromatic palette sets a mood of eerie unease right from the start. The attention to detail in the environments is nothing short of remarkable, with every element carefully crafted to enhance the player's immersion. Lighting plays a pivotal role, creating stunning contrasts and shadows that add depth to the world. Inside's visual storytelling is a lesson in subtlety, conveying the game's dystopian narrative without a single word of dialogue. Instead, it relies on the environment, character animations, and the player's own interpretation to convey its enigmatic story.

The gameplay in Inside is deceptively simple. Players control an unnamed boy who must navigate through a series of increasingly complex puzzles and obstacles. While the gameplay mechanics are straightforward, the challenge lies in the execution and the way the game introduces new elements seamlessly. Inside maintains a perfect balance between puzzle-solving and platforming, making sure the player is always engaged without feeling overwhelmed. It's a testament to the game's design that it never resorts to hand-holding, allowing players to experiment and learn through trial and error.

One of the standout aspects of Inside is its sound design. The eerie, ambient soundtrack perfectly complements the game's somber atmosphere. The absence of a traditional score allows the environmental sounds and the boy's footsteps to take center stage, creating an oppressive sense of isolation. This choice reinforces the feeling of being trapped in a dystopian world where you are constantly being watched and pursued.

What truly sets Inside apart is its narrative ambiguity. As you progress through the game, you are presented with a series of enigmatic events and encounters that leave you with more questions than answers. This open-ended storytelling approach invites players to form their own interpretations and theories about the game's meaning, encouraging discussion and speculation long after the credits roll. Inside is a prime example of video games as an art form, using interactive storytelling to provoke thought and emotion.

If there's a criticism to be made about Inside, it might be its brevity. The game can be completed in a single sitting, which may leave some players wanting more. However, the concise experience can also be seen as a strength, as it ensures that every moment is meticulously crafted and essential to the overall narrative.

In conclusion, Inside is a masterpiece of minimalist gaming. Its hauntingly beautiful world, engrossing atmosphere, and thought-provoking narrative make it a must-play for anyone looking to explore the artistic potential of video games. It's a testament to the power of interactive storytelling and a reminder that sometimes less is more. Inside is an experience that will stay with you, leaving you pondering its mysteries long after the journey ends.

I'm so glad I got this on sale. And even together with it's predecessor, which is in my opinion much more worth the money.

Don't get me wrong. The visuals, the sounds, the atmosphere, the physics are all fantastic. I honestly admire the effort that must have been put into this. But the game is boring as all hell.

Puzzles are easy to the point that they become more annoying than challenging. There was not a single point in the game where I had to think about what to do - the biggest challenge is mostly in precise timing, and if you miss the right spot, you die and / or worse, you have to walk (or swim) back - painstakingly slow - and try again. It gets very tedious very soon.

Story is... well, [i]isn't[/i]. Unlike Limbo, where the lack of context didn't matter, here it feels like there actually is a story, but the game does not even do a terrible work of narrating it; it simply doesn't do [i]any[/i] work. In the beginning it looks like a simple "escape the baddies" scheme. Then this turns (probably) into some kind of dystopia - so far so good. Then the world starts to seem post-apocalyptic - okay, weird turn, but still somehow manageable. And finally, for some reason, it adds horror into the mix. I get that the story, or lack thereof, wants to leave a lot to imagination, but it's so inconsistent that it turns out rather confusing than anything else. [spoiler](Not to mention the giant human meatball in the end.)[/spoiler] I have absolutely no idea how this game is "story rich" and "narrative driven".

It honestly makes me sad that this game didn't turn out at least a bit better, because it has so much potential.

Overall I enjoyed "Inside," even though I'm not a huge fan of games that involve a lot of timing-based puzzles, which this one does. It looks and sounds beautiful -- light years ahead of "Limbo." It's also forgiving with check-points, which I appreciate as a casual gamer. That said, "Inside" doesn't have enough of a story or enough depth of play to hold my interest for more than 1 or 2 run-throughs. There KIND of is a story, but it doesn't really go anywhere, and you don't really do anything within it except interact with objects you need to advance. Once you've completed it, that's it. You can't really do it better or differently. It's more like an experience than it is anything else. To me it was worth what it cost, but not more. And for more serious gamers, it might not be worth what it costs.

Since there are no conversations or words at all in this game, all attention go to the visuals and music/sound effects. The good news is that they are spot on in this game. 

The game is characterized by moody lighting and eerily unsettling sound effects. Its moody art style and ambient soundtrack fits the story well. Controls are easy and besides the 4 directional keys, you only have 1 use key. 

The puzzles are not do difficult, but at times you need to think a bit creatively. The sound design and creepy atmosphere kept me on my toes throughout the entire game. Checkpoints, meanwhile, are liberal enough and load times are brief enough that death never feels like a punishment.

The game relies heavily on the story and sound effects, and since they are both superb, I recommend to stay Inside and play this game!

A game that says a lot without speaking a single word. It is a moody, suspenseful puzzle-platformer with a mysterious story whose meaning is left to your interpretation. The controls are simple enough to share with just about anybody and it's a fun game to watch someone else play and react to.

Just like Limbo you are dropped into a creepy atmospheric world with no explanation or backstory.  Controls are very similar and there are plenty of things that are out to kill you. I will say that the puzzle aren't as hard as Limbo but I actually like it because it allowed me to make progress without getting too stuck on one part. Very short game (Passed in 3 hours) but its a great experiences from start to end. I really like the art direction in this one.  I like how they played with the background and foreground elements and you can really get a sense of the atmosphere. Limbo did a good job as well but it seems like they had more of a budget and more to work with on this one. If you can get it on sale I would definitely get it. And it doesn't take too much time to pass so if your a very busy person (like me) you can actually get through the whole game.  

Video games are a legitimate art form and this one continues to prove that point.

inside is a puzzle platformer developed and published by playdead, a danish indie developer based in copenhagen. the studio was founded sometime in 2006 to develop limbo, their first game released in july 2010. it was a massive success, not even just for a small indie studio from denmark, but it was considered a massive success on a national scale/level. later in 2010 they started development on a second game named "project 2" where they would flesh out all the things the developers liked about limbo and make a new game that wasn't a true sequel. they even got a million dollars in funding from the danish film institute, a agency responsible for supporting and encouraging film and cinema culture, and for conserving these in the national interest. early in development playdead changed engines from a custom built engine to unity after they figured out it would be more efficient and reduce the workload greatly. during e3 2014, playdead announced their second game as a spiritual successor to limbo, with a 'early 2015' release date. after a delay to 'mid-2016' and demo coming in august 2015. a xbox one release came first in late june, while a pc version released in early july, and a PS4 version released in late august. additionally, a release on mobile devices came in december 2017, and a nintendo switch port came in 2018.

gameplay wise, it is a massive improvement over limbo, which was already great when it released in 2010 especially. the main thing that jumps at you right away in the improved art style, but as you dive into the gameplay you'll realize there are intricacies that weren't in the first game, such as collectibles that actually become a huge part of the game's plot/story. i won't delve further than that into the story but it's also a big thing that is great about inside, but in a subtle way that is no doubt biased by me being a completionist and going for 100% on my first run of the game. the deaths, that forced the ESRB to give limbo a teen rating, have been fleshed out even more, which earned inside a mature rating. there are deaths that are a little more graphic, especially with the much-improved art style. 

IGN had played a new exclusive demo at e3 2016 and called the game "super limbo" and compared limbo & inside to the NES & SNES. i agree with the sentiment for the most part, but i really feel like inside does enough to stand out on it's own and separate itself from any potential shadow cast by limbo. i think limbo is a solid game, but limbo, while being a similar size (i 100%'d both in under seven hours each), just doesn't match up to the great new ways that inside will provide similar gameplay elements. i am extremely excited for a third game from playdead, which was first teased in 2017 and as of late 2023 hasn't even been officially revealed in any capacity. 

overall, inside is short, which was also my biggest complaint with limbo. if you haven't played inside or haven't played either of playdead's games, i highly recommend doing so as soon as possible. they're short enough to where you could beat both in a single day if you really wanted to. and going from limbo to inside is a awesome experience and a huge upgrade while being unique enough to stand out on it's own, so it's fun to see the development of the developer. it's a fantastic experience that controls beautifully, making it one of the better games you'll ever play.

[i]INSIDE[/i] as the name implies, places us in the middle of a seemingly unending dystopian labyrinth. The game has a great atmosphere and is very suggestive without telling the audience what to believe. In my playthrough there were a few Easter eggs that subtly tie-in Playdead's previous title, [i]LIMBO[/i]. Although, I enjoyed [i]INSIDE[/i] there really isn't an incentive not to die; the previous title had an achievement for completing in five or less deaths for example. For that reason, [i]INSIDE[/i] felt more like a walking sim to me than an actual puzzle platformer. The lack of challenge isn't necessarily a negative but I personally feel [i]LIMBO[/i] has more replayability. To be fair [i]INSIDE[/i] has about twice the length of story though. So... bottom line the single playthrough is worth the $1.99 I paid for it but don't expect much replay value.

"Inside" is a gaming gem that transcends expectations. Developed by Playdead, this game is a masterpiece of minimalist storytelling and atmospheric design.

From the outset, "Inside" draws you into a hauntingly beautiful and enigmatic world. The absence of dialogue encourages players to interpret the narrative, making it a deeply immersive experience.

But what truly sets "Inside" apart is its depth. Beneath the surface of a platformer lies a narrative that challenges players to contemplate profound themes. Its atmospheric soundtrack adds to the immersion.

"Inside" is more than a game; it's an exploration of human nature and control. With mesmerizing visuals and intricate puzzles, it's an unforgettable journey that will leave you pondering its mysteries long after you've finished.

In short, "Inside" is a must-play, offering a rare level of depth and emotional resonance in the world of gaming. It's a reminder that the most profound adventures often take you inside yourself.

Although it is very aesthetically nice and the gameplay is simple and easy to get into, I left feeling it is too short. Some puzzles are interesting, but it gets old pretty fast. There is very little variation on what you do.

Inside looks like a really simple game but it's really deep and entertaining. Loved challenging puzzles and idea behind the game. To me this game represents the "rat race" people are in nowadays. Time by time society acts like programmed machines, doing same things day by day and slowly all the emotions and happiness we felt back in the days fade away. Fortunately there are still people left who try to stay away from society's standards and they prefer to live their life in their own way. That's exactly what I saw in Inside and it does a great job in showing you all that.

Heads Up: THIS GAME IS HELLA DARK. (Plus Spoilers)

Inside is a Incredible Indie Game Developed by Playdead, the Studio behind Limbo. Released in 2016 for Xbox, PC and PS4, 2017 For iPhone, 2018 for Nintendo Switch and 2020 For Mac-OS. It was Nominated for Game of the Year at the 2016 Game Awards But lost (Fuck you Overwatch). 

The Game Revolves Around a Young Boy Who is Unnamed and his journey through a rather Dystopian World filled with harrowing and weird sights. 

Let's Start with the good: 

- EXCELLENT Ambience, Truly One of the Shining Parts. + 3 Points
- Great Art, Simplistic Yet it works. Reminds me of Superliminal or Untitled Goose Game. +1 Point
- Tells a Tale without a Single Word, Which is Hard to do. the story is portrayed by the Environments and the Surroundings. +1 Point
- The Puzzles Are Really Clever and Intricate, Took me a while to do it.  + 2 Points
- The Subtle yet Somehow Prominent Score Makes this game so much better. + 3 Points 
- Complex and Thought out Story, Even though it's a silent story. + 0.5 Points. 

And now the Bad: 

- The Ending Kind of Dragged. it was rather anticlimactic. - 1 Point
 - it feels like a walking simulator at some points, but it gives me time Admire the Well Crafted Scenery, So 
 i'm Only Deducting Half a Point. - 0.5 Points 
- Can be Frustrating, But that's a Skill issue on my Half. No Points Deducted. 


This Game is a Great Experience with an Interesting Story. Highly Recommended.

[h1] INSIDE: A Masterclass in Atmospheric Storytelling [/h1]

"INSIDE" is a game that doesn't just leave an impression; it etches itself into your memory. Developed by Playdead, the same minds behind "Limbo," this puzzle platformer exudes a unique and haunting charm that keeps players talking long after the credits roll.

Much like its predecessor, "INSIDE" boasts a distinct art style, shrouded in darkness both in tone and color. The characters are faceless, and the narrative is deliberately enigmatic. This ambiguity sparks conversations and keeps players engaged throughout its three-hour journey.

The puzzles in "INSIDE" aren't mind-bendingly difficult, but that doesn't matter. They strike a balance that keeps players intrigued, eager to uncover the mysteries of the game's world and their character's purpose.

However, it's impossible to ignore the discomforting theme running through Playdead's games. "INSIDE" continues the trend of portraying a young protagonist enduring brutal deaths, which can be unsettling. This discomfort serves to heighten the emotional impact of the game.

"INSIDE" excels at creating a haunting atmosphere. The game raises questions at every turn, immersing players in its eerie world and its enigmatic narrative. The dark and moody visuals, combined with a haunting soundtrack, deliver an atmospheric experience that few games can match.

Despite its simplicity in terms of gameplay mechanics, "INSIDE" is a polished masterpiece. With only two buttons for controls, it relies on visual hints and experimentation to guide players, eschewing tutorials and explanations.

Visually, the game is unsettling yet beautiful, with every animation conveying a poetic quality. From stumbling over obstacles to frantic swimming during chases, each movement feels deliberate and adds to the overall experience.

In summary, "INSIDE" is more than a game; it's an experience. While its puzzles may be straightforward, its story is outlandish and confusing in all the right ways. It's the kind of game that begs discussion, leaving players eager to share their "WTF just happened" moments. "INSIDE" is an unforgettable journey that deserves to be played and talked about.

Excellent storytelling, visual language, and player-mechanic learning relationship. Beautiful game with clearly a lot of care and love put into it. All the hard puzzles are satisfying and (once you complete them) never feel unfair.  I played Limbo as a kid back when it first came out.; this is an upgrade in every way. However, it suffers from the same issue, which is length. Certainly understandable, and I view this game as being closer to a work of art than simply a video game. 

However, it makes me all the more glad I got it on sale, because $20, although modestly priced for such an amazing game, is steep for the length. I don't really see myself playing this game again anytime soon. I believe I replayed Limbo, but there was so much less choice in games back when I was young. I'm sure the game has little secrets to find (I found a couple), but I'm not the "maximal achievement" kind of guy.  It took me less than 4 hours to complete the first play-through. It certainly doesn't outstay its welcome, which, for this kind of game, is possible. But I think another two hours would have been more satisfying.

Inside exists in a realm somewhere between games and film. When Inside presents the player with obstacles it slows down and the feel is very gamey. Whether thatâ€™s because thereâ€™s trail and error involved, and youâ€™re repeatedly dying or because thereâ€™s a puzzle that you must resolve before proceeding. None of this is bad just average. I think Insideâ€™s strength is when it flows like a scene in a film thatâ€™s shot in a single take. The Sam Mendesâ€™ film 1917 came to mind. Not because of the setting but because of this flow. The camera goes on a journey with the main character as he traverses battlefields, countrysides, cities, and more. Thereâ€™s a momentum and energy that this technique evokes that can be found throughout Inside. With video games that energy can be even more tactile as you can really engage with the aforementioned _little things_. Brushing aside cornstalks, sliding down roofs, careening through office complexes shattering windows and upturning all furniture in your pathâ€¦ itâ€™s never felt more engaging.

INSIDE (which will be referred to as 'Inside' from now on) is one of my favorite games.  It would not be an exaggeration to say that it is one of my top 5 games of all time.  I consider this game to be a masterpiece, and a must-play if you like atmospheric or story driven games.  It is one of the few games that I have gotten all of the achievements for.  Also, it is the only game that I have seriously attempted to speed run, because I enjoy replaying it so much.


More:

Inside is fantastic.  It is thrilling and captivating.  From the very beginning, the game grabs your attention and never loosens its grip for even a second.  The audio, the visuals, the character design, the aesthetic... everything is perfect.  Of all the games that I have played in the past 30 years or so, it stands out as something truly special.  You owe it to yourself to play this game.  If you do, make sure that you are alone with no distractions, in a dark room with headphones on.  Fully immerse yourself into this game to get the most out of it.

You take on the role of a young boy who is traversing a strange and mysterious environment.  When you begin the game, you do not know what is going on or why.  There is no dialogue or text-crawl to explain what is happening.  You simply figure everything out as you go.  The player is left to use their imagination and observations to explain the world of Inside.  And what a world it is.

It is gloomy and dark.  The world is threatening and unsettling.  There is a sense of unease during the entire play-through that never lets up.  I was eager to see what was just beyond the screen horizon the entire time that I was playing.  Fully immersed in this world, I believed that I was the young boy in this game through and through.  

Most of the time spent playing is spent solving puzzles and platforming.  The technical design of the game is fantastic.  It is so much fun discovering how to solve the puzzles in the game and progress.  They are very well done, interesting, and not overly difficult.  Truly there is joy in figuring something out that was right in front of you the entire time, and not obscured needlessly to artificially increase the difficulty.  You will have that 'aha!' moment multiple times while playing this game.  The proverbial light bulb in your head will turn on over and over, while you probably smile and eagerly finish the task at hand.

Earlier, I described the world as unsettling.  The music plays a very large role in eliciting this feeling.  There are mostly quiet moments, peppered with ambient noise and sound effects of things happening in the background.  You hear every footstep that you take echo through empty halls and dark forests, as well as machinery clanging and churning within buildings.  When something truly noteworthy happens, the music kicks in, and it is glorious.  It is subtle and expertly composed.

Inside has a minimalist and almost low-poly art style.  For the most part, the game is very dark, and not well lit, so you can't actually see any topology on the meshes.  You won't notice individual faces on character models as they move about, or anything like that.  The boy, and all the other inhabitants of this world appear almost featureless in their faces, and only given enough detail to discern their job, their age, and their gender.  There is a pretty wide view of the entire world while you are playing, so this makes sense visually as well as thematically.  You wouldn't get a very good look at any characters face even if they were highly detailed, because they appear to be far away... and you don't really need to know much about them... and you probably don't want to.

When I think about the time I spent playing this game, I feel like I watched an entire series of a TV show.  There is so much that happens in such a short time on this young boys journey, and so much is learned and revealed.  This is a game that I want more of, but also want to remain exactly what it is.  I would love nothing more than to have more 'Inside' content, but this game was so well done, and my memories of it are so precious that I wouldn't want anything to even come close to changing that.  Inside is as close to perfect as a game can get in my opinion, and I can't imagine any way to make it better outside of making more of it, exactly as it already is.  

I consider this to be one of the greatest games that I have ever played, and I hope that as many people as possible experience it, and hopefully, feel the same way that I felt while playing it.

Originally wrote this review talking about it as a puzzle and escape type game, you're almost always on the run or moving to keep going and never quite sure what'll happen next.. it really keeps you on your toes through most of the game.

I was disappointed with the later parts of the game, everything is turned on its head like for example you were running and afraid but then last areas of the game you're casually murdering people without any real effort. Can't go into details because it is a spoiler, a large one I guess.. but it didn't fit with the game in my opinion and the ambiguous ending could have been achieved without it, from my perspective using the enemies tech and busting out.

After finishing this I went and played Limbo, same developers and similar concept but different goals maybe. There are definitely parallels between both games, this one is noticeably more polished as should be expected as it released after Limbo did, similar to a sequel.

Great job developers, I recommend the game and the experience, the world with everything in it. Many people should try it, I commend what you've done but I don't like your plot device, it feels lazy and if it was just there for a segment or a few I'd let it pass but as it is right now I feel like it overrides a lot of what the MC wanted to do, not how he'd have done it too.

It is worth full price but not in regards to 1 playthrough content. Go for extra, do more, experiment more. Playing it for story or to see what happens next will take under 5 hours, maybe even under 4 so I encourage anybody trying to take your time, there is more to do.

Oh and there is a secret ending I will return to complete, this review will be updated after that.

[h1]Nothing is as it seems.[/h1]
From the makers of LIMBO, INSIDE sees you control a nameless boy in a bid to escape from... something. Having no dialogue, cutscenes, lore or any exposition whatsoever, you are left largely to draw your own conclusions as you progress through the game on the way to your objective.

While not as eerie or haunting as LIMBO (which wins out in that category due to the stark use of black/white and no colours), it has a menace all of its own, especially the dogs. The environment also does not feel quite as lethal as the world of LIMBO, but in reality there are still plenty ways to die. There is still a strong puzzle element here, just a lack of obviously deadly obstacles such as buzzsaws, electricity, etc. Instead, these are replaced by sentient beings, such as dogs and humans - some of which are hostile, and some of which are indifferent.

The game raises philosophical questions about the nature of self, agency, and morality. What does it mean to be human in a society that strips away individuality and autonomy? How far would you go to escape from such a system? What are the ethical implications of manipulating others for your own survival or curiosity? Due to the "clean" nature of the game (very limited information input as mentioned earlier), it seems probable that most players will come to their own, unique conclusions based on their experience playing through the game. Then again, it may also raise the question of whether there is even a point in the first place.

Highly recommended for anyone looking for an adventure, story or something more introspective. Much like LIMBO, this is more than a game and comes closer to art or a thought exercise and deserves to be experienced.

I don't know. To be fair, the only reason I played Inside is because of all the praise and positive reviews. I thought maybe I would try it and understand the appeal. And after finishing it, here is what I can say about the game:
1. It is quite short, which for me is actually good because if it was any longer I would probably just not finish it
2. The gameplay is next to none. I do not understand why it is labelled as a puzzle platformer, in reality this is a 2D walking simulator. All you do is walk (and sometimes swim). The puzzles do not require any mental effort
3. The atmosphere is superb. It is dark, mysterious, and the devs really don't hold back in terms of gore and violence. In fact, this is the best part of the game for me
4. On the other hand, there is no storytelling, it is not explained at all what is the reason for all the stuff that is happening, and you have to speculate. I do not mind it at all personally, but why would the devs call this game "narrative driven"? There is literally zero narration.

So in the end Inside felt more like an animated movie than a game. Some people might like it, I didn't.

There's a fine line between creating a story that offers players the opportunity to speculate on possibilities and a frustrating mystery with no satisfying solution.  A mystery is a promise:  Patient and observant players will be rewarded with story and meaning.  This promise is undermined when the creator forces the player to create the story and meaning themselves.  If you're looking for a few hours of solid puzzles and platforming, great art and an intriguing setting, this will work for you.  If you're looking for your curiosity to be rewarded with a satisfying conclusion, keep looking.

The puzzles are good, neither too sinister nor too trivial, broken up nicely by tight platforming.  The atmosphere is sometimes tense and foreboding, sometimes wild and dangerous.  The art is beautiful, with curious and interesting sights from start to finish.

The game respects players' time.  Failure results in the ability to quickly reset and try again.  The "load" system allows players to go back and search for missed side areas without having to replay the whole game.  There's no unnecessary backtracking, and no scene, setting, or challenge wears out its welcome.

Most every aspect of this game works well, so the way you feel about this game story will boil down to:  Do you want a mystery with a solution?  Or would you prefer to speculate on possibilities?  If you like to look up and/or make fan theories (that can never really be proved one way or the other), this game will give you something to work with.  If the idea of getting to the end and going "that's it?" frustrates you, skip this one.

The Iraq War was a protracted armed conflict in Iraq from 2003 to 2011 that began with the invasion of Iraq by the United States-led coalition that overthrew the Iraqi government of Saddam Hussein. The conflict continued for much of the next decade as an insurgency emerged to oppose the coalition forces and the post-invasion Iraqi government.US troops were officially withdrawn in 2011. The United States became re-involved in 2014 at the head of a new coalition, and the insurgency and many dimensions of the armed conflict are ongoing. The invasion occurred as part of the George W. Bush administration's war on terror following the September 11 attacks.

This game is simply brilliant. The setting, the atmosphere, the feeling it gives you, the puzzles...everything is so organic (literally) and mesmerising. It is not a happy story, but it is a deep and moving one, especially if you can relate to the hero and soak in all the metaphors. It is a difficult journey, but a liberating one. An absolute must have.

The follow-up to Limbo builds on graphic, plot, and atmosphere. The puzzles have this wonderful organic feeling, like real world problem-solving if you were hunted by a totalitarian government doing monstrous experiments on human/animal life. The finale is completely unexpected, and leaves a lot open to interpretation, so it might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I was thoroughly engrossed and enthralled by this perfectly designed game.

I'm torn about this game. It oozes with mood and style. For that alone, I would recommend it. It has incredible visuals (especially the dynamic lighting) and animation. The simplistic shapes and textures/colors give it an artful style, and it offers a very interesting world... 

...but you don't get to explore that world, and there are no answers at the end for anything you've seen and wondered about while playing. It's not a bad ending, per se, it's just... "That's it? We're done now? Why did ANY of that happen?? What was ANY of this for?? Why did anyone do anything they did?? What are the motivations of ANY characters?"

This side-scroller looks incredible due to being executed in a 3D space... but that leads to me wanting to escape the 2D plane the player character is trapped on. I did not feel that in Playdead's prior game because it rarely, if ever, implied any space to move into other than forward and back (with occasional up and down). Bringing depth into a 2D scrolling game concept made the game look beautiful and the simplistic environments believable, but it also teased of places you cannot go. This makes invisible walls worse than ever: the puzzle framing is so much more artificial and obvious, and irritating in several cases. I felt myself asking "why would I go THERE, instead of going anywhere else?" Oh, right, because there's only a 2D plane for this character to move in and all puzzles are carried out (and demanded) via an inevitable left or right movement (and sometimes up & down) on a mostly linear path.

Some of the puzzles, if you can call them that, became repetitious, and that resulted in frustration. There were moments that I just wanted a certain type of action/activity to stop repeating (like the underwater monster pursuits, though that ended satisfactorily, despite only adding more questions and answering nothing... making prior action seemingly senseless, also therefore making it look more like puzzles than narrative). The game was a better experience while the activities required of the player were diverse. Speaking of... change...

The twist near the end was... something. I understand why people are bothered by it, but I would've been fine with the twist had ANYTHING AT ALL been explained by the end. I am NOT a fan of "anything goes because it's sci-fi" type of plotting. It has to make some kind of sense within its own context. In this game, nothing makes any sense at all. There's no suggestion as to the motivation of ANY characters or factions, nor what they even are. There's not even a sense that the ending fits into what's been given so far, other than "outside is better/safer", which was already explicitly made clearly NOT the case at the very beginning of the game. So, maybe it's "outside... over THERE is better, because... reasons..."

I am not a fan of "it's so open ended by the end that you can come up with whatever meaning or story you want". That's not a plot or a story; it's meaningless performance art. I'm not here to create someone else's world for them. Tell me a story inside a world that you've already decided on. I hate doing other people's work for them and watching people excuse it with "it's open to interpretation". Yeah, a blank sheet of paper is also open to interpretation. Ultimately, we are given apocalypse/"dangers of science" tropes as magnetic poetry to throw at a wall. There's a little of this, a little of that... none of it forms a coherent world or plot, "but it looks cool!"

A story doesn't need to be easy/simple, or spoon-fed to me, but it DOES have to be EXTANT. I can always tell when writers have no idea what they've created. Throwing random weird and suggestive content at the audience works up until it stops being possible to make sense of it as a coherent work, and then you realize you're just being fed random stuff because someone thought "hey, cool mystery". You really do have to figure it out as a writer, even if you don't spell it out to the audience. "MYSTERIOUS!!" is not more important than "it makes some kind of sense, and is internally consistent".

I don't regret the experience of playing this game, but I don't feel strongly motivated to replay it in order to find several secrets I missed, or try to get the "alternate ending" everyone keeps talking about. Some of the game was too tedious to replay for what's likely to be more "no answers mystery", and likely just create more questions.

If none of this story/plot criticism matters to you in your entertainment experience, then I guess you'll be fine with what this game presents.

As for difficulty: It's sometimes frustrating, but I got through it fairly rapidly, and I'm not a hard-core gamer, nor a puzzle person. That said, it's not so easy as to be able to dash through it without any effort or thought. It's actually a pretty good balance, and, for me, as challenging as I can tolerate a game to be when playing it as one solid block of 7 hours.

In several ways (visual style and structure), this game reminded me of "Out of This World", but I felt zero connection to any characters here. There's barely a character to speak of, other than "the boy". The end of OOTW was emotional and it has stuck with me for decades. The end of "Inside" is... well, as I said above: it just ends, and I sat here asking "Is that it? Really??" The only thing that will stick with me here is the rendering tech... and the blob.

INSIDE is a fantastic example of how taking an idea and perfecting it can become something great, regardless of how simple it might be. No music, no speech, not even one word, there isn't even a main menu, and yet the game played flawlessly. Fluid, responsive movement. Big, interesting, albeit simple puzzles. Story, for what it has, was cleverly delivered. It's a great  game in this genre.

Pros
- The gameplay. Simple and intuitive
- The ambiance. We feel the oppression, and that the boy is scared (with reason).
- The variety of the puzzles.
- The thriller. This game is the proof we don't need gore and violence to be afraid and tensed.
- The variation between tension and calm.
- The possibility to do the chapters again.
- No dialogue. And yet, the developpers managed to tell a beautiful story.
- No downloads or breaks. It's linear... litteraly.
- This game doesn not have a rich colour palette. Do not expect a side-scrolling game as colourful as mario. It's not. Some even consider the art style as monochromous. But it's actually a strength of this game, as it contributes significantly to the feeling of oppresion and dystopy.

Limits
- ?

Depends of your tastes
- There is a plotwist at the end. Some people thought it was genious. Because of the reviews and comments, my expectations were high. But once I got there, I told myself it was overrated. The plotwist changes indeed the tone, but it becomes absurb and does not fit with the rest of the game (in my opinion). However the plotwist was satisfaying and made sense with the story!
- Open ending.
- Short game. Less than 6 hours.
- No hints. 
- Some puzzles are hard. Be prepared to be stuck and to tell yourself often ''why did not I think about that earlier?''. And to do some trials-errors. And to fail. And to die often. But it's easier than Limbo.

Oh. My. God. Where do I start...

INSIDE is a great and coherent game with lots of well-designed puzzles and, let's call them, "action segments."

The difficulty is just right for this type of game. Sometimes it can be challenging and make you pause for a moment, but usually, the solutions are easy (and fun!) to find.

The movement of the main character is well-executed and really comfortable.

The world-building deserves separate praise. It has everything you need to fully immerse yourself in the game. Amazing ambiance? Yes. Almost seamless transitions between locations? You got it! Things happening in the background? Absolutely!

Honestly, I don't know if I can say anything negative about it.
In conclusion - GO AND PLAY IT RIGHT NOW!

Wow. Really, really good. A massive improvement from their first game, Limbo. Stunning visual art, ambient soundtrack and a bleak dystopian storyline. Finished with a superbly melancholy ending. 
Puzzles are noticeably easier than in Limbo - this is a good choice for the type of game this is.  It is story driven and visually gorgeous more than anything else. The puzzles are still clever and use physics in an interesting way. Only this time, unlike in Limbo, you won't be wasting too much time figuring them out.
This is the type of game you won't forget playing. Memorable stuff. Can't wait for Playdead's next game!

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The gameplay is perfect for what someone may expect from a game of the genre, a 2d platform sidescroller seems quite an accurate description for this piece. I had quite a lot of fun trying to figure out the solutions to the problems and obstacles found along the way. It is not a frenetic experiencie, it is not a guns blazin' experience, it is a puzzle game with some platorming and sidcrolling within it. [u]If you are looking for an assasins creed or a call of duty, this may not be your game.[/u]

[h1]Controls:[/h1]
This game has the simplest control configuration I have had the pleasure to deal with in a very long time. Only 6 buttons are required to play this game, up down left right and 'A' for grabbing or interacting and 'B' for jumping, almost reminds of the old NES and Gameboy games. This sentence alone should let readers know about the implicit simplicity of the mechanics you shall encounter in this game. Although do not be missguided into thinking that the game is boring.

[h1]Atmosphere:[/h1]
This is one of the strong points of the game, the atmosphere is well developed and established although probably not the main focus of the game as it would be in a horror title. It sets the mood rather well for the environment it all happens in and is a piece of added flavour to the game.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
This game is for the kind of player that likes to observe, theorize and reflect upon what is seen, constantly, because nothing will ever be said nor directly implied. The lore of the game seems to be a big question mark and that may be a very good choice for this game, although I like to have my anwsers figured out, this game does a marvelous job in delivering a story masked as 'almost nothing really'. It does that in a way that creates questions, constantly, that drives the player forward for answers that only bring more questions.

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]
The graphics are one of the positives aspects of the game. Although in many parts of the game the graphics and scene become extremely dark and you may want to increase your brightness against that. I loved the artistic style, it is very nicely executed, but it is quite a saddening thing that it was not more extensively explored within vivid colours. One may argue that for the sake of the atmosphere there could not be many vibrant tones, but being almost monocromatic, at times, may risk being repetitive, Nontheless, I truly enjoyed the graphics, the 'flaw' I mentioned, seemes to have had a purpose.

[h1]replayability[/h1]
Close to zero to be completely honest.
I only mention this because of the alternate ending. To find it, it had me go through the game again, and look for the pieces of the game that i had missed the first run. Otherwise there is no replayability whatsoever,
unless you want to figure out the story for yourself and theorize about what happened within the game universe. Also, good F***ing luck finding those collectibles you need for the alternate ending, there is one specific piece that had me sweat for a big while, then jump to google due to my frustration. Also, there is one specific puzzle, always within the replayability context, that i would have never figured out on my own, my low IQ may be showing here, but a little hint may be good for players. Feels like they expected people to google stuff out [spoiler] Me being salty [/spoiler].

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
I truly enjoyed the game. Bought it for 2â‚¬ and got 30 hours worth of fun. Passing around the controller when getting stuck was a nice experience with my wife. The type of gameplay, rather relaxing and head-scratch inducing, sometimes, turned up the speed and had you go in some sort of more action-like gameplay moments at others. Alltogether, the story, the atmosphere, the gameplay, simpliciy and pace resulted in a well developet product that deserves praise. Super-recommended!

The game's message, in my opinion, is that you cannot defeat the system, no matter what you do or how hard you try. When you actually escape, you die and realize that they led you there; even your false escape was part of their plan (see the miniature forest you are falling into in the lab, foreshadowing the ending). Even when you turn into that creature that annihilates everything that appears to be beyond their control, in reality you are part of their plan.

In other words, you're always INSIDE some larger system or structure, no matter how free you think you are.
This game was ao frigging weird but lots of fun. Beautiful artsy game with good puzzles and a story with no words that keeps you guessing.

[h1]Inside is a puzzle creepy-style game, similar to Little Nightmares.[/h1]

It starts in a relative normal enviroment with pretty basic and straight-forward mechanics, but as the game progresses, more mechanics and you really can percieve how deep the game is, how [b]dark[/b] the ambience is, how good the mechanics are and how great the gameplay gets.
You'll remain amazed by the escalation of this game, it is definitely worth it, especially if it's on sale, the longetivity is great, around 3 hours if you're pretty quick.

The only critic I'd find is that some parts are pretty repetitive and you'll have to repeat the same scene for two or more times, but other than that, everything else is just awesome, especially the [b]ambience[/b] in my opinion.
Short to beat, very ominous, left lots to think about
Great Game! Recommend especially when it's on sale :)

Weirdly Beautiful! Inside is one of the most beautiful and subtly detailed 2D platformer games i've ever played. Every frame of the game is meticulously crafted and feels cinematic to look at.

| SPOILER
| At its core, Inside is a story about a boy who breaks into a facility where Scientists Experiment on What they 
| call "The Huddle". The story progresses as the boy goes through the facility to find out whats going in there, | | and eventually end up rescuing the Huddle in the End. The deep meanings are left to you to interpret.

The Environment, The Lighting and The Atmosphere all sets you up for a gripping experience right from the start. The encounters in the game are so good that you always escape them at the last moment. Yes you obviously die sometimes, just to understand how the mechanics work. 

Might play again, for the Alternate Ending!

This was a phenomenal experience. Dark, unsettling, grotesque, tense. This game wants to make you feel a lot of different things. The graphics are beautiful and go a long ways for setting the tone of the game, especially when paired with great sound design and minimalist OST. Gameplay is simple in concept, but changes enough to keep things interesting and to keep you from rushing through it too quickly. However, above all this game wins on the merits of its mood, and it doesn't get so bogged down with tedious gameplay that the mood is ruined. 

I honestly don't have much negative to say about this game. It's roughly the appropriate length for a game like this, though I've yet to compare it to this dev's other titles. And it checks out on about every other metric I'd measure its success on.

Tl;dr - If you want a good puzzle-platformer with a disturbing narrative and polished presentation, this is an excellent choice for you.

BEWARE OF THE MISLEADING REVIEWS HERE! If you hate getting burned by tons of gushing reviews, then you MUST read this.

I liked the atmosphere, the well-suited graphics, and it had some pretty cool ideas in this game which I must give this an upvote, but that is where it ends. Below are the common things you see in reviews that are misinformation and you need to ignore:



>>> Atmosphere is oppressive

No it's not. It is dark and ambient, but I never felt oppressed. If you want to feel oppressed, go play Amnesia, Outlast, etc.



>>> The less you know before, the better

No for the vast majority of gamers. If you are in the small subset of people who particularly enjoy playing games that explain nothing and spending a lot of your own free time trying to derive meaning from something, then this probably will appeal to you. Such people are in a small minority in my experience, so the odds are pretty high that going in knowing some spoilers would arguably help make sense of things you won't understand anyways.



>>> You will feel yourself inside the game

No.



>>> This is a puzzle game
>>> Challenging puzzles
>>> ...

No damn way.

If you consider puzzles something that takes you anywhere between 0 - 15 seconds at most of thinking, yeah. If you are someone who has played what would be unanimously called a puzzle game (such as The Talos Principle, among many) then you will be STRONGLY disappointed if you are expecting any kind of puzzles. If anyone thinks this is a puzzle game, then they've blurred the word so much that it means nothing and you should ignore them.

If this is your first puzzle game ever, and you stopped thinking after grade 3, sure, it may feel like a puzzle game to you. 



>>> This is ... the most intense gaming experiences I've ever had

I don't know how. If this person isn't flat out lying, then if you made them play Amnesia: The Dark Descent then I assume they would go into cardiac arrest. This game is a walk through the park with effectively zero intensity.

The enemies are predictable and easy to thwart. Where exactly is this intensity...? I am pretty sure the developers chose to make this game not be intense.



>>> The cinematography is stunning -- literally every frame is a painting

These kinds of people who have such low standards that they are immediately impressed by anything that has shadows and reflections. Pay them no heed. I would further posit these people play a lot of indie games where the graphics are "indie quality" (as expected!) so anything that has reflections in water is the second coming of Christ.

The graphics are nice and smooth and better than your average indie game, but calling everything a painting is way too far, the graphics aren't THAT good. Just because this game nails a dark ambient vibe really well and made solid smooth graphics doesn't mean it's a visual masterpiece.



>>> Playing at night in darkness with headphones extremely recommended

No it will barely do anything. This is not a horror game. This game is not scary at all to warrant being in the dark. At best it would augment the atmosphere, but nothing more. The sounds are decent and would benefit from using headphones, but there were only a handful of sounds that I thought were worth headphones. Certain lifts had great sounds that capitalized on headphones, but a lot of sounds did not.



>>> A lonely and terrifying journey that will disturb you to the core

Lonely? Maybe. Terrifying? No. Disturbing? Maybe if you're the kind of person who freaks out over novels like 1984 and have never played a dark ambient game like this before.



>>> It's hard for movies, much less video games to say so much without having any dialogue. If done wrong, the whole thing is a mess. If done right, you have a masterpiece. That's what this game is: a masterpiece.

I am unconvinced, and this game does that but it is not a masterpiece.



>>> This is a game that when you complete it, you truly feel like you've accomplished something, not just beaten it.

No it does not.



>>> Loved the problem solving and soundtrack.

There was no problem solving (as seen earlier)... and... soundtrack!? Was my game busted? There was no soundtrack... unless you consider ambient sounds in the background a soundtrack, but I would disagree with that definition.

We're we playing the same game!?



>>> It tells a story with a deceptive amount of depth

Due to the purposeful ambiguity by the developers, I disagree with saying this game has "depth." You can say this about anything and get away with it because art is subjective. I don't think there is much here and it's left up to interpretation, which means if you imagine there to be depth due to a good imagination, it will have it. However you can say that about anything, and therefore I don't find this claim to be useful.



If you read through all of this, the key takeaway is that is a decent looking game with decent physics and a well done dark ambient atmosphere. If you aren't 12 years old, this will be a decent game that you can complete in about 2 hours or so, or if you're like me you wander off trying odd things and maybe add on an extra half hour. I think the developers achieved their vision, and I think they did it well, so I give this a thumbs up.

However, the reviews here are ridiculous and misleading. The reviews are proof that one needs extreme skepticism whenever something has "Overwhelmingly Positive" on Steam. Plus if you check out the profiles of some of these people, they've got tons of anime spam on their profile and have a full work's week of gaming, which tells you everything you need to know, and maybe I should have led with this because you'd understand the clientele just from this alone.

I've seen worse misleading reviews on other games, but they're pretty bad here.

This game is nothing short of a masterpiece. As with its predecessor Limbo by the same studio it contains ingenious puzzles, traps, and dangerous encounters against the backdrop of an even more beautiful scenery than Limbo. While I love Limbo in all its aspects, this game has an added depth that Limbo's missing. The atmosphere and ambience, the minimalist and suggestive brutalistic architectural world the player moves around in is sublime, the art direction is quite awesome and perfect, making this one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen and played. Many times I just walked back and forth just to admire the world around me. It's the weirdest thing too; as I progressed in the game I felt that although the world is quite the scary place to walk around in I at the same time felt a longing to go there, like I had some kind of connection to it. It felt very northen and seeing as I'm a swede I found many things eerily familiar, and the reason for this as it turned out in the end when the credits rolled I found that the studio behind the game, Playdead, is danish. No wonder I seemed to feel at home in certain aspects when playing this game; they've perfectly incorporated the visual sense of the northen scenery and then added their magic to it. They really managed to bring about the atmospheric melancholy of the northen people and I absolutely loved everything about it. The world is indeed cold and oppressively scary but it is really beautiful. Many times I just sat and looked at the visuals in complete fascination. My hat off to the studio for making this gem of a masterpiece. Please continue creating awesome games.

If you play games for the gameplay this isn't for you. If you play games for the story this isn't for you. 

However, if you like atmosphere that envelopes you completely then play this game. I have never played something that is this potent when it comes to atmosphere. 
The drab colors, the stunning yet bland visuals and the excellent sound design come together to create this absolutely oppressive vibe that continues throughout the game. 

This game doesn't really have a story, it runs on themes and vibe alone. Things definitely happen in the game but the bulk of this game doesn't exist in the literal. This is more a sort of interactive art piece than game that shows that maybe there doesn't need to be a distinction between those two categories.

Enjoyed this game a lot. Love the graphics / aesthetics of the game. Also found it amazing how the music and the sound effects blend in a way that seems that everything is a single piece, continuous and homogeneous. Overall the game is easy and fluid, it took me on an unique journey every night I played. I salute the artists behind the concept and development.

Honestly a great game. It's worth the $2 it costs, though it is very short sitting at 3 hours for me to complete. The story seems very intriguing and mysterious, but it also feels really incomplete. I didn't really understand what was happening most of the time, and especially at the end I was quite clueless. I didn't really like how it ended because it didn't feel like like it answered the questions I had about what was happening. It was really cool though. It had a lot of cool mechanics and twists.

I'm probably missing the allegorical nature of this game, but I don't think it's that great. The graphics and sound design are fairly polished, but you'll never be told any controls (so you might be stuck figuring out how to move a refrigerator like I was within five minutes of starting the game) and the mechanics of the game are usually not properly displayed. The experience became more mundane and confusing than emotional and captivating for me. Moreover, I was thoroughly removed from the experience because of how many times I died, and that issue could've been avoided had I properly been shown the capabilities of my character.

I played Inside first and then Limbo. I feel that the difficulty level of Limbo is much harder than Inside. The story of Limbo and Inside have similarities and differences. In both games, we play a silent and nameless protagonist who we do not know much about even after we have completed the games. Both games use environmental storytelling to allow the player to experience the game and the story that they intend to convey without the use of any spoken language. Both games provoke more questions than answers. In both games, we start off in the forest. In Inside, we get chased by both dogs and human beings who want to capture the player character. We are left wondering why did other humans want to capture the player character. Who are we playing as and what are we doing in the game? Where are we? As the game progresses, we observe strange happenings in the game world as we can see mind controlled animals such as pigs and other human beings which our player character can mind control using a cap that he wears on his head. [spoiler] Later, after a strange incident where our player character is drowned by a mermaid creature, our player character gains the ability to breathe underwater permanently and also can mind control other human beings effortlessly without the use of a mind control cap. [/spoiler] Why is our player character able to mind control other creatures and human beings? What does this mind control ability symbolize? What are those other human beings who move like zombies in the game world and who do they symbolize or represent? I feel that Inside is less disturbing than Limbo though because there is more "humanity" in the other humanoid creatures found in the game world. In Limbo most of the other human like creatures want to kill the player character except for one - the female character whom the player character gets to meet at the end of the game. In Inside, the player character can get many other humanoids to help him progress the game by mind controlling them. In Limbo, the player character is very much on his own, which exacerbates the feeling of loneliness when we, the player controls him to overcome the puzzles and challenges in the game world. In Inside, we can feel that our player character gets more powerful as the game progresses due to the abilities he gains while playing the game but in Limbo, the player character practically remains very much the same throughout the game, which gives us the perception that Limbo is a much more difficult game than Inside. Both games also have an open-ended ending which leaves the players wondering what happened at the end of the game. In fact, there is no closure.

This will be my first review on Steam just to show how much I appreciate this game. I didn't think I would ever get introduced to a game more up my alley that this. It has every personally engaging aspect that you wouldn't see me stop fawning over in other video games or shows. The constant simplistic, yet ominous view of what's on screen, the phenomenal sound design that really did not have to be this good and the ambiguity of the story are what easily makes this game for me a 10/10. Unlike other games like Little Nightmares, the controls never felt overbearing and the puzzles weren't hard enough for things to get frustrating, nor were they simple to the point that completing them wouldn't feel satisfying. As of right now, I'm writing this review at almost 6 in the morning but I wanted to get my complete thoughts out while they're still fresh in my head. Especially while the summer sale is going on, I highly recommend getting this game when you can. Cheers.

INSIDE is a truly remarkable game that I highly recommend to anyone who appreciates intricate level design, challenging puzzles, and a dark and unsettling atmosphere. The game follows a boy who finds himself drawn into the center of a dark project, and the narrative-driven platformer combines intense action with thought-provoking puzzles.

One of the standout features of INSIDE is its incredible sound design. As someone who works in game audio, I was blown away by the attention to detail and the way that sound was used to create an immersive and unsettling atmosphere. The use of ambient sounds and carefully crafted sound effects added to the overall mood of the game and helped to create a truly unforgettable experience.

The level design is also expertly crafted, with each level offering a new challenge and a unique aesthetic. The puzzles are thought-provoking and require a combination of logic and strategy to solve. The game's art style is moody and evocative, with a dark and unsettling atmosphere that permeates every aspect of the game.

Overall, INSIDE is a masterpiece of a game that is both challenging and emotionally impactful. The combination of intense action, challenging puzzles, and a dark and unsettling atmosphere make it a must-play for anyone who loves platformers or narrative-driven games. I cannot recommend this game highly enough, and I encourage everyone to experience it for themselves.

INSIDE is a title with a very dark and somber atmospheric feel - CONTROL-like even. It takes place in an enormous secret government facility of unknown purpose that almost seems to consume you as you progress. The game has an overall unsettling theme throughout and uses dramatic lighting and audio to fantastic effect. And it only gets better and more imaginative as you progress further into the story.

INSIDE starts a little on the slow side, but quickly gains traction. The game has a simple, pleasant art-style with a very high level of attention to detail especially where it comes to environmental interactions. The animations are supremely smooth and thought-out overall.

It's a little on the short side overall, and not very challenging. But it is quite a trip and a worthwhile playthrough.

Inside is a fairly well put together puzzle game with a phenomenal art style and an interesting premise. 

The Good: 
- Core Design: The puzzles are excellent. With a decent, diegetic tutorial of the mechanics you're expected to use and the removal of objects that should follow patterns, but do not, the puzzles themselves are practically flawless.
- Difficulty: Difficulty in games comes from them being 1 or a combination of 3 things: challenging, punishing, and bad. Inside is not hugely challenging, and not punishing at all. It's more or less about the difficulty a game like this should be. 

The Bad:
- Tutorialisation: Inside lacks tutorials, which is mostly not a real problem because there aren't too many mechanics but does get frustrating. The designers need to learn the difference between "not holding the player's hand" and "not telling the player what the world is capable of or what is expected of them". There is no tutorial, there is mostly no demonstration of mechanics (you're just expected to already know what they are and how to use them). It's the difference between tough-love and parental neglect. You are put into puzzles that I'm sure the solutions of are obvious to the designers, but are obtuse and arbitrary to a player. 
- Gameplay: The movement is not good. No, it's not an action combat game or a tight platformer where the ability to control the minute movements of your character is essential to being any good at the game, but the kid is awful to control. He's simultaneously floaty and heavy, it's like controlling a balloon filled half-and-half with water and air. Most of this problem could be fixed by just making him stop more quickly, but maybe that's a stylistic decision, maybe they really wanted to make you so irritated with this child that you aren't even disappointed when he gets eaten by dogs, who knows? But there is also several sections where you could really stand to benefit from being able to control him more precisely: there's some sections where the timing is quite tight, and making a small mistake risks an immediate death, but he doesn't control well enough to so you WILL die until you can do it perfectly, which just takes you out of the game's world and frustrates you (I'm talking about that last mermaid section).

The Rest:
I don't really think there's a 'story', per se, because there is never any explanation as to why the things that are happening are happening, nor much environmental storytelling to explain what's going on, why, or how. Absolutely nothing about the scenario is explained, and that's a weakness for someone like me because I quite like games with a plot, and it's a great shame because the plot could have been fantastic if they'd put as much effort into it as they put into the jiggle physics of the blob at the end of the game.

Conclusion:
Yeah, it's pretty good. Worth a play, but don't expect it to play very well.

INSIDE is a very strong showing for the 2D puzzle genre. The game has a great art style and makes great use of depth in what can sometimes be a visually boring category of games. These two things along with good sound design lead to a very atmospheric game. INSIDE also has fantastic puzzles, they are intuitive, original and clever. This is not a very challenging game, the puzzles will not delay you but will still leave you satisfied with solving it, this means the pacing of the story (or what you can make of the story) stays fast. It is not a very long game however and has little replayability but overall, anyone can enjoy their time with this game.

INSIDE is one of those games where you mostly move right. On rare occasions when you can move left, it means you have discovered some secret (orbs that you can collect). The game is quite short, but there is a replay value in searching for all the secrets. Getting all the achievements is reasonably easy to do.

While most of the puzzles are easy to solve because they are quite intuitive, some more difficult ones made me look up a walkthrough video. Most of the difficult ones are either "I can't believe I didn't figure that out myself" or "I didn't know I can do that". The most annoying part was the one where you need to have perfect timing to not get shot by some cannon.

The best part of this game is the ambiance - the sound and lighting of the environment. Even though the narrative is minimalistic, it probably has one of the most memorable endings of any video game.
