I'll be real... I didn't enjoy this game. 

You know what I did enjoy, back in 2010? A little indie game called Limbo. It was a simplistic, shorter game in which you played a scared little child running left to right in foreboding, shadow-silhouetted environments. It had a control scheme that only used a few buttons,  a minimalist soundtrack, and a pretty much non-existent story sprinkled with hints of pretentiousness.  You spent the first thirty or so minutes fleeing a giant demon-spider, followed by two hours of traipsing through dull, boring, insipid, ruined warehouses and factories. Honestly, if you stopped after the demon-spider died, you did yourself a favor. Oh, and every death animation was brutal and cruel. Said animations shocked you the first couple of times, but then lost all meaning as desensitization kicked in. 

Limbo pretty much kicked off the "scared child in spooky nightmare land" indie genre. A seemingly endless litany of similar indie games followed in its wake, each slightly more tedious than the last. Almost none reached the lofty heights that Limbo did with its freaky-deaky giant demon-spider. 

So what did Limbo's developers do to follow up their success? This game, which would have been more aptly titled Limbo 1.5. You're still a little kid, running left to right in a big, bad world. Only, there's no demon spider hunting you through a big pine forest for thirty minutes. Instead, you run from some blokes and their dogs as they chase you across a small patch of forest and some corn fields. Then, the obligatory two plus hours of run-down, dimly lit, gray-colored warehouses, factories, and research facilities kick in. It's dull. Exceedingly dull, and the muted sounds and minimalist soundtrack DO NOT HELP MATTERS. On the plus side, the last ten minutes of the game veer wildly into a psychotic, non-sequitur blob sequence that makes no sense whatsoever, but feels like a generous reprieve from the afore-mentioned tedium. 

It just did not work for me. The deaths lost all impact ten minutes in. The level variety left a lot to be desired. The story was non-existent and abysmally shallow (though that hasn't stopped hardcore fans from filling in the massive blanks with their empty conjectures and pseudo-theories). I was checking my timer 20 minutes in and praying that the game would end soon. Never crashed, ran fine, and seemed polished. Just not my cup of tea. This genre is clearly not for me. 

But... if you're a fan of this genre, here's another one of them. It's made by the people who put this genre on the map, so you're going to get what you're looking for. If you're not a fan, I might recommend Limbo instead. Same developers, same ambiance, similar control scheme, and same general polish. It sells for a fairly low price nowadays and the first thirty minutes with the giant demon-spider are wonderful. Tense, freaky, and off-putting. Again, just make sure to stop immediately after you have bested the eight legged terror.  You'll have seen the best this genre has to offer and can move on.

Title: INSIDE: A Hauntingly Atmospheric and Thought-Provoking Journey

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… (5/5)

INSIDE, the enigmatic puzzle-platformer developed by Playdead, is a masterclass in atmospheric storytelling and immersive gameplay. With its haunting visuals, atmospheric sound design, and thought-provoking narrative, INSIDE delivers a captivating and unforgettable experience that pushes the boundaries of the genre.

One of the most striking aspects of INSIDE is its visual design. The game's dark and atmospheric environments, rendered in minimalist yet highly detailed graphics, create a sense of unease and mystery. The use of light and shadow, combined with subtle animations and seamless transitions, adds depth and immersion to every scene. The visuals work in perfect harmony with the game's narrative, unraveling its dark secrets and unveiling a dystopian world filled with sinister undertones.

The sound design in INSIDE is equally remarkable. The haunting ambient sounds, eerie melodies, and atmospheric effects contribute to the game's oppressive atmosphere, heightening the sense of tension and unease. The lack of traditional dialogue or exposition allows the player to immerse themselves fully in the experience, interpreting the story through visual and auditory cues, deepening the sense of mystery and intrigue.

The gameplay mechanics of INSIDE are simple yet ingeniously designed. As the protagonist, players navigate through a series of challenging puzzles and platforming sequences, utilizing the environment and manipulating objects to progress. The puzzles gradually increase in complexity, requiring keen observation and experimentation to overcome. The fluid controls and intuitive mechanics make for a smooth and satisfying gameplay experience, ensuring that the focus remains on the exploration and the unraveling of the narrative.

The narrative of INSIDE is a masterpiece in subtlety and ambiguity. It slowly unveils a thought-provoking and metaphorical tale, inviting players to interpret its meaning and symbolism. The game's deliberate pacing and meticulously crafted set pieces create an unsettling and mesmerizing narrative arc that leaves a lasting impact. The lack of explicit exposition allows for personal interpretation, making each playthrough a unique and introspective experience.

INSIDE's concise but profound storytelling is complemented by its impeccable pacing. The game masterfully balances moments of tension and quiet introspection, providing a captivating rhythm that keeps players engaged from start to finish. The gradual reveal of the world's secrets and the protagonist's journey through various environments create a sense of wonder and curiosity, propelling the player forward.

While INSIDE's brevity may be seen as a drawback by some, the game's concise length is a testament to its focus and artistic integrity. It is a tightly woven experience, leaving a lasting impact in its relatively short playtime.

In conclusion, INSIDE is an atmospheric and thought-provoking masterpiece. With its haunting visuals, immersive sound design, and enigmatic narrative, the game invites players on a deeply introspective and emotionally charged journey. It's a testament to the power of minimalist storytelling and atmospheric gameplay. INSIDE is an experience that lingers long after the credits roll, leaving players contemplating its profound themes and imagery. For those seeking a unique and evocative gaming experience, INSIDE is an absolute must-play.

Completed it in one day (4.4 hours), short game but I believe it is for the good. The game has the perfect length for the playstyle it has, more than this might leave the player exhausted and uninterested by the end. This is not to say that the game is boring, only slow paced (which is not a bad thing). It is only what it tried to be: a simple controlled game with tricky puzzles, nice and soothing visuals, a satisfyingly eerie aesthetic and an attempt to tell a nice story.

Always been fond of these kind of games since I played "Another World" so many years ago. This game is really captivating. It has good puzzles, without being too complex if you're used to the genre; it has some good thrill scenes you need to escape. 
The gloomy cartoonish choice for the game is top notch for the atmosphere, and all the animations are gorgeous and very well done. 
At some point the game can seem a bit repetitive or uninteresting because you have to run quite a lot non stop to the right without so much challenge, but that quickly changes and you'll quickly be captivated by that strange world you seem to want to escape.
The game is not too long, I completed it under 6 hours, but it's in my opinion really good value for money.
Highly recommended.

This game is dripping with atmosphere, every fifteen minutes had some fresh horror making me ask â€œWhat in Satanâ€™s unholy butthole is that?â€. Unfortunately, thatâ€™s about all this game has. The puzzles are simple and for a â€˜platformerâ€™ it doesnâ€™t have a whole lot of platforms. The world is like a subway tunnel, too cramped to explore in any direction but one, and the â€˜storyâ€™ is just a collection of creepy vibes linked by nothing but blank spaces that the player can choose to fill with whatever they want. Still, for most of its ~3hr run time it had me at the edge of my seat eagerly awaiting the next unholy crime against nature that was going to try and kill me.

Is atmosphere enough to make a game? I think that depends on the player, I enjoyed it, but if youâ€™re looking for something with a little more substance to it, a narrative or a challenge, then this is probably not the game for you. If you enjoy watching weird, high-art horror films but wish you could be about ~15% more involved with them, then this is probably the game for you.

A Masterclass in Ambiguity: Inside

Inside, developed by Playdead and released on Steam, is an unequivocal triumph in the world of video games. A spiritual successor to the acclaimed Limbo, Inside continues the tradition of crafting a haunting, atmospheric puzzle platformer that leaves an indelible mark on the player.

The beauty of Inside lies in its seamless blending of the visual and auditory aspects to craft a narrative without uttering a single word. The stark, oppressive world is rendered in a way that the minimalist art style paradoxically teems with detail and story. The muted color palette and meticulously crafted visuals convey a depth of emotion that few games manage to capture.

The atmospheric sound design deserves equal praise, reinforcing the narrative elements with the ebb and flow of ambient sounds that pull players deeper into the game's universe. The music is not just a complement to the visuals, but an equal partner in storytelling.


The game's greatest strength, however, lies in its ambiguous narrative. It refuses to spoon-feed the player, instead opting for a cryptic story that inspires discussions and theories. It's a brave choice that enhances the game's lasting appeal and reinforces the unsettling, dystopian world the game depicts.

Excited to see Playdead's next game and take all the time you need to develop the next game!

a general note about interpreting reviews: games on steam which offer demos will have boosted ratings for two reasons. 1) only steam users who own a game can review it. 2) if a demo is offered for the game then there is a higher proportion of people buying the game who *already know* they like it, as well as a higher proportion of people who don't like the game that the demo filters *out* from buying the game (and therefore filters out from the review process). this shouldn't bother you since you can simply ignore the reviews and play the demo for yourself, but it's worth pointing out.

This is excellent, I loved it!
A short, dark, mysterious, side scrolling puzzle platformer, with a really good story line, amazing art style and sound effects. It's storyline is horror/sci-fi/thriller/suspense .

There's no dialogue, back story or any lead in to the game, it just starts and your alone stumbling down a dark forest. You run, and you keep running, not knowing who or what you are running from, who you are or why you are running. You just know you can't let anyone catch and kill you!

You hide out of sight briefly when you can't run and there are a few cases where timing is important to avoid enemies, and the use of moving objects is required to solve small puzzles and navigate around enemies or progress further in the story. The game always keeps moving and can be completed in 3 and half hours.

Although you don't know anything about the story, the intrigue is there and mystery of what has happened in this world - dead pigs, a derelict world, civilians marching as if controlled, and you, just a boy running - is this a war, a plague, a famine, some sort of invasion? 

You'll speculate what it all means, who you are and where you are running to, what's going to happen next, and right up until the end couldn't wait to see how the story was going to unfold.
Played it through in one sitting. It was that good!

I could even see this being a comic book or cartoon, the style and story was amazing that it didn't even bother me that there was no dialogue from the characters.

Would play it again, and again.

10/10

For the price, definitely an enjoyable Sunday afternoon 5 hours.

A pretty great li'l puzzle platformer that stands out with its presentation and creativity, and is otherwised saved from being a tad cliche it's MADNESS-riddled ending.

GOOD STUFF:
+ Art style and graphics are great to look at and really convey a mood. Could maybe have used a TOUCH more color.
+ Most puzzles are tough enough to be satisfying, but even a tard like me didn't need a walkthrough. They all make sense and while they're very unique and diverse, they will probably be approachable if you apply logic from other video games.
+ There's a real relishable weight to the movement and momentum. The player character has so many subtle little twitches and animations to interact with what's currently going on, and he usually feels good to control. The way your lobotomized followers bumble and crash around is fun to watch.
+ Gameplay keeps changing itself to give you fresh new interactions. There's a submarine section that was particularly fun.
+ Soundwork is great. Very minimal score, which suits the game. Foley work is very creepy, visceral, and great.
+ The death/failure animations don't hold back. When the protagonist dies, he gets f*cking killed.
+ A reasonably interesting story is told purely through the environment. I could have used maybe 20% less vagueness about some parts though.
+ There seemed to be sort of a hackneyed dystopia element to the narrative at first especially being a vulnerable little boy in red running away from the industrialized, scary world... but that's revealed not to entirely be the case, and the final 1/4 of the game comes out of absolute nowhere and I feel cements this game's high reputation. It's not just a narrative reveal, it affects the rest of the gameplay too.

BAD STUFF:
- I really don't like to rate games by "dollars per hour," but $20 is just way too much. It's one linear campaign that took me 3 hours, and nothing else besides some achievements. I think I got this for like $6 or something. Wait for a sale.
- A couple puzzles were pretty oblique in their methodology, wherein a couple I got lucky from guesses and a couple more I tried the correct solution 2 or 3 times before it actually went through. 
- The complex physics and momentum don't always follow your inputs as well as they should. I screwed up the puzzles and died a handful of times because of this. This can be extra finicky in the otherwise great ending segment.

I loved playing this game by Playdead, this beautifully crafted masterpiece is a tense, thought provoking ride from start to finish. From being chased by rabid dogs, to mysterious evil people to the charming puzzles, this is something I feel everyone should experience. 

The art style is highly affective, the use of lighting and colour are some of the gameâ€™s strongest points, helping build up this Inside world. A dark grey, world awaits you little red shirt and you must go boldly into the darkness to break out. 

Sound scape of the game is dynamic and immersive, with some fantastic tense stings and crescendos during the chase sequences. There were many moments in this game that got my heart pounding. 

I would highly recommend picking up this game and playing it through, if time spent vs cost is of your concern, then wait till it is on sale. It is so worth your time and money. 

Additionally, this game ran like an absolute dream on the Steam Deck, which I played a majority of this game on. 
Hope you found this useful!

Story is ambiguous, captivating, and eerie... the music is foreboding ominous... the art direction is stunning--a huge step up from LIMBO. Love short and sweet games like this. Also lots of secrets... if you collect them all, the game hints at a secret ending. New game devs should take notes.

INSIDE is a puzzle-platform game that establishes a very intriguing story and features a much fitting protagonist, an innocent young boy. The game uses many dark, depressive themes, which it demonstrates through graphic violence throughout the story (I promise you I flinched quite a lot at the brutality), and often scenes with poor lighting.

As an FPS player, I've never been much a fan of campaign/story games, but INSIDE compelled me to keep playing and playing, until I check my phone and see that it's 2 am. I can really appreciate the platformer style of INSIDE and must highlight the immense amount of detail employed in the interactions between all characters in the game and all the detail even in the parts of the map that are hidden away. I also like the realistic colour palette used in this game and I was unable to find a part of the map that looked plain or dull.

This game left me satisfied with it's conclusion, although this is to no surprise as I loved INSIDE's predecessor Limbo when I was younger. I absolutely don't regret trying INSIDE, and I look forward to any future works by Playdead studios.

Inside is a 2.5D puzzle-platformer by Playdead, and it continues their tradition of having a unique look, a colored, low-poly artstyle this time. You play as a boy who is hunted by government agents. After running through dystopian streets filled with mindless people and empty fields, he would have to cross a mysterious research facility. It does raise the question, is this facility simply on the way, or does he have a greater mission? 

Story plays an important part, in fact this game is more story-based and less puzzle-platformer than its predecessor Limbo. The puzzles here feel natural, like how you must use the items around you to progress, instead of being puzzles for the sake of puzzles. For example, in some parts you can gather mindless people to progress. You can lead them and with their help, move heavy objects or reach higher ledges. There's no annoying precision platforming such as "jump down the slide at the right time to reach next platform and avoid these unnaturally large saws". And while timing-reliant stuff still exists, the timing is a lot more forgiving.

The level variation is another good thing, there are many, but they also feel real and natural. There are forests, farms, flooded labs, mines, etc. The enemy encounters, which are my favorite parts of Limbo, are also more common here and are fun to dealt with, like hiding from guards and running from dogs. It reminds me more of Little Nightmares, another great puzzle-platformer with a creepy atmosphere. There are also collectibles, don't forget to seek these mysterious orbs out for achievements and an alternate ending that might make things a bit clearer... even though its still confusing.

Overall, I think Inside is a major improvement from Limbo, which to be honest I don't really like. The most important thing is that its easier and more story-based rather than puzzle-platforming, I never felt frustrated during my whole run. If you enjoy puzzle-platformers and story-based games you will have a great time with this title. Especially recommended if you like Little Nightmares, it might scratch that itch despite the lack of scary enemies and boss battles.

I genuinely loved this game; through every development and turn, it kept me invested and intrigued. This, alone, is a huge reason as to why I like this game so much. INSIDE is clever with its puzzles, has fantastic escape sequences, it's unapologetic and gruesome. Even the narrative alone is this depressing, dark, wicked, incredibly-interesting yet terrifically-done tale on Class and Human Testing. (Of which, sadly I will not go into due to spoilers.) In summary - it's incredibly well made.

In large, the world-building is phenomenal - every scene means something and Playdead makes anything you may go through count. Watching the sleepwalkers mark in unison, realising what is happening in the factories and other places alike. It's disturbing but once again, so, so interesting. Especially on your first play-through. The puzzles are also fantastic. (As you would expect from a puzzle game.) They fit the world perfectly and it even 1-ups Playdeads previous game, LIMBO. INSIDE does what LIMBO did but just better; the lack of UI. Though, with INSIDE, it's cleaner and polished. The intricate use of colour design makes the experience as a whole even better. It clues you in better - it's straightforward as to what you can interact with but by no means does it give the puzzle away entirely. Plus, it's worth noting, how that when you mess up a puzzle, you can tell where you went wrong. Did I just get torn to shreds by one of the dogs? Okay, maybe I should've been more patient. Stuff like that.

Another large aspect I like about this game is just how well it flows. Going smoothly from one environment to another - gives you a large range of puzzles without it seeming abrupt or forced. It's honestly great. And, it's in this regard, that INSIDE's visual style and design are just on another level entirely. The enemies appear and you deal with them, and even how they progress and change throughout the game too is beyond amazing. It's such a simple concept when put like that but something INSIDE nails. Something I will quickly mention though (it's a part of the trailer so no spoilers here) - the sequence where you have to blend in with the sleepwalkers felt fantastic with the game's flow. It was unexpected but you just have to go with it knowing that one wrong move and you're a goner again. It happens but it's not abrupt. Again, something this game nails. Even despite it being one of the most straightforward parts of the game it's incredibly nerve-wracking. 

Something I feel isn't mentioned enough though is this game's sound design. Every noise and crack and bang is finely tuned to immerse you further into the experience. The dogs barking, the jostling of a chain fence, it's silent when it needs to be, loud bangs fit, the no dialogue - all uninterrupted. 

In conclusion, there are no UI prompts, no minimaps, no score, no timer, and no health or stamina bar - it's immersive and incredibly interesting. As much as I love the narrative of INSIDE and as much as I would love to see it more - it's something that shouldn't be replicated or copied. I'm glad INSIDE has its own, unique story and especially in the way it's presented to you. I just wish other video games learnt from this sort of storytelling.

INSIDE is a very well made and beautifully executed indie game, similar to Playdead's other game LIMBO, INSIDE is pretty much that game but everything done just 10 times better making it seriously one of the best indies ive played in recent years, the puzzle platforming is better then ever with the interactive gameplay still being simple but offering a great challenge to accomplish with alot more environmental objects to mess around with and manipulate. Excellent. This game is almost a spiritual successor to Limbo, created by the same team, and it improves upon the idea's, visuals and sounds of Limbo in every way.

The atmosphere created in Inside is simply awesome. You are drawn into a world that is filled with tensity and ever impending dread, as you try desperately to escape terrors, and just manage to by the skin of your teeth.

The sound and visuals of the game are breathtaking at times, and the soundtrack will leave you well and truly immersed.

There is an ongoing theme of escape throughout the game and it has a good storyline that gives away just enough for you to understand the general plot, but leaves enough ambiguity for you to question certain things and fill in the blanks using your own imagination.

The gameplay itself is fun and progresses nicely. The puzzle's aren't too difficult but they are very creative so they're still fun and don't feel repetitive.

The games has some nice secrets that are fun to discover and solve, and lead to a secret ending.

I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoyed Limbo or any similar puzzle game.

as a little boy being chased through a lovecraft-inspired world, you have to solve small puzzles that are relatively simple. the gameplay and controls are also minimalistic, and mechanics are only implicitly explained. 

overall, it's a great experience and makes for a good night's entertainment at 2-4 hours in length. Price might seem a bit over the top, but you should definitely get it on sale.

Playdead is back with another challenging cinematic puzzle platformer where you don't exactly know what's going on in the story upon first blush.

Animation and design wise this is an upgrade from LIMBO. I love how the protagonist is animated here, he feels real despite having no dialogue, he look around when needed and when idle sometimes he'll catch his breath or wipe himself off.
Above all else the animation breathes and I loved that about it.

Puzzles where taxing but fair, there where a couple of gotcha moments that took me right out it at a few points tho.
The "mermaid" enemies about 3/4 of the way through where extremely annoying, though those where the only exceptions I can think of.

The story could be interpreted several ways and leave you thinking about it for some time, I have my own ideas on how it's a metaphor for capitalism treating their workers as disposable resources brought to a post apocalyptic extreme.

Not sure if it was intentional but the last segment of the game was extremely funny and cathartic 

So yeah! If your looking for an artsy puzzle platformer that you can beat in 4 hours I cant think of a reason not to check out INSIDE

This is an incredible game. The design of the levels, the color of the scenarios, the sound design and the game mechanics work perfectly together to give a sensation of being lost, curious, afraid and amazed at the same. The vague story helps with this, making the mad world you're in fascinating but dangerous, which gives the desire to survive and explore every place. It's the perfect example of how a simple, but well developed, game can be way better than many complexes games.

The sound design is probably one of the best experiences I've ever had playing a game. Particularly this pulse shock wave section. It was a genuine audiophile moment where headphones could just never give it justice. The story is nothing to write home about, but for me the sound design hits me so much more emotionally than a good story, and it's like 50% of the game play experience if done correctly. Gorgeous environmental depth too, it's very similar to Little Nightmares in that regard. It's honestly incredible how one can manipulate a 2D style game to evoke that much perspective. Really recommend playing this one.

wow.. I'm absolutely blown away by this one. this is nothing short of an interactive, speechless, cinematic masterpiece! I wish that I could get that "first play through" experience again... also, it left me with questions. many, many questions.. O.o

the sheer depth of every single scene is astounding. nothing ever feels "flat".. and yes, I know the game is actually fully 3D. but to capture that feeling this well in a side scroller? that's just beautiful.

top that off with super fluid camera movement, and everything comes together so very well.. not once did I ever think "oh that's a crappy camera angle", as one does with so many other games.. it just makes you want to explore every corner, just to see it.

not gonna lie, that got my character killed... many, many, many times. in many, many gruesome ways. but the sights to see along the way, well now, that's the best part! (: oh, yes, and always follow the yellow cables...

honestly though, it made me laugh, it made me jump, it made me ask WTAF (many times).. all with no introductions, no explanations, no dialogue, and yet every moment spoke volumes. I cannot wait to play through this again, and see things I missed before, just like any good book... :)

[h1]INSIDE is a short but extremely well crafted puzzle horror platformer from the makers of LIMBO. I can't believe I didn't play it sooner - I didn't enjoy their previous game so I had reservations. At the same time I am in love with Little Nightmares and this game is much more similar to it. I believe it is a must-play for fans of the horror genre, especially at a discount. That being said, it is best to experience this game first while knowing as little about it as possible.[/h1]

Please excuse the poeticism that will follow in this review, but as much as I don't like this style for the most part, there is really no other way to think about this game without losing a key part of the whole.

The game is presented in a carefully modelled and directed 3D environment, but you move only in two dimensions, disregarding depth, for the sake of focus one could assume.

The controls are simple and so are the puzzles, but it doesn't take away from the experience in any way. To the contrary - it seems to ground the game mechanics within it's theme, unlike many other similar games where your protagonist pauses to interact with an overly convoluted immersion-breaking minigame for 20 minutes.

The game doesn't feature any text or dialogue to explain it's story, instead relying on visuals and soundscapes. It makes no effort to ensure that it's plot is coherent. This is probably the most important factor deciding whether someone will enjoy it or not. I did - immensely.

Games are often being called art for completely arbitrary and sometimes even insincere reasons. I think this isn't one of those cases, this title fully deserves to be called a piece of high art. Not even because how painstakingly crafted, planned and directed the experience is or how hauntingly beautiful it looks and sounds. After all, the graphics seem simple, possibly relatively easy to be replicated by others, and the core gameplay is nothing to write home about. But the way this game made me think about it and obsess over it surely deserves recognition. And I'm not alone in this, as there are many people looking for clues, explanations to the mysteries, crafting fan theories and being driven to write long and winded paragraphs about them. While it's interesting and fun to read up on all of these, most of them are purely headcanon, conjecture, unnecessary overanalysis and guess work.

Usually I hate this kind of stuff. I guess the method of hyping people with mysteries was popularized by the TV series Lost, which was probably just a method of covering up for a cheap writing process where the showrunners thought about the plot of the next episode only after finishing the previous one without any overarching plan in mind. I don't think this is the case here, though, as there's no contradictions with some disappointing canon, no lazy writers to steal fans' ideas and no real answers to be found in the first place.

To me, INSIDE is simply a nightmare. Terrifying in it's beauty and hypnotizing it's witnesses, planting seeds in their minds with it's many mysteries. That's how nightmares work - they consume us completely while we are inside them, make us question even the most obvious things and shudder at the thought of the secrets they tease. But when we wake up, we realize the answers will never be found as the whole thing was probably just nonsense, a fever dream and with each waking hour the once fascinating details get blurry and fade into oblivion. Most of them we will forget completely, but the most powerful nightmares will stay with us for years or longer. Even if only as slivers of meaning, strange feelings and alien images ingrained into our minds. Even if not because they touched us on some fundamental level, but simply because of how bizarre they are and unlike anything else we experienced.

And in this strange way, even though it only took a couple of hours, I believe INSIDE will stay with me and haunt my thoughts for a really long time. And despite it being unsettling and scary, I am grateful for that outcome.

Lot to say about this game.

I think the first thing I have to note though is the brutality. Because while the game is gorgeous, the world building is spectacular (with no dialogue! Show, don't tell), the puzzles are clever, and the escape sequences are so tightly timed that I tensed up [i]every single time[/i], I HAVE to warn you that it's unapologetic in its gruesome story telling.

INSIDE is not a happy story. It's depressing, dark, and twisted, but most importantly: It's terrifically done. INSIDE had my skin crawling like few games dared to try. But that meant going through with the graphic content to back up the stakes.

I'm going to list a one of the death animations and describe it, but under a spoiler tag. That way if you need the extra info to decide, it's there, but I'm not spoiling anything for somebody just scrolling by. But to note: Some of these wouldn't be as bad if you weren't a [i]child[/i] being killed.

[spoiler] When a dog catches you, there's a full death sequence. It bites you, some tear at you, others snap your neck. And you watch for a couple seconds after you die, so it's just dogs eating your body, or your now limp body hanging from the dog's mouth. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] If adults catch you, you get a couple different ones as well. Strangulation seemed to be the most popular, but I was also beaten with a stick/bat once. Again, disturbing to see an adult beat a child like that. [/spoiler]

ALL THAT SAID:

It's [i]incredibly[/i] well made. The world-crafting is terrifically done, as they make every scene you go through count. Watching the people march along, realizing what this factory does to people here, all through phenomenal visual storytelling.

And the puzzles fit the world perfectly. INSIDE does what LIMBO did, where you create a gorgeous puzzle game with no UI, except INSIDE did it cleaner. I loved LIMBO, but some of it was tough with it being all black. Through INSIDE, they're able to take full control of color design to make the entire puzzle even better. It's easier to tell what you can interact with and what you can't, the context clues are more fleshed out, and the whole experience flows better for it. Mess up a puzzle and you'll be able to catch what went wrong from your first death. It's great that I only have to mess up once, and the death again gives you clues on what went wrong. I stood somewhere too long, I should've let go sooner, whatever it is.

The flow of the whole game feels terrific. I didn't realize how jarring it was to go from a desert to the sewers to ice capped mountains, when suddenly I ran into a puzzle game that flowed the whole way through. There were varied environments to work through, giving you a diverse array of puzzles, but it wasn't just abruptly changing scenery all the time. INSIDE's visual design is on a whole separate level in this regard. The enemies that appear, how you dealt with them, and how that progressed the game were [i]beyond[/i] brilliant as well. I'm going to talk about a part from the trailer, so no spoiler tag here: The part where you have to lock-step with other people was AMAZING mid-game. It happens, you have to go through with it, and eventually you make your way out the other side. But I wasn't ready for it, and it felt like such a fun part of the puzzle to do and experience. It's nerve racking, despite being one of the simplest parts of the game!

Every facet of this game is finely tuned and crafted to make the most of a video game that you can. The dogs barking, the chain link fence jostling, the silence, the loud bangs, all entirely uninterrupted by flimsy stories to justify you changing from the sewers to Paris france even though you were on a mountain. No UI prompts, no minimaps, no score, no timer, no health bar, to bring you that much closer to the piece of art and not the "video game" portion of the format.

Sincerely recommend, it sets a ridiculous bar for video game story telling as a format. Other games would do well to learn from INSIDE. Not copy it, but learn from it.

While I found this to be much better than Limbo, I still don't fully understand the appeal. The controls are smooth and the visuals gorgeous, but the game play is lacking. Which would be okay, if the story made up for it, but it doesn't. The story utilizes striking imagery to tell us themes we all already know and agree with. It is not saying anything unique, and doesn't tell its message in any particularly interesting way through game play. Is more of a series of paintings you walk through and by the end I felt like it would work better as a picture book. There are moments of beauty, wonder and horror that almost feel like they are adding up to something worthwhile, unfortunately it never really feels whole.

Although this game is definitely visually impressive and attempts to communicate a powerful story, I actually found that in terms of general gameplay this was lacking.

Most of the puzzles are enjoyable, and the ending, without spoiling it, was definitely a sudden burst of fun that I did not expect from this. Regardless, there are a few puzzles that don't make much sense in hindsight, and were otherwise very difficult to figure out.

The length of the game is also lacking, though I don't see how much they could stretch this without making it obnoxious. I beat the game in 2.4 hours, which means that, realistically, someone could play this to completion, enjoy it, and refund it if they finish under 2 hours. Without speedrunning.

Overall, an enjoyable experience, but not an experience worth over 20$. Wait for a sale under 10-15$ instead.

INSIDE is one of the more distributing games I've ever experienced.

The visual style is both simplistic and grand. It tells an eerie story that will pull at your heartstrings without a word of dialogue. And its a compelling, enjoyable puzzle game to boot.

Playdead is a pinnacle in gaming industry. They got so far two games but what they did is something that no other company have managed to accomplish in the past 13 years. I haven't seen any other game executing the environment with mechanics and physics so well. INSIDE is so simple to play - you don't have complicated controls or systems, minimalistic to it's core, puzzle are easy yet make you think about how creative these levels designers actually are. Similar to LIMBO, INSIDE doesn't tell you to story directly, it let the players to find it and interpret it as they want. INSIDE managed to tell a fantastic story without single line of dialog or text, something that many company can't achieve till this day, even with help of next-gen engines and highly paid voice actors. Looking forward for their next project.

Beautiful and promising, but terrible to play.
As you guide the little startrekian RedShirt across a seamless 3D blockout, it brings to question one's gaming habits.
Does one enjoy a linear sequence of puzzles and reflex moments, presented with no explanations and some brutal timings? So that you die over and over, until you figure out that one solution, with no hints whatsoever?  If so, INSIDE got you covered.

For everyone else, including me - folks, this is a worse deal of a "videogame" than the point&click adventure games from 90s! Those had you pixel hunt to figure things out, but at least you controlled the pacing, encountered interesting NPCs, and the deaths were more jovial. So If I wanted an atmospheric narrative with lot of trial&error guessing, I would play any of those instead.

Some "games" are better watched on YouTube, for sure.

At its core, Inside is a walking simulator composed of mind numbingly simple and tedious puzzles that serve as the majority of its runtime. While the atmosphere is on point, the artstyle is subjectively bland, and the gameplay is so boring that itâ€™s almost a nonfactor. I suppose the story is interesting, but really only by video game standards. While the game does an excellent job of implementing show donâ€™t tell storytelling, there are just too many loose ends and things that were not properly expanded apon for my liking. The game certainly has its moments, but for people who prefer their games to be overall fun or challenging, this game is a hard pass. Definitely one of the most overrated games Iâ€™ve played in recent memory.
it aight

First of all, the game is a masterpiece of visual storytelling. The graphics are stunning and the animations are fluid, and there's no dialogue or text to distract from the haunting atmosphere. You play as a young boy, and your journey takes you through a surreal and dystopian world that's equal parts beautiful and terrifying.

But let's talk about the puzzles. Inside is like a puzzle game on steroids. The puzzles are challenging and creative, and they're woven seamlessly into the narrative. You'll need to use your wits and your reflexes to solve them, and you'll feel a real sense of satisfaction when you finally figure out the solution.

But what really sets Inside apart is its sense of mystery and intrigue. The game raises more questions than it answers, and the story is open to interpretation. You'll be left wondering what it all means long after you've finished the game.

Overall, Inside is a haunting and immersive experience that will stay with you long after you've played it. If you're a fan of atmospheric games, thought-provoking storytelling, and mind-bending puzzles, then this game is a must-play. Just make sure you have some time set aside, because you won't want to stop playing until you've uncovered all the game's secrets.

I was first introduced to this game after watching playthroughs â€” and I still bought the game myself. Being someone who absolutely loves ambient and puzzle platformer games, this is one of my favourite games of all time. The entire environment is dreary and mysterious while also having the element of puzzles you have to solve. I like games where it makes me think a bit more, so I enjoy that aspect of it. Gameplay is very straightforward â€” just consists of moving, jumping, and interacting with stuff. Harder parts are the puzzles. Sound and music add a lot to the atmosphere as well â€” I highly recommend having your volume on for this.

The storyline is somewhat fuzzy as the ending gives way for various interpretations but it generally goes like this: A young boy wakes up in a forest, ventures his way through a town and eventually through a sort of factory where people are being experimented on. I won't spoil the details for the ones who haven't played the game and still would like to. 

Overall amazing game if you are looking for an ambient puzzle platformer!

Inside is a masterful game that uses visual storytelling to convey its narrative in a powerful and immersive way. The gloomy atmosphere adds to the overall feeling of unease and mystery, drawing the player deeper into the gameâ€™s world. But what really sets Inside apart is its incredible sound design. Every sound effect is perfectly crafted to enhance the experience and create a truly unforgettable gaming experience. Overall, Inside is a must-play for anyone who appreciates great storytelling and atmosphere in a bite-sized platformer.

There are a lot of unanswered questions. It's nice that the game is open to discussion and makes you think. Isn't that curiosity that's attractive? My first question would be, why and how did that kid get there? The game has a different ending, which I discovered while following the contents of the game. Go and check it out. It's a little hard to find ourselves, but you can watch it.

The game has an incredibly clever level flow. That's why this game has managed to become one of my top favorite games. You just dive into the game and the game progresses without interrupting you, just like reading a book.
This puzzle game gives even the basic first steps like jumping or pulling something as a puzzle. It made me think like a complete problem solver. You are exploring on your own.

In general, the story is good, the flow is good, the level system is good (you can start from the beginning of the chapter you want), the mechanics are good (mind control mechanics for example); the ending is unsatisfied (so what happened now, what has that boy become?), there are some questions that need answers but didn't answered (the girl under the sea was trying to kill at first, then why did she save us later?, where did the kid come from at the beginning, what's the system inside, what is that object?)

In short, please play :)
Truly something special. A mystery that hooks you and provides great fun along the way.

I purchased this game during a sale because it was only a dollar or two, just because. I went in completely blind with absolutely no prior knowledge of what to expect, and that honestly made the experience that much more fascinating to me. It went from a spontaneous "well, it's cheap, why not?" to 5 and a half hours of enjoyment completing the game and finding all the little secrets hidden throughout.

Firstly, the visuals are fantastic. Pretty dark at times, but it never felt like a bad thing. It added to the mystery of "what in the world is going on here?" The sound design was also impressive and, as other reviews have said, playing this game with headphones on really gets you immersed in the world.

The concept alone is also captivating. No dialogue is presented or needed, all of your information coming from visuals alone and allowing you to draw your own conclusions. Where is this place? Who's behind it? What's the purpose of these experiments? What is the boy's goal? Normally I'm not one for open-ended plots, but this one truly grabbed onto me and did not let go. I never quite knew what would happen next and it surprised me throughout as the world became more and more bizarre and intriguing.

And lastly is the length and difficulty of the game. I honestly found it to be just right. Not so short that I was disappointed when it was over, but also not so long that it feels impossible to complete in one sitting or like it dragged out. Right when I felt like the perfect time for an ending was approaching, there it was. The difficulty level also felt just right. The puzzles were never so easy that it felt boring or so difficult that it felt frustrating. You do have to think (harder on some levels than others) but it wasn't overdone at all.

Overall, if your kind of game is awesome visuals and sound design with a captivating open-ended story to theorize over and twists that keep you on the edge of your seat, this one is absolutely worth it.

I recently picked up "Inside" on a spring sale for just 1.10 USD (83 INR), and I have to say, it was an absolute steal. The puzzles were challenging yet satisfying to solve, and the atmosphere was absolutely haunting. I completed the game and unlocked all of the achievements in just three hours, but the experience was so engrossing that I was left wanting more.

What sets "Inside" apart from other puzzle games is its thought-provoking storytelling and stunning visuals. The developers have truly created a world that is both beautiful and disturbing, and the soundtrack only adds to the overall immersive experience.

I was also impressed with the incredible value for money that I got with this game - thanks to the spring sale, I was able to purchase the "Inside and Limbo" combo pack for such a low price. I can't wait to dive into "Limbo" and see what other incredible worlds the developers have created.

I want to take a moment to appreciate the developers of "Inside" for their hard work and dedication in creating such a memorable and unique gaming experience. They have clearly poured their hearts into this game, and it shows in every aspect of it. If you're looking for a game that will stick with you long after you've finished playing, I highly recommend "Inside".

While I definitely recommend this game for the dark atmospheric undertones, the ending was rather disappointing. Though Playdead's Limbo didn't exactly have a linear "story" per se, a story was told regardless of the lack of dialogue. The ending was emotionally touching, and in my opinion, dang near perfect. This ending was, might I say, underwhelming? Yeah, that's the word. Otherwise, the gameplay was fun and inventive, the atmosphere was incredible, and the art style beautifully dark. Overall, an 8/10, would recommend.

I'm not a "gamer" but I still really liked this game. I would highly recommend using headphones, since the sounds effects make the game much more immersive. 

In hindsight, it would have been better, for a slow player like me, to skip trying to get any of the achievements and just watch the secret ending in an online video, which I ultimately ended up doing, thankfully. 

I'd also resist trying to find any meaning in the game, or read blog posts about what others think it is trying to say. The game's world is really bizarre, but unless Playdead's Danish development team eventually comes out and tells us what they were thinking, it is useless to conjecture -- it would be like trying to understand the ending of "2001: A Space Odyssey" without hearing it from Stanley Kubrick himself.

Warnings + more detailed review: 

If you have cynophobia, thalassophobia or fear of being chased, only play this game if you don't mind your fears being triggered. The end can be disturbing if you don't like body horror. It's more cartoonish, so I personally managed.
Still, there's a lot of being chased involved in this game, which I don't like, by humans, dogs and creatures I won't spoil. There's much more chasing than in Limbo, which focused on puzzles. Limbo's spiders were cute in comparison.

I also thought the puzzles in Limbo were more elaborate and not as easy. But maybe my memory tricks me. There were some good puzzles here, too, but a lot were easy to grasp for me. With the graphic the game is definitely atmospheric though and I still enjoyed playing it. It's more like dark art than a game, similar to Limbo the game gets you thinking...

I'm not a fan of the horror genre or stressful games, but I found Inside fantastic despite these. The world design is so weirdly delightful. I haven't seen such a perfect combination of gameplay elements in a long time. [list][/list] [list][/list]The sound and visuals are very immersive. It combines puzzle elements with platformer design, and the design is so tight that there are many "nick of time" moments which have you on edge that you can pass only by a hair's breadth. Solving each puzzle is very rewarding. If you like games where you explore, combine elements, and solve mysteries, you'll love this one. [list][/list] [list][/list]Some gameplay mechanics are very unusual and interesting, and nothing like I've seen in any other game. The game gets more and more bizarre as it progresses, and builds up to an insane ending. I played the game twice â€“ once to just run through, and the second time, to collect all achievements. Terrific fun. Replay value is a little low once you solve the puzzles the first time around, but I was surprised by how much I'd forgotten in my second playthrough. [list][/list]  [list][/list]Highly recommend. 10/10. Worth every penny.

If Playdeadâ€™s Limbo was the first slice, Inside is the whole cake. Everything is grander in scope, from the oppressive atmosphere of the world to the puzzles and scares. While buzzwords such as â€œminimalismâ€ and â€œenvironmental storytellingâ€ have certainly taken over the industry since the early 2010s, Limbo takes those two in spades and delivers without elements feeling unnecessary or underutilized. Puzzles are clearly conveyed and satisfying with many feeling like actual devices diegetic to the game world than random contraptions a la Myst. Like a resistant microbe or a persistent parasite, Inside is something that sticks around after completion and leaves players asking questions, but itâ€™s a satisfying kind of curiosity rather than a medical emergency.

Oh boy, where do I even begin with my review of "Inside"? This game is an absolute masterpiece.First of all, the visuals in this game are stunning. The art style is minimalist but incredibly effective at setting the mood and creating a sense of unease. The animations are so smooth that it's almost like watching a Pixar movie (except with a lot more darkness and existential dread).But the real star of the show here is the gameplay. "Inside" is a puzzle platformer that will have you scratching your head and wracking your brain, but in the most enjoyable way possible. Every level is a unique challenge, and you'll find yourself constantly surprised by the clever ways the game forces you to think outside the box.And let's not forget about the story. I won't give anything away, but let's just say that "Inside" is one of those rare games that manages to be both incredibly thought-provoking and absolutely bonkers at the same time. It's the kind of game that will stick with you long after you've finished it, and leave you pondering its meaning for days.Overall, I can't recommend "Inside" enough. It's a funny, heartwarming romp through a world of darkness and despair that will leave you feeling optimistic about the human condition. Okay, maybe not that last part, but seriously, go play this game. You won't regret it!

It's funny cause right untill the end I had in mind to give a positive review. 
Game-play wise, this is a relaxing game, with easy puzzles and obstacles, it starts exiting, then it gets a little slow in the middle part (the underwater part) and then it shines again at the end. 
The graphics is average, you have only a few colours since it's always dark and gloomy. 
The music is non-existent, you only hear the sound from the boy running or interacting with the environment. 

This game is all about the story. No doubt this game has a very special, complex story. 
But, what is incredible is the following. While reading the game description, when you see a few pictures of the game, and while playing the game untill the ending, you get a feeling that it's about a boy being chased from a sci-fi high-tech dictatorial regime, being one of the few remaining free individuals that hasn't been enslaved and assimilated. I thought the story is very similar to the matrix movie, with the goal to enter the core of the system to unplug your body and mind from the matrix. 
But, at the end you have a shocking revelation, and you understand that it's NOT about the boy, and the story is not similar to the Matrix. The player is not the boy at all, but something else. I don't want to spoil anything, so I will just say that I really didn't like the twist in the end, and the fact that the story is completely different from what I thought it would be. I thought: "why on earth did they shift the paradigm from something that is exiting and easy to relate to ( especially if you are interested in conspiracy theories ) to THAT. It doesn't make sense."
It turns out that the game doesn't even describe the story properly, because most of the things are vague, superficially put out and left to the imagination of the gamer. On the forums players have many discussions about trying to explain the story and there are many theories about it. 
I would wholeheardedly recommend this game if it was about the things I described, but since it's not, I really can't. Too bad, because it's otherwise relaxing and engaging.

Worth playing, but make sure to get it at a discount, and completely avoid if you don't like platforming timing puzzles.

This is a beautiful game to experience, but I can't help thinking that it doesn't know what it wants to be.

There are parts that are casual and thoughtful where you can take time with puzzles and enjoy the atmosphere and those parts I enjoyed.

Then there are parts where split second timing is required, with no obvious way to tell what is required until you have died several times. Sections which I struggle with due to age/health and find intensely frustrating and not the slightest bit fulfilling when I finally do manage to do exactly what I should.

Working out what needed to be done was much more interesting than trying to actually do it, when mostly the actions are fairly mundane, but require precision.

It would have been immeasurably better had there been a 'casual' mode with walking/puzzle solving, and an 'action' mode with the platforming and split second guesswork for those who enjoy that, rather than an odd combination that probably doesn't quite satisfy either camp.

Because of some of those sections, there is no chance I would ever want to replay this, but for under Â£2 I can't complain about that - if I'd paid the original price I would have felt short changed though.

Also note that it is not a long game - 4-5 hours maximum will get you through it, but Steam seems to think all the times I left it running and went and did something else because of frustration at the design count as playing hours!

Here's my little sales pitch: The game starts right where it left off, with a blob by the sea. Then it sees the one dude coming to get him, so he rolls into the ocean. Next, the blob tries to swim but is finding it hard because it's a blob. Then a fishing net swoops it up and takes it onto the boat. Then the main character dude crawls out of the blob and is given clothes by the ship's crew. Then, he sees a bunch of fat dudes chasing a girl in a yellow raincoat. Wait, this is sounding familiar... And then some gnomes- Wait, am I having deja vu? Oh no.

Wow, what a gem. A mix of a puzzle game and art project basically. It is really well made and a very polished and fluent experience, no loading screens, super thick atmosphere with tense/scary parts here and there, fascinating physics and animation system that gives everything momentum and weight, as well as superb set design and lighting. All in a weird, frightening, fascist/brutalism/postapocalyptic world in which you are thrown as this little innocent child.

I don't like puzzle games in general, but fortunately they keep it on the easier side of things here so it's not frustrating, probably comparable to Portal and of course Limbo. It is quite short (took me around 3 hours), but worth it.

I bought this game on a promo for a pocketful of change. And it was more than worth its money despite the short play time. I finished the game in about 5h playtime. It is a side scrolling puzzle game with a very minimalistic steering. Just arrowbuttons and the spacebar.

But OH BOY the athmosphere of it! The storytelling. The nifty effects, the visuals... every screenshot is an art nouveau painting. You get immediately drawn in. 

You start out as a boy running in the forest,  you seem to be running/hiding from shady company men and their guard dogs. The further you run the trickier the puzzles get to hide/escape/advance. As you advance you find out more and more about the weird experiments that seem to go on in this company and you will need to use their tech to get ahead. 

All in all the puzzles are quite doable, avid puzzlers might even be a bit underchallenged. But the execution of them and simplicity of handling complex mechanics is just baffling. There are hidden secrets so do consider replay and check every nook and cranny and the end will have you go WTF!

10/10 would buy again.

INSIDE is an absolutely breathtaking game that left me awestruck with its incredible graphics, immersive atmosphere, and hauntingly beautiful music. As someone who loved LIMBO, I found that INSIDE takes the concept to a whole new level. While the puzzles weren't the most challenging, they were still enjoyable and kept me engaged throughout the game.

Despite its brevity, INSIDE manages to pack an emotional punch with its incredible storytelling and unforgettable visuals. The platforming is tight, and the overall experience is simply unforgettable. I found myself getting lost in the game's incredible world and didn't want the journey to end.

In conclusion, INSIDE is a must-play for anyone who appreciates a game with incredible atmosphere, stunning visuals, and an engaging story. While the puzzles may not be the most challenging, the game more than makes up for it with its other strengths. If you're looking for a game that will leave you with a sense of wonder and amazement, then INSIDE is definitely worth checking out!

Inside is a fantastic audiovisual experience that well outdoes the development team's previous effort. It is full of tense moments and often plays like a horror title. I can't fault the presentation in any major way. 

Mechanically, the game is full of relatively simplistic puzzles. Unlike what one might expect, these puzzles don't gradually teach the player things or culminate in a final challenge that calls on the player to demonstrate what they've learned. There's little to say about the game mechanically.

There's also--and this is the more unfortunate and serious criticism--little to nothing to say about the game thematically. Inside clearly wants to say or suggest something about despotic governments, oppression, the devaluation of life by huge systems and so on, but never actually does. One doesn't even get the catharsis of 'revenge' on their pursuers if that's what one was looking toward. 

It's like if you were to watch a wordless Twilight Zone episode which ultimately had no point at all, nothing to say (something anathema to Rod Sterling). There is a twist, and you can try to intuit what that twist means, but beyond plot curiosities, there is nothing there. You move from inside a system of oppression to, at least in a literal sense, outside of a containment building. 

I have to consider this a major criticism because with all this beautiful art and evocative imagery and sound, there is so much opportunity left on the table to actually take the time to try and *say* or even simply *show* anything at all about its subject matter. It's another in a long trend of indie works that thinks that ambiguity is a stand-in for actual courage and intellect in one's art, for the willingness to take a stand on something. 

And, while ambiguity and mystery can be a powerful force in a work, those works still need to have said something along the way before you leave viewers to ponder, not unlike David Lynch's works. Inside makes no such effort. It never works up to anything, either a big, grand puzzle or a punctuating emotional moment. It settles for the kind of low-effort 'storytelling' that people mistake for depth.

So while I can recommend it as a walking simulator with light puzzle/horror elements and an intriguing world (which admittedly cribs a lot from Valve's work on Half-Life 2), I can't recommend it as a thematic experience, story, or really anything that might create a lasting impression on someone beyond its largely neutral imagery.

[h1] A wordless story that leaves you wordless [/h1]

INSIDE is one of those gems every one should put on their radar (and this comes from a person who disliked Little Nightmares). Iâ€™m not a fan of puzzle-platform games with trial and error gameplay but this one is quite forgiving and easy, making room for lesser frustration. Briefly, INSIDEâ€™s strongest points are its linearity, simple controls and delightfully spooky atmosphere as well as the creativeness of the puzzles.

The gameplay is more focused on puzzle-solving than survival so instead of introducing â€sh*t your pantsâ€ type of scares, youâ€™ll be immersed into a creepy, atmospheric world with artistic graphics and ideas that will chill you to the bone. That is to say, there is still a bit of sneaking and escaping, and you must have an understanding of the perfect timing to make a successful getaway, otherwise youâ€™ll end up like mushed potatoes. 

Also, the way the gameâ€™s narrative conveys itself without words is mind-blowing. Despite the main characterâ€™s silence, I sympathized with him very much â€“ thereâ€™s no need for words when you see the world around him. So I recommend INSIDE for basically everyone out there. Itâ€™s short and while it gets a bit repetitive towards the end, itâ€™s worth every cent.

The game follows a young boy who must navigate through a dark and dystopian world filled with danger and mystery. The gameplay consists of solving puzzles and overcoming obstacles by manipulating the environment and interacting with various objects and creatures.

One of the standout features of "Inside" is its stunning visual design. The game's art style is simplistic yet incredibly effective, using a dark and moody color palette to create a sense of unease and tension. The attention to detail in the environment is also impressive, with every area of the game feeling meticulously crafted and full of hidden secrets.

The game's sound design is equally impressive, with an eerie and unsettling soundtrack that perfectly complements the game's visuals and atmosphere. The game also uses sound cues to great effect, helping to guide the player through puzzles and alerting them to potential danger.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of "Inside" is its storytelling. The game tells a captivating and mysterious story without ever relying on exposition or dialogue. Instead, the story is told through the environment and the player's interactions with it, leaving much of the interpretation up to the player.

Overall, "Inside" is an outstanding game that successfully combines innovative gameplay, striking visuals, and a captivating story to create an experience that is both thrilling and thought-provoking. It's a must-play for anyone who enjoys puzzle-platformers or is looking for a game that pushes the boundaries of what video games can achieve as a storytelling medium.

Inside excels in atmosphere and general engagement through pure weirdness. Past that it's a very simple platformer where you walk right. I say platformer and not puzzler because there are no real puzzles until the last third. The game is pretty sparse on traditional "game" elements. 

It excels in those clinch moments of life and death chases that are so perfectly timed to get your heart racing, but those are few and far between. 

In some ways, I'd like to say they've pushed this 2-d type of game as far as they can, but taking a step back, there's quite a lot Limbo accomplished that this game didn't. The real draw here is the atmosphere and ramp to supreme weirdness. 

It's a 6/10 game that gets a thumbs up, but not a lot because three hours for twenty bucks is a bit pricey.

Overall impression - 75 C - Wildly over-hyped, but still not a bad game. Due to the nature of the game and its short play time I would only recommend this game at a steep discount and only to those who do not being killed time and time again before getting a puzzle right. Inside might not be for those wanting closure at the end of a game too.

More Details: The game's controls are a little too fluid and imprecise. With some of the tight spots some of the puzzles put you in, it can get annoying to be killed by controls that are subpar. The 'story' of the game is left open to interpretation. While that is not a huge detractor to me, a little more explanation of what is going on in the game would have been nice. 

The art and music of this game carries it. Though a somber palette of colors is used through the game, there were scenes that amazed me. The music is minimalistic, but is skillfully used and matched to each section of the game to give them much more impact. The puzzles of the game take a little thinking, but none of them were unfair. I cannot say the same for some of the early chase sequences. The abundant save points kept some parts of the game from becoming frustrating.

I would recommend Inside only to people who like this style of game.

Disclaimer -  I didnt like Limbo, the puzzles felt obtuse and a chore to trial-and-error your way through. I was worried that this game would frustrate me like Limbo did, but my friends suggested I give this a shot anyways and man I wasnt disappointed!

Other disclaimer - doing some game design homework and publishing it here as a sign of completion, dont expect this to be too coherent.

#SPOILERISH OF COURSE!

Boy this game really sets the tone fast with a close-up, dark, intimate view of watching a child (you) being suffocated. You really feel them too, whether you are being harpooned or torn apart by dogs, they are very visceral in a way that most other games dont manage.

Not only is it (imo) prettier than Limbo, the sound design has also improved. It is mostly ambient, environmental noises that still manage to sound menacing. You as a character are very quiet, you only hear your own footsteps and breathing. All of the other sounds are the environment, which can be read as: things that can definitely kill you. Speaking of, because of the visuals and the sound, it is extremely tense when you are being chased by someone/something. I cant remember the last time I held my breath because I was so unsure if I was going to escape my pursuer.

So indeed there is still some Limbo-esque "youll have to die to figure out what to do" due to lack of hints visible before dying once or twice. However, the clues feel way less obtuse, and the clever use of light and sound to gently guide you in the correct direction, since this game gives you a bit more freedom in movement than Limbo (several floors of a building, for example). One more little Limbo-like complaint - near misses when jumping still happen, still set you back progress-wise, and are still annoying.

After dying a few times, it really began to feel like death (more specifically how you were killed) was a feature, not a bug. They actually use the way in which you die as a storytelling mechanism. Getting impaled by some weird surveillance robot with an electric cable as a harpoon made me think of this. They use it to color in the world with details you would otherwise miss if you never died throughout the game.

So to talk briefly about the story: I have no clue. This game is super mysterious, and it does such a good job of teasing you, getting your interest, and then never actually revealing the thing that got you so curious. In most games that would just be frustrating, but here, it adds to the sense of mystery even more, making you even more eager to plunge deeper. Once I finished the game, I still had no clue what occurred. I had a million hypotheses, but no strong sense of what happened, and I actually think that is desirable for this game. Everything hinged on your curiosity as a player, and the mystery of the game world. It left me thinking about it, as opposed to how I feel with most other games, which is more along the lines of â€œdone, whats next?â€

Even though I watched the last third, I still feel like this game has made quite an impression on me, and most likely a more enduring one than any other games I will play in the near future. Highly recommended.

[hr][/hr]
# **Discuss a meaningful moment of gameplay**
When the game opened up and it felt unbelievably vast and intimidating, moreso than any other game that I can think of in recent memory, maybe ever (even games with technically larger physical scales). It felt so lonely and empty and ominous, it was excellent. You felt like you were completely naked in front of a crowd of your worst enemies and they'll surely tear you to pieces. 

### What did I think? What did I feel?
I felt so small and vulnerable, like I was helpless in such a large, demanding environment. I felt possibly the most vulnerable I have felt in a game before. It just seems so bleak and impossible for you to resist in a place like that, after so many gruesome deaths, after barely being able to open doors myself. This vast space also added to the mystery - am I still underground? Where the hell am I anyways? Always more questions.

### What are the underlying mechanics that made this work?
Deliberate vulnerability on the part of the player-character. Throughout the whole game, we are made to run away from hunters, dogs, mermaids, scientists, environmental hazards, etc. You are a small child, in a world that is almost always bigger than you, but they take that 

### The dramatic aspects?
There is danger everywhere. Everything is a threat. Even in the sound design - our character is silent, the only sounds are the machines we manipulate and alllll of the various things trying to kill us. Our character is a child, the perfect example of innocence and vulnerability. 


[hr][/hr]
# Dig deeply into the choices I made, and what I thought and felt during those choices.
Does the player have any agency in this game? I never felt once like I actually had any choices in the game. It was always: solve puzzle, move up, rinse and repeat. 

### What game mechanics support those choices?
You don't have a choice by design - this fits the narrative since it deals with free will. 

### Why do certain mechanics exist in this game?
Minimal mechanics exist for the character, they have to augment themselves with machines and mind control devices just to navigate and survive in this world. Who did that blob of flesh control? My character is limited to increase perceived vulnerability. The ways in which we survive/grow stronger further the narrative.
Oldie but goodie. Worth grabbing on sale if you haven't yet.
It's wonderful.

If Playdeadâ€™s Limbo was the first slice, Inside is the whole cake. Everything is grander in scope, from the oppressive atmosphere of the world to the puzzles and scares. While buzzwords such as â€œminimalismâ€ and â€œenvironmental storytellingâ€ have certainly taken over the industry since the early 2010s, Limbo takes those two in spades and delivers without elements feeling unnecessary or underutilized. Puzzles are clearly conveyed and satisfying with many feeling like actual devices diegetic to the game world than random contraptions a la Myst. Like a resistant microbe or a persistent parasite, Inside is something that sticks around after completion and leaves players asking questions, but itâ€™s a satisfying kind of curiosity rather than a medical emergency.

Trying to find the right words to properly describe INSIDE is hard. 
The first word that comes to mind is "dark". 
The world you'll find yourself in is unforgiving, harsh, hostile and chokingly dark.
To survive you must overcome countless cruelties that lead you closer to INSIDEs twisted story. 
Without doubt you will come across a point during playing this game where you'll just freeze for a couple of seconds and soak in what the hell you've just seen.
This game certainly isn't everyone's cup of tea, but perfect for those that don't mind some occasional moral conflict now and then.

INSIDE is a unique experience with stunning visuals and a compelling story told without any dialogue. The sound design is phenomenal, and the ambience will surely make you unnerved. There are many unexpected events and a pretty obscure ending.

It contains some of the most fluid movement I've ever noticed in any game and is easy to pick up for anybody. None of the puzzles were too taxing. Even though the game is linear, it gives some freedom of movement and interaction with the environment.

It's a great but short game that takes around 5 hours to 100%, including achievements. Though I do recommend buying the game on sale.

I can't remember how or when I got this game, but it was in my inventory. I finally decided to play it, and I am glad I did. It immediately took me back to the early 90s of playing "Another World", which I loved (though it was a ridiculously tough game to finish). It had been a long time since I played a puzzle-platformer like this, and now I have a number of similar games on my wishlist (like Limbo, Stray).

Regarding the game, I found the main story line and the puzzles fairly straightforward. However, I didn't bother checking the achievements list before playing the game; thus, I didn't know about the orbs until finding the 4th one, which is the most obvious. After that, I started to pay more attention, and I found about half of the remaining ones. On my second play-through, I got the others ones, but there is no way that I would have found some of them without guided help.

I found this game more enjoyable with a louder volume and a sub-woofer. You can almost feel the energy wind blasts, and then there is the rhythm puzzle.
Absolute atmospheric delight.

My expectations for this game was high, considering this was from the same developers who created Limbo. This is even better than Limbo, imo. The dark, weird and creepy atmosphere within the game keeps you on the edge of your seat until the end.
The best thing however about the game is it's story. Much like Limbo, the story is can be interpreted in anyway we want it to make sense. Without going into any spoilers, my understanding is Inside has two stories. The literal story of a boy solving puzzles to try to escape (or get into) a secret facility, and a philosophical story about the society (how we're all just puppets in someone else's story). 
The ending is confusing at first. But if you have no problem with spending another 30 minutes to get the secret ending (you can get it by going back to previous levels and collecting all the orbs), the story will start to make sense a lot more.
The game can be completed in less than 5 hours, and I loved everything I experienced during that time. The art style, background score, well thought-out puzzles... it's clear that the developers put so much effort into this game and I'm glad it got the recognition it deserved. 
A 10/10 from me.
This is an amazing game if you love good world building. It also has a creepy atmosphere and reminds me of Portal 2.

Inside is original, meticulous, aesthetically impeccable with its chiaroscuro, depth, photography, sound design and gameplay. I would have loved to see its mechanics fully fleshed out. However, it earned a well-deserved place in the best of the year thanks to all its virtues. It is strange to discover joy in what terrifies us and generates anxiety, but this game manages to generate emotions not only through its gloomy context, but also with its mechanics. Few titles manage to do so. Inside succeeds in producing fascination with the unspeakable. It is almost like the irresistible attraction to observe the forbidden, the obscene or the sacred.

This game is an absolute gem. LIMBO is nothing compared to this masterpiece. I watched Markiplier play this ages ago and wanted to give it a go. Finally got around to it. And got all the achievements. We're trying to escape from an uncanny project environment where we don't know what's going on by controlling a small child. It has been a very successful game with its various puzzles, sense of art and simple gameplay.

A couple of bad points; I can say that it is relatively short and leaves a lot of question marks in the head. While the game doesn't answer the questions "who are we, where are we and why are we running from" at the beginning, it also doesn't answer them when it's finished. The obscurity, the mystery is nice, but I wish they could at least answer a few things that need explaining. The ending was also insufficient, there is also an alternative ending, which is very difficult to make sense of.

However, it would be unfair to give a negative for this game that started mysteriously and ended in a few hours with its mystery, because the game is pretty good.
