[h1]So, so, so, so much better than Limbo.[/h1]

I didn't like Limbo that much. It was a decent Puzzle platformer in it's first half and then, when I had seen enough of the art style after an hour or so, the game slowly became boring and ultimately even frustratingly annoying towards the end. So I had very reserved expectations towards Inside and at first I thought it would be even worse than Limbo. After a super-tense and serious start in a forest, I came to a farm after 5 minutes and got stuck in a barn. [spoiler]It turned out that I had to lure some fluffy baby chickens that were following me around to a machine that would violently suck them in and shoot them at a box higher up, so it would fall down and i could use it to climb over a wall. I was speechless. All I could think was "Am I playing Inside or some f*cked-up version of Angry Birds?" [/spoiler]. The game started super-tense and serious, you are running through a dark forest, chased by mysterious people, who shoot you on sight or drown you in puddles if they get to you, and then: ANGRY BIRDS! Sometimes those comical moments, wether they are intentional or unintentional, do make you chuckle a bit, but they also stand in harsh contrast to the super-serious and dark tone of the game.

Fortunately, moments like that are very rare in Inside, but nevertheless they make the game involuntarily funny at some points. It's weird. But after this initial frustrating face-palm moment, the game got gradually better and actually wasn't that annoying at all. In contrast to Limbo, where the artstyle gets old after no more than 15 minutes, Inside's visuals are actually  varied enough to stay interesting for the whole game. It's overall art style and design is even creepier than Limbo's and it has some stunning scenery here or there. A huge additional plus is the rest of the presentation: The animations are very detailed and life-like, the sound and ambient music are sparse but good and the controls are smoother, too.

However, what made Inside so much better than Limbo is it's general leveldesign. Contrary to Limbo, Inside really makes you want to know what all this weird sh*t is about in the end. The world of Inside is so much more interesting, captivating, creative and fun to explore and the difficulty curve is much more consistent all the way through to the end. Limbo's puzzles devolved more and more into annoying reflex-tests and frustrating, overly-precise platforming towards the end, but in Inside there is none of that sh*t. Sure, you won't solve some of the puzzles without a basic sense of timing and at least rudimentary platforming skills, but it never gets frustrating. Inside is all about just using your brain properly, like every good puzzle game should. Instead of just getting increasingly harder, the game is more about it's atmosphere. Actually, the puzzle that took me the longest time, was the one I mentioned above, right at the start of the game. It stays at this level of difficulty and once you know what the game wants you to do, every puzzle and platforming section in the game are perfectly solvable. If you push through all the way, you'll get rewarded with one of the craziest, weirdest and also kind of funniest endings I have ever seen in a videogame.

In the end I'd say: Limbo is overrated, Inside is art. Of course, Inside too is definitely not a game for everybody. You have to be somewhat open-minded to its style and willing to use your brain and think about stuff. If that doesn't sound deterrent to you, then I'd say try it out. Even if you didn't like Limbo, Inside could nevertheless turn out at least decent for you. However, despite it's very short playtime of about 3.5 to 4 hours and minimal replay value, Inside currently sells for 20 Euros at full price, which is just an insult. 50% discount is definitely the way to go here!

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I first played INSIDE six years ago and it was one of my first experiences in the realm of video games as a whole. This game is the first example I offer up not just in support of the â€˜Video Games as Artâ€™ argument but also of the notion that great art doesnâ€™t need to also be inapproachable. The mechanics of INSIDE are simple enough that they allow for even beginners to pick it up and have an enjoyable experience. Its game length is not overly long that people short on time may never see that ending. Yet its themes â€“ should you choose to ponder and speculate about them -  are so universal and completely open to interpretation that no two people could have the exact same experience. 

If anything, the greatest testament to this gameâ€™s brilliance is that even six years later, I still find myself thinking about it now and then. And wishing that other games out there could offer me anything close to what INSIDE does in its final 15 minutes.

Inside apparently took me 3.9 hours, but it felt a lot more like 10+. I have this feeling that when this game was mapped out, the devs had this one really cool scene in mind - if you've played it, you know the one I mean - and were having a real head scratcher trying to figure out how to justify charging $20.00 for that, so they slapped another 3.5 hours of content together, had their 5th graders take a crack at some puzzles, and congratulated themselves on a job very well done.

I paid $2.00 for this game, and while I cannot say that this is a lot of money, what I will say is that I could probably buy 6 McNuggets for that same price. While McNuggets are not always good, based on my past experiences with them and my past experiences with Inside, I think that I probably would have had a better time overall with them. So if we consider that maybe 15-20 minutes of this game is (from my perspective) worth your time, we're looking at a ratio of 2 dollars to 15-20 minutes. If I told you that you could watch MOST of an episode of Community if you gave me two bucks, you probably wouldn't take me up on that offer, so why would you take up Inside?

At the end of the day I do not recommend Inside, and the appropriate pricing that I should have paid is an apology to me from everyone who tricked me into playing it.

This game is absolutely beautiful on all levels of production. The moody, dystopian environments are such an incredible balance of fantasy and brutal realism. It didn't take me long to lose myself in the world. Not a single word of dialog is spoken, and yet a story unfolds with such a great sense of pace and nuance. 

The art direction in this game is absolutely top-notch. Carefully crafted environments breath unsettling life into the world. The desaturated world around your young male avatar does a fantastic job of painting with light, shape and silhouette. I also found the animation, particularly the character animations, to be wonderfully fluid, with weight and friction. Pushing and pulling objects in the world, jumping, climbing, all had a great tactile feel to them. The platforming and puzzle solving isn't going to challenge you beyond your patience, but it's just challenging enough to keep you interested and involved in the subtle story being told around you. 

The sound design is another aspect that should be taught in a master class. The minute differences between footsteps as you run on mud or loose gravel to the soft pitter-patter of footsteps on wet concrete, all have a natural realistic feel. Every sound is as it should be. And the way the environments play with the acoustics of each sound element is chilling and immersive. 

Inside is a short game, but it is definitely worth the purchase. It's creepy and disturbing, and leaves you with eerie imagery that stick with you forever.  

It's hard to put into words how a game like Inside goes above and beyond. Implementing such care and attention to detail, and it simply must be played to understand the meaning of the game, as an art piece, or a day-in-the-life of a  young protagonist trying to survive this parallel dystopian universe. It's all so damn beautiful and carefully crafted. Definite Orwellian 1984 vibes play-out in the environments and the mood.

In my opinion, Inside should be placed in the Video Game Hall of Fame for it's beautiful attention to detail and silky smooth execution.

My only gripe with this is it's barely a video game, it mostly plays itself, since the puzzles are piece of cake for the most part (though done for pacing purposes), you can't really get stuck or lost. Admittedly, if you want slightly deeper gameplay, there are secrets sprinkled throughout the game and they require straying off the beaten path (going left instead of right, most of the time) and stop for a minute to think about some of them.

"Inside" makes no bones about what it seeks to be: an evolution of the ideas first presented in "Limbo". Playdead took the notions from their debut and further expanded upon them, making an output that feels more polished and actually much more enjoyable. It's an economical game that is eerie, surreal and immersive, if also not perfect.

Like its predecessor, "Inside" is a side-scroller, and you move to the right for most of the time. The world however is now rendered in 3D, which conveys better the places you're at. Environments can also directly interact with the player, in that some characters in the world may break from the background and come after you. The game is minimalist in almost every aspect: the music, the faceless models, the visuals, the plot, and most importantly, the controls: you only use the arrow keys to move, and right control to grab objects. There are some underwater sections, as well as a couple of vehicles, and this game pulls all of that nicely.

You encounter different kinds of obstacles - some of them will obligate you to further explore your surroundings. But the game has the same issue of "Limbo", which is to punish players for doing something wrong, except that we may not even know what we're doing wrong. You walk into a place, die, and then you have to observe what you did, so you won't die again. If this trial-and-error was something that would happen sometimes, that would be tolerable, but it's a core element of the gameplay: so often, I would die again and again, until I learned what I would have to do. And it would get to the point of frustration.

Let's compare this to a more successful example of puzzle design: "Half-Life". In that game, players would come across these situations in which they would have to read the room to figure what to do, and where to go. Sometimes, players would have to do some experiments with the environments and the tools at their disposal, but very rarely those would be situations that would outright kill the players if they did something wrong. The game would also sometimes give players a visual hint of what to do or what to avoid.

On the other hand, "Inside" has these puzzles that, even after I figured them out, I would often feel bummed out with the way the game treated me, instead of feeling triumphant. Of course that many puzzles are clear at first: if you're sneaking in the woods and there are some guards walking by, you wait for them to clear off. If a massive door opens and people start walking in, you have to wait behind a crate instead of dragging it. If there are massive shock waves that can destroy things, you seek shelter from them. But at one point, there were these sirens that followed me underwater, and dealing with them was very annoying, for I had to die to learn what to do.

The game has this unbroken progression of events, and the places seamlessly lead to one another - it reminded me of "Far: Lone Sails". There are these moments when I had long walks in large ambients, without much happening, which I guess were these moments of ma for players to absorb the scenarios and try to put together what's going on. The game escalates into the final stretch, which is at the same time disturbing, absurd, grotesque and even a bit funny, almost as if it belonged to a David Lynch movie. I don't mean to spoil anything, but I'll say this much: at the closing chapters, I felt the puzzles were much more well designed, ditching the punitive nature of previous puzzles.

At one point, you'll see these zombie-like humans that can be controlled with mind-controlling helmets, and at some points, these zombies will even follow you, stumbling around and helping you to jump longer and higher, breaking your falls by grabbing you (and I have to say: those guys are so wholesome).

Like in "Limbo", it has secrets for players to uncover, which are these hidden orbs that need to be unplugged - in fact, all the achievements in this game are about them, the 14 of them. Some are actually fairly easy to find if you don't mind going the other way, but as you move forward, these secrets become harder to find. In the end, if you unplug all the orbs, you'll have an alternative ending, which you get by returning to a level.

The game is visually superb: right from the get-go, you can see it's an Unity game. The visuals are simple and greyed out, and the world is bleak and truly dystopian. Because these are not the silhouettes of "Limbo" anymore, the portrayal of deaths is more violent, but not quite distasteful. Which is good, since you may die a lot playing the game - the shock wave death even made me chuckle a little. And speaking of which, the sound design and soundtrack are absolutely spectacular, at tense or calmer moments.

In the end, for all the frustrations I had with "Inside", I really enjoyed my short time playing it - a little over four hours. It is a casual game, but casual games aren't often this deep and unnerving while being so quiet and understated. It really made me feel interested in Playdead's next game, how they'll improve this formula even further, or if they'll try something new altogether. But I learned that their next game will be published by Epic Games, and it most certainly will be an Epic Store exclusive forever.

So have a nice life, Playdead.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. In many regards Inside is a masterpiece. From it's dark minimalist graphics to it's intelligent gameplay.

Inside doesn't hold your hand, does not force upon you a lame story just because every game apparently should have some kind of narrative, even if it's of no importance. Rather it let's you use your imagination to fill in what might be going on.

The lacking of any kind of narrative explanation nor gameplay mechanics fits perfectly with the dark and grim background and the faceless characters. 
The gameplay mechanics are well balanced between being witty yet avoiding frustration. 

This is a must play and worth every penny!

I loved this game. It's very atmospheric, has beautiful graphics and silky smooth physics. The puzzles are not so easy as to be boring but not too difficult to be frustrating. I loved the mystery and suspense in the story, while at the same time I found it a very relaxing game. It was just what I was looking for - a self-contained short-ish game that I could take a few hours out to relax with. I actually enjoyed it so much I played it twice for the secret ending, even though you don't have to play it all the way through to get it.

My only criticism would be that I found the ending(s) a bit lackluster, but it seems to be the type of game that's meant to make you think about its message/meaning rather than be overly showy. Overall, if you like 'Little Nightmares', I think you'll enjoy this game. (Also, I recommend playing it without finding out much about it. It's more fun to watch it all unfold.)

If the task was to create a beautiful looking game with a low texture look, this was a success. The controls are ok. And the premise of the world building isn't bad either. 

The actual world building on the other hand is. Far more tragically the gameplay/puzzle design isn't just amateurish, it's objectively really horrible. Most of the time the puzzles are mundane and failure comes from trying to do something too fast and then you'll have to just be slow about it to get it through. But puzzles where death is required for the game to even explain the puzzle you're trying to solve FOR THE FIRST time is bad game design, just REALLY BAD. That's not learning from your mistakes, that's having shown something for the first time after you've "failed". At the end of my play I looked at a walkthrough just to figure out what the designers had thought of at a couple puzzles that were badly designed in a different way. The first time I let it slip but after the second one I didn't bother continuing as the low quality of the gameplay/puzzle design had sunk deeper than the main character at that point of the game.

10/10

[b]TLDR[/b] Despite the similarities with Limbo, Inside is deeper in narrative and world building, although with less challenging puzzles. [19/20â­, 5hðŸ…, 2/5ðŸ’¡]

[b]Context[/b] Inside is an atmospheric puzzle platformer. At first sight, it looks and feels very similar to its spiritual predecessor [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/48000/?snr=1_1056_1055_1056]Limbo[/url] (and any review will necessarily drawn comparisons). But as the game progresses itâ€™s clear that he devs took a considerably different approach. 

[b]Writing[/b] The game follows a boy in a post-apocalyptic world trying to break into some kind of facility where biological experiments are performed. The storytelling is purely visual, as was the case with Limbo, but here much more context is provided in the background events, allowing the player to piece together some kind of narrative. There are tons of different interpretations online, but I donâ€™t think the game was designed to have answers to everything, and it is better for it.

[b]Aesthetics[/b] The game looks and sounds amazing, working together to build an incredibly tense atmosphere. The design is less abstract than Limbo, but still minimalistic and bleak.

[b]Gameplay[/b] In essence, the mechanics are rather simple, itâ€™s a physics-based platformer, but very smoothly implemented. It is similar to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/48000/?snr=1_1056_1055_1056]Limbo[/url] in that regard, but with less action sequences and precision jumps, which also makes it slightly less challenging. However, these simple mechanics are used in more creative ways and result in some memorable chapters. [spoiler]By mid-game thereâ€™s an amazing sequence chapters (the submarine, the horde of zombies, the blast zone).[/spoiler] Finding the secret areas is harder and requires more out-of-the-box solutions.

You can, and will, die a lot and in varied ways, but youâ€™ll just respawn in a close checkpoint. The game autosaves in each checkpoint. There is no undo but you can restart chapters (although as far as I can tell there are no deadends).

[b]Value[/b] It took me about 5h to complete the game and the achievements [spoiler](including the secret ending)[/spoiler], which is kind of short. There is a single progress slot, but you can revisit previous chapters from the menu. There is an alternative, secret ending. Achievements are related to finding secret areas which involve more challenging puzzles and interesting areas that add to the story. They add up if you revisit chapters, so there is no need for multiple playthroughs. The game is linear, but to me it is replayable just for the experience.

This game is worth every penny! (as long as you buy it on sale!) It has an amazing feel to it and the visual + literal themes are very compelling. Besides the striking beauty and clear intention of every object and color from the foreground to the background, the puzzles are comprehensive and do not feel repetitive - they are meant to teach you a technique that you then expand on, which is fascinating and adds to the buildup of the actual story, which is rich in and of itself. No dialogue means you have to pay a lot of attention to what is going on around you, making the game very immersive. Even though the main character doesn't speak, you start to get a feel for who he is and a sort of connection with him throughout the game. My only complaint I could think of was that the main ending is very open-ended and does kind of feel like the game was cut short - I was actually spamming every key in the small repertoire of keys you CAN use because I thought my game had frozen or glitched and it was just a cutscene. As far as open-ended up-for-interpretation endings go, it's a pretty good one - I'm not going to say anything, but it is pretty poetic to look at and think about. I just wish the game was longer, it took about 3 hours for me to get through the actual game and probably another hour and a half at most for the extra content. I think I got it on sale and I recommend doing that, otherwise you're paying a lot for a game that is more beautiful than it is lengthy. Overall, this is a really good game, and I am so here for puzzle platformers!

Graphics are excellent, sound design is also great. Puzzles are really creative, most are pretty easy but some will have you scratching your head for the solution. Playthrough takes about 5 hours.

If you liked LIMBO and you like platform puzzle games with lots of humour and creativity, you will love this gem of a game.

Inside is a small gem, made by the same developers of Limbo.
The title isn't very long, but it's one of the best 2D adventure/horror games I've ever played. It is very detailed and every second of the game shows how much care they put into making it. The devs thought of some FANTASTIC concept art. They came up with an excellent aesthetic for a game. Apparently they considered that enough, because the gameplay is tedious and the plot is nonexistent. The start of the game is so compelling. You play a mysterious boy running through picturesque moody environments with minimal color, as guards attempt to hunt you down. Who is this boy? Why is he being chased? What happened to him before, and what is his goal? No answers.

And I mean it. No answers. There's the popular trend of games that give only vague hints for a story, requiring you to piece together what happened through anything from item descriptions to environmental storytelling. Some of those games are pretty great, and some consider the experience of piecing it together rewarding. Some hate it, because they think there's no real lore and fantheories aren't a substitute for plot. Turns out, INSIDE is what you get when there's ACTUALLY no lore behind things and it's fully left up to fan theories.

The problem isn't that it's vague. The problem is that a game's ideas should tie together elegantly, and this is true regardless of whether it uses detailed text or vague imagery. If the game stuck with its early ideas and provided a compelling conclusion, then it would have been satisfying. Instead, it introduces idea after idea, until they start to feel like non-sequiturs, complete with an ending so utterly ridiculous that it was hilarious. You can make up explanations for all of it, but that makes you impressive, not the game.

If you look at the wikipedia pages for Dark Souls or Hollow Knight, the plot sections will tell you the actual lore. Lore that might not be obvious to the casual player; a taste of what those fanbases have uncovered. On the other hand, INSIDE's wikipedia page lists a literal play by play of what you do in the game. Because there really isn't anything else to say. The problem here is that the ideas themselves, at least the ones shown early on, are compelling enough to make you WANT to see more. It doesn't have to be a text dump of explanations, but just something that ties back in to the game ideas.

When a game like this gets criticized, the response is often "you just have to be able to appreciate abstract ideas, to piece it together yourself, to take in the worldbuilding rather than need a narrative." I think that's an absolute copout. There are excellent games that fit that description, and those who dislike INSIDE can dislike the execution of that approach, not the fact that it went for it. Having several separate ideas that don't connect or even allude to each other in interesting ways isn't how you make an interesting world, it's how you fail to make one. Being inexplicable is not a virtue; being interesting is, and INSIDE fails to be the latter because it doesn't even treat its own ideas with enough respect to say anything about them, much less treat the player with respect.

You can think of a genius theory that explains everything for, well, anything. I've seen insane fan theories that made Sonic Adventure 2 sound amazing (honestly, look it up, the video is by Khonjin). Of course, no one, much less me, can be an objective judge of what you can or should interpret from a game. But that also means that just because you have a great theory that makes you personally like the game better, doesn't mean it has to be compelling to anyone else. If you love INSIDE and part of the reason you do it because of how much it made you use your imagination, I'm happy for you. But the game itself should be judged on what's there in the game, not what isn't there.

In addition to thinking of art but not a story, they also didn't think of much gameplay. The puzzles aren't awful, but it doesn't develop any of the mechanics far enough to give you real brain benders. I spent more time wandering around not realizing there was a thing I had to interact with, or not realizing where I even had to go, than I actually spent trying to understand the mechanical logic of any puzzles. Deduction and lateral thinking aren't absent, but you wouldn't play this game for them, and they don't offer enough to make the slow running around not annoying.

You know when someone learns a new word and uses it way too much and it annoys everyone? I'm being that bish right now. I watched that new-ish Matthewmatosis video about Context Sensitivity recently and it blew my mind on how much it actually defines the feel of a game. Everyone know the general idea but when you really break down the difference between games that rely on it hard and games that don't, it's night and day. Of course, neither approach is technically bad, but I have my preferences, and I'm about to explain why that's relevant: There's an annoying amount of context sensitivity in INSIDE. Jumping means jumping, at least most of the time, but the Grab button is used for way too much. The uses are varied enough that you don't really think about grabbing things as a physical act, but rather have to conceive of it as a more general "interact" that relies more on the vague intuitive idea of how a game wants you to use something than it does the physical act you're having the character perform. This doesn't like, kill the game, in the way that having a nonsense and unsatisfying story does, but it was a frequent annoyance, to have a larger mental gap between controls and actions than I'd prefer, that contributed to the gameplay feeling uninspired and unengaging.

Anyway, idk, 5/10, not really worth your time unless you love the visuals so much that you'll play anything for them alone. Personally, I feel like the visuals tricked me into expecting more.
Loved the design and storytelling, with ultimately a criptic message about humanity that you have to decipher fotr yourself which is very healthy. The last hour is amazing.

It's fine. I don't think it deserves all of the praise it gets, however. It's about a 3 hour long game with easy puzzles. I heard the game was a narrative masterpiece before playing, but it's more of a 2.5 dimensional art project that challenges you to figure out what's going on in the story at all times. If you're into having a different interpretation than everyone else about what is really happening in front of your face then you're going to like this, I just wouldn't call that good narrative design, personally speaking. 

If I had a choice, I would pay $10 for a short, but sweet, atmospheric and low-stress experience with headphones on for the immersive sound that Inside provides. I'm looking forward to Playdead's next game.

Incredible storytelling. It's basically a walking simulator with moderately difficult puzzles at best. Zero dialogue or explanation. You're just bungling along, trying to figure out what fucked up thing is happening in this dark, twisted world you're stuck in. Don't get caught by dogs, humans, or weird creatures in human-like form. The last 15 minutes of the game had me smiling wickedly and muttering to myself, "This is the most grotesque thing I may have ever played." As a huge fan of puzzle platformers, I can definitely mark this among the top for its immersive quality alone. 10/10 Hurrah!

Gorgeous and an absolute master class in building a world without saying a word. Full of tense moments and creepy bewilderment. Clearly a lot of time went into the design and aesthetic. 

I am aching to know more about what the heck is going on, [spoiler]but any kind of explanation for the genocide, abandoned urban decay, and human experimentation can't possibly match whatever conspiracy one can come up with in their head. Any explanation would make it mundane, boring. It would bring rules to the world and apply limits to what could possibly happen next.

However, I suspect there ISN'T an in-world explanation. I suspect this whole game, and the whole journey of the protagonist, is symbolic - and thus the world doesn't make any logical sense, and it's not supposed to.
What is it symbolic of? Well, I have my theories, but frankly I have no real idea, and I don't think anybody else does either.
I'd love for the developers drop some hints or confirm/deny fan theories, but I'm not holding my breath.[/spoiler]

As a game, it's a bit rough. Bounding boxes are large - plenty of times I've had enemies shoot me through walls [spoiler]or grab me while clearly outside the water (if you've played it, you know exactly who I'm talking about)[/spoiler]. Some of the puzzles have unforgiving timing or require precision maneuvering. I suppose this is to ratchet up the drama/blood pressure, but having to redo a puzzle a dozen times because I couldn't get the timing down is more frustrating than fun. The protagonist is slow and stumbles about, will cheerfully drop off ropes and handles without warning, and run right off into voids at the slightest button press.

That said, gameplay isn't the point at all. This isn't CS:GO - the point is the world and the story, not having hyper-tuned mechanics for maximum control. Even when you're just riding an elevator, the state of the world around you is whispering history and events.

Is it worth a play-through? Absolutely. Put on the headphones and turn down the lights for the maximum experience.
[spoiler]Most people will be able to complete it in one or two sittings, depending on their tolerance to frustration. There is zero practical replay value.[/spoiler]

In 2016 I was working at a grocery store while taking classes at the local community college. It was the kind of place that attracted older people. You know, a place that is small enough for an old barnacle to get around but large enough to get everything you need on your shopping list. The place had a few managers at the time, one of them a 50+ y/o guy called Pat. Pat was the kind of guy who loved to tell you about the sports cars he owned and never passed up an opportunity to explain to someone how car companies design their vehicles to make the light dance across their cool red and blue bodies. I was standing there in the summer heat one day, looking at the car with Pat as he explained how this worked - he had me walk around the car and see the light effect in action ('Pretty cool, Pat' I would say). I'm not a car person. The only car I've ever had some kind of affinity for is my late dad's 280Z Datsun. It don't like it very much anymore after my brother replaced all its parts, cut it up and turned it into an over sized RC car. Anyway, I'm standing there with Pat while he talks about the history of automotive aerodynamics and I'm itching to get home to play INSIDE. I played the first half of INSIDE before going to work one day and finished it when I returned home. A couple of months later I went to a friend's house for a party and talked about the game with someone I'd known in passing from high school. She was pretty cool.
A joy to play with its clever gameplay, compelling narrative and beautiful visuals.

Playdead's "Inside" has breath taking visuals, great art direction, awesome character animation, amazing sound and level design. I found that compared to the previous game Limbo(previous installment by Playdead studio), though the puzzles were challenging, it doesn't take much time to figure them out and finish the game in one entire seating. I felt that this game has an overall darker( includes blood and more gruesome ways to die )theme than the previous one. It's smart use of camera angles, playful mix of shadows and lights throughout, pushes you to pause take a breath, move the character around a bit, record and take a screenshot.

Some small nits and picks which i believe could have made the game slightly better. 

When picking up boxes and activating "rocket boxes" i believe the animation interaction and response time when trying to select a box and gearing it up to launch was a bit annoying, Sometimes I'd wind up climbing the box and loose time trying to bend down and activate it making it more irritable,

The same problem takes place when trying to enter or exit through small openings or where you have to select (on mac it's the shift button), hold and launch(don't wanna reveal spoilers)

The story of this game always leaves you wanting more, so I'm not sure how players will feel after they finish this game. I haven't played Limbo in years (even though I enjoyed it so much ). The initial urge and curiosity to quickly ace through the puzzles sans perfection dies slowly once you complete it and get to the finish line to see what happens.

Overall I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who likes puzzles(not too hard), dark humor, a bit of survival horror, game as a blend of great art and engineering and also wants to finish this game the same day.

The gameplay is subpar, even compared to LIMBO, the gameplay and puzzles are subpar. Most of the beginning of the game is being chased, with a lot of it being trial and error. You won't know the truck shoots you, or the branch on the ground trips you. The best parts of the game are with the mind control puzzles and those are a shockingly small section of the game. INSIDE does at least try to change the formula but "threat management" becomes 50% of the game instead, which is just as annoying. Hide from x, do thing, hide from x, repeat. It was tedious the second time, because the threat has been dealt with, its just annoying.
Then you get weird and totally random bullshit like why does the girl not kill you after one specific part? If you're caught any time before you die, but when you're forced to be caught she... Ya know what, its not explained why the girl suddenly gives you the ability to breathe underwater. It's just ~~SHOCKING~~ because "oh look!!! its nothing!"

The ending is terrible, its made entirely for the shock value, the alternate ending is even worse because it makes even less sense.

I think I explained my opinions on this game by just saying: "Oh look! Its nothing!"

This game is worth 5$, nothing more.

The game wanted to be a "story rich adventure game with puzzles and some horrors" but it failed. 

Compared to Limbo this is just a mediocre, boring game without a proper story and good puzzles.

I was expecting a simple puzzle platformer. I was not expecting such great world building and storytelling. 

While the ambience and backdrops tell a lot about the world, much of the backstory is revealed by the puzzles themselves in a way that I haven't been able to appreciate since the Portal series. Inside is littered with easy-to-miss details that will answer some questions, but raise many more. 

It's a game that is okay with leaving some loose ends and room for interpretation. If done incorrectly, this can come off as pretentious or lazy, but it was executed perfectly in this case. 

Inside allowed me to re-experience what it was like to play Limbo for the first time. The game was the perfect length and I just loved it.

[b]*First playthrough completed in about 3,5 hours.
**Achievement notes at the end of this review.[/b]

INSIDE checks the boxes for me after having played LIMBO. What its predecessor seemingly tried to achieve, this game succeeded at greatly. I'll be comparing this game to that experience a bit here - it may sort of double as a review for that game as well.

In a nutshell; is a short, linear puzzle platformer with low difficulty and an atmospheric world featuring an unspoken story.
The atmosphere being sad, intimidating, hopelessness and such fun things.

For the general story and experience, the two games start off very differently despite looking similar. Boy slides into screen and off you go, travelling mostly along a single axis and taking in the minimalistic scenery. But where one starts off in LIMBO and it's essentially a simple from-A-to-B experience with obstacles along the way, INSIDE actually makes you feel like you're (among other things) a little underaged detective.
From beginning to end you bear witness to scenes that may tell you what's happening. Wether or not it'll all make sense in the end remains to be seen until you actually get there, ofcourse. But there's certainly a lot more to it than "Where is person X? Oh look, person X is on the far right end of this game".

The puzzles then. Cue a collective "yeah, duh" here as I say that this was the most important thing to me that I wanted to see improved after the first game. Where LIMBO seemed to want to punish players for progressing by introducing tedious puzzles to them that required nearly impeccable timing to avoid death in, INSIDE instead looks to reward players who can turn off the overthinking part of their brain and see the simple but clever solutions to its puzzles. There's plenty of opportunities for fatalities but not only so. Not every puzzle has you getting cut up or crushed on failure.

While I appreciated the elements of physics that LIMBO incorporated into the puzzles, the whole game (after the starting levels) just felt like nothing more than a series of painful tests chained together to never really give you a breather or a sense of accomplishment. Too many times a puzzle was retried because one element of it was off by half a second.
INSIDE is a little more forgiving and relies more on, as said above, not overthinking solutions.

This leads to internal reactions of "Hah, ofcourse! How did I not think of that before?" rather than "Feck sake, I figured this puzzle out 10 attempts ago but I'm still dying because I keep grazing that random sawblade". That may be a poor description but you'll know what I mean when (not if, right?) you play this game. It made me actually appreciate and enjoy the puzzles. Like I said, there's generally a low difficulty but due to HOW the game challenges you, it remains a satisfying experience. And with the addition of new mechanics and interactions, INSIDE knocks it out of the park here.

As for atmosphere, LIMBO with its basic black, white and grey colour scheme was totally fine in my opinion. But it became rather bland after a while with the punishing puzzles just making me feel like a lab rat getting shocked all the time by evil scientists. With INSIDE there's a little more room for the player to marvel at the surroundings. The scope of the facilities, the events, the possible storyline/plot and the interactive experience of the player with the environment and other creatures.

Last but certainly not least important: [u][b]it's short![/b][/u] As a casual player I got through the first game in about four hours, stubbornly throwing myself against lethal objects just to force myself to figure out solutions and timings. This game I beat (finding just a couple of the achievement-linked secrets) in about 3,5 hours. Lots of adult gamers with limited time to play will appreciate finding a game that's actually good, satisfying to play and finished quickly - a session or two depending on your daily/weekly game time. Looking to slowly clear out your backlog? Install this one today, you won't regret it.

In short, PLAYDEAD had a concept for LIMBO and I liked the idea but did not enjoy the execution of it. Then they made INSIDE and fulfilled the expectation that I had in playing the first game. I'm happy to put this game in my personal 'gems' category where it belongs.

[b]**Achievements:[/b] the only achievements are for finding the individual secrets. They are cleverly hidden but easy to find if you keep your eyes peeled and explore a bit. Thanks to the chapter selection you can easily load any specific section of the game so there's no need for full re-playthroughs if you missed any. A guide/walkthrough is not needed and they do not need to be found in order or in a single playthrough.
Spoiler tagged hint to help find them: [spoiler]yellow cables indicate the presence of a secret and will often lead you to them. Some secrets have long hidden paths and others are close to the main path.[/spoiler]

Tip for PC players: 
You might run into a pretty common bug at the beginning of the game. If you find that you can't "grab" (push) a refrigerator in the woods, try this: press "Esc", then choose "settings", then "keyboard". There, bind "Grab" to a to a different key on your keyboard than the default setting. This is what worked for me, anyway.

[h1]8.5/10[/h1]

[i]Now this is pure art, and I'm in absolute awe. LIMBO was something unique, unusual, and pretty simple (in its design and story, of course). Minimalistic, yet stylish. Frustrating, but enjoyable. One hell of an experience. INSIDE takes it all, then makes it perfect. One of a kind, remarkable, ingeniously designed. Unforgettable, exquisite, engrossing, fascinating. Playdead's games are so vague, subtle, and arthouse-like, that there has to be a new genre already, just like Rogue, Metroid&Castlevania, and Demon's Souls got theirs. Now I simply can't wait for Playdead's next project.[/i]

In the shadows of old factories, the mindless hordes stumble through their exercises. Their bodies are not their own, their faces blank, their clothing grey and molded over. When told to jump, they jump; when told to spin, they spin. Within the horde, a boy does his best to stay in time. Ahead? Unknown. All the boy knows is that he must find his next solution, must escape what lingers behind, search for what awaits beyond. Nothing will be quite as alive as him ever again.

Man, what can I say..? 
Going into this game I only knew it was the the successor to LIMBO which I also enjoyed, the 2d theme puzzle plat-former. Although, unlike LIMBO, there seemed to be something more going on here. There is no obvious story line, but it puts you into a world where you discover a dystopian world and get to find out more about it all while interacting with it and risking getting caught by things that are hunting you. The 2d/3d feel of the game along with its art style really made it rather enjoyable and definitely satisfied my hunger for a game that provides challenging puzzles along with suspense and awe.
The only complaint I have with the game is the ending, it leaves much to be desired. I wont spoil anything but i hope to see a second game as a continuation.

Spoiler free short review:

Game good. Game short. You did read other reviews, right? Then shut up and play this game already.





Not spoiler free not short review:

Inside is a beautiful game with both great artstyle and intriguing designed world, story, great puzzles and very good set pieces.
The game is short and sweet so it doesn't overstate its welcome. 
It takes around 4-5 hours to finish and I simple adore the Lovecraftian style ending.

I don't have much negative stuff to say about the game. The game was perfectly balanced in term of puzzle challenge and didn't had any particular annoying moments or bugs.
What I have is couple of personal nitpicks. 

The game is trying to be creepy but I say it could go even further with that concept. 
For example more weird creatures, especially lurking inside water.
Same thing with stuff in the background. Some extra glowing eyes, moving shadows, shapes would be nice there.

Secret ending is stupidly cryptic and hidden not in fun way to unlock it on your own. 
It's basically "press left or right or up button in right order" type "puzzle" except it's based around fart sound effects coming out of tape and password is hidden in the most random location in the game that no way any average player would even GUESS the real purpose of it while playing the game.

Also this password is always fixed for every single player. 
I think it would be way cooler if password was more randomized.

Achievement descriptions are not enough helpful in finding collectibles. First few was ok but the further you go with the game the worse it gets.

99,9% of players won't even know secret ending exist without reading about it on the internet and 99,9% won't even bother replaying entire game and scrapping every single locations for hours and hours in hope of finding collectibles on their own resulting in simple looking at guides on the internet. 

That is indeed a terrible game design. 
Fun hidden secrets are one thing, cryptic stuff is another but the game litteraly gives you ABSOLUTE ZERO reasons to even search for those on your own without proper hints. 
Yeah, there is sometimes that yellow cable as a hint but more often it's not there or well visible and replaying the entire game just for those is beyond tedious thing to do.





My idea for fixing that huge issue mentioned above:
Inside have pretty deep checkpoint loading system which displayes images of location sometimes related to achievement (sometimes not sadly) and stuff. 
Checkpoints are displayed in a form of small red squares. 

So to hint collectibles locations with them would be displayed as you progress the first playthrough in a form of slightly bigger empty golden squares without filling and collecting the thing fills the square with gold filling (gold because it symbolize a light).

When you beat the game for the first time a new, final big square appears showing you the location of final collectible, allowing you to access the room with it (in the game you can enter it at any time) and just like in the game you need to light all previous lights (aka golden fillings) on wall to get final collectible. 

Collecting the final one display now big panel on the wall with mysterious text hinting the player where to go (aka in game location of secret ending) something like:

"to preserve your incoming doom,
seek the location of red room"

A location that player probably already visited in the past, nearby one of early collectibles.
Right next to this text would be a up/left/right password combination that is fully randomized everytime a player starts a fresh new game or press "reset game progress" in options.

In my honest opinion doing this would encourage players to seek those collectibles and secret ending on their own instead of them instantly searching the internet for guides because this is a simple result in creating over complicated cryptic collectibles.

People most of the time WANT to get 100% or to see extra puzzles/content or endings. 
That is normal gamer brain nature.

BUT even tho the game is short, people don't want to spend hours and hours and hours on replaying the game on their own to find those thigs without even knowing if its where, there or not. 

That's why developers should put more effort in hinting those locations to encourage players in searching for them because if the player knows that instead of searching the entire game for one or two collectibles all they need to do is to search those specific locations it makes them more willingly to do so on their own.

Such a beautifully unique and interesting game.

Incredibly simple and incredibly short, but packs in a whole load of personality and some really creative puzzles. I thoroughly enjoyed the puzzles, despite none of them causing too many issues or leaning into tedium.

The game really doesn't overstay its welcome - by the end I had enjoyed what it had, but was also ready for it to be over. For that reason (and because it has very little replay value) I'd say you should definitely get this on sale.

Some horror stories are told through jumpscares and eerie atmosphere, This game doesn't have jumpscares or insanely creepy atmosphere but still does a great job at stealth puzzle/platformer! Some stealth games can be cumbersome, but stealth isnt the main focus of the game. Just get while its on sale and you'll thoroughly enjoy this game if you like platformers. Give it a try! Takes about 4-5 hours to complete on a casual play through

I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game! I loved how you were just being thrown into the game, no explanations of controles or whatever, you just had to figure things out by yourself, including the storyline. Very creepy vibes throughout the game, very atmospheric - it somehow reminded me of Little Nightmares (which is probably one of my favourite games).
Without saying too much, the puzzles are mostly straight forward, but a few of them definitely took a lot of thinking and brainpower xD
If you are an achievement hunter like me (/completionist) - pro tip â†’ you cannot get the last achievement without unlocking the previous ones, BUT you can load the chapters to find the collectibles that you are missing, and then loading the chapter where you find the last one - this worked for me, and I got them all!
Will definitely recommend, and will look forward to replaying this game again sometime in the future!

Wow, what an experience.

This is indeed a perfect example of insanely accurate planning and execution. A game which serves as a workshop itself for gamers and developers on how to create a complete, unique and distinct adventure.

My advice would be to not read this review and to just play.
If you're interested you can find the first minutes of gameplay to ease up your mind on my channel (where I upload the first minutes of the games I review): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5W5UDWw5IGY

If you want to learn more, I'll explore some aspects below without telling much of the story.

[h3]Oppressed[/h3]
This word comes to mind when you start. 
If you've ever played Little Nightmares, you'll probably find some recognizable patterns in this game's pacing. 
With that said, Inside manages to bring the atmosphere and sense of stake to the next level, resulting somewhat more original and oppressing.

I can't quite put my finger on it: it may be the desaturated tone, the neverending silence, the masterfully created ambiance. I don't know, but there's a constant sense of danger and discovery which instantly sets you in the right mood.

[h3]Creative Physics[/h3]
Throughout the game you'll come across different type of puzzles, and even though they're really not that difficult, they surely are creative and make you appreciate the effort. I would say that creativeness has been more of a focus rather than difficulty. In fact, everything runs smoothly and rewards you for thinking simple patterns. 

What's interesting is how characters' animations and movements were made. Particularly your character, the child. There's a sense of heaviness and naturality to movements when actions are performed, and it allows for a more immersive and "desperate" feel to your constant run towards your objective. 

That combined with the use of "inverted" water physics made for an unique environmental experience, even though I would've appreciated more of that (even though I prefer to have less quality experiences than more average ones).

[h3]The Sound Of Silence[/h3]
It really baffles me that the "silentness" of Inside is what makes it great. Sound direction is so on point, well layered, dark and heavy that it makes for half the experience. Just hearing the world around you and the strangeness that comes through it is enough to make you invested. 

Even though it may be simple at times, this game's ambiance is unbelievably layered. Some ideas excited me for their originality. Really, really good.

Other than that, you won't hear a single line of dialogue while playing. I'm constantly repeating myself in my reviews, but this subjectively makes for the best experience one could ask for. You've got a world which makes itself believable and interesting without a single explanation. Everything is there and what you see is enough to draw your own conclusions. Inside is just that: there's no menu, no introduction, anything. It's just you, the player, experiencing a slice of time in the bigger picture that is Inside. 

[h2]Closing thoughts[/h2]
Inside isn't a long game. In fact, it'll probably take you roughly 3-4 hours to complete (that is if you walk around and explore with a slow pacing). But it is so intense that you won't be bothered by that at all.

I'm kinda sad that Epic will be Playdead's publisher in the future: this game is the perfect example of creative freedom with a powerful message and clearly shows the developers' intentions all the way through. I hope they'll still manage to surprise us. Funny enough, given Inside's overall meaning, it's interesting to see Playdead being funded and aided by Epic. On a further note, though, publishing games by yourself is hard and can lead to uncertainty on the economic side, so it's no wonder they went this route. I'm eager to see their next project.

With that said, this is an amazing example of what Unity is capable of and, from a developer point of view, the amount of character they managed to squeeze into Inside is really remarkable. Truly one of the best games I've ever played, and it'll be remembered fondly.

Play this game, you won't regret it.

TLDR: I got this game on sale for â‚¬1,99. I've never been so glad I didn't pay full price for a game

I went in blind, I knew nothing about this game. I saw it on sale and I gave it a chance. 
First impressions were alright, the game is nice to look at and I enjoyed the atmosphere and overall sound design. 
...aaaand I ran out of positive things to say. 


I can't state this enough though, it took me less than 3 hours to beat this game from start to finish (Not rushing it, I definitely took my time), and I was obscenely bored through the entire duration of it... let me explain

I never felt challenged during any of the puzzles the game throws at you. Most of them are trial and error, or so intuitive calling them "puzzles" is generous. Even then, most of the best puzzles this game has are repetitive and tedious.
I won't spoil any of the story but I felt my time had been wasted in the end, I felt it was pointless and ambiguous. 

I didn't absolutely hate inside, but I definitely didn't enjoy it. I think it's worth a buck or two, but I would've been pretty mad had I paid full price for this.
Most of what you're going to be doing is holding right on your keyboard while waiting for something interesting to happen. Also the fact that the default movement is set to the arrow keys instead of WASD was an instant slap in the face, forcing me to remap the controls to my left hand instead for comfort and muscle memory. 

I would honestly tell you to spare yourself playing this UNLESS you find it on a huge sale. 
Inside felt like a chore. I felt the game was wasting my time as I was playing it, which is interesting given how short it was. 
It is aesthetically interesting (mind you, not mindblowing), but not worth its full price.

I have been told Little Nightmares does Inside better than Inside, so go play that instead.

I can understand why this game gets such overwhelming positive reviews, but to me the atmosphere is lost to the poorly handled puzzle aspects of the game. This is my critique of Inside (no spoilers).

Inside is the story of survival of a young boy against all odds - physical barriers, dogs, people, and other such adversaries in the game. The gameplay against this narrative comes in 3 flavours, which the game rotates through as you play: escaping adversity, puzzle solving, and spectacle.

Spectacle I have no aversion to - the game nails its art style and atmosphere, and is thoroughly enjoyable eye candy. Sometimes the sections felt a little long to me, but I typically play more action intensive games, so this isn't a great surprise.

Both escaping adversity and puzzle solving are entirely mechanically devoid - that is to say that the challenge isn't knowing what to do and struggling to do it, it's not knowing what to do, but once you work it out it's relatively trivial to pull off. There's nothing wrong with this, it just means the game places its difficulty/challenge in the solution finding. This is important.

The character controls comes across rather out of place in a lot of the escaping adversity sections of the game, where the boy moves at a comfortable jog / light run, despite having a ferocious dog running full pelt behind you with clear intent to kill. This can feel frustrating, because if you don't quite have the solution to the puzzle (but you're most of the way there), it feels like you probably could have survived if the protagonist just put a littttle bit more effort in.This bring me onto the main thing I disliked about these escaping adversity sections in general: they require trial & death to overcome. In my opinion, putting a time limit on solving a puzzle when your life is at stake is not fun, and it's the core mechanic of these parts of the game. It damages immersion in my opinion and makes solving the problems not feel rewarding.

To talk more generally about the puzzles (this also applies to escaping adversity), they are not designed to facilitate first time success / improvised success. Timing windows are narrow where present, and the game does nothing to help or guide the player (hell, it doesn't even tell you the controls when you start playing). In dedicated puzzle sections (those with no imminent threat of death), performing the necessary trial and error ends up being time consuming and slow, primarily due to the size of the environments and how slow your character moves.

The final nit I'll pick with Inside is the size of the environments. Especially frequent during the spectacle sections, you can end up without a clear indication of where you need to go, and thus simply have to run in one direction until you find a wall, and then turn around. The game's achievements lead me to believe there are more secrets hidden throughout the levels, however more often than not I found myself having explored the 'wrong' way intentionally to no reward other than the boring return journey. The game actively feels like it's trying to dis-incentivise this 'explore the other way first' style of play.

To conclude, I did complete the game and enjoy it's ending. I didn't feel overly compelled by the story due to it's obscurity, and was more than ready to be done with the puzzles by the time I got to the end - and that's for a short 3.5 hour game.

Overall experience is a 8/8.5 out of 10. The puzzles are difficult but not to hard to complete spending 30 minutes on one. The lack of speaking in the game really makes you create your own scenarios of what you think is going on and leads for endless possibilities. Short game play 100% at 2.4 hours I would strongly only recommend buying when on sale.

Inside is a short but atmospheric 2d platformer/puzzler. You can move left, right, jump, go up and down and grab objects. Puzzles are fairly simple environmentally based, not difficult to complete the puzzles without a guide; some may require good timing or a bit more thought but there's no crazy logic required for anything. Some of the secrets can be hard to find through. The game world is quite dystopian with your child character creeping around trying to avoid capture at various points. There's zero dialogue in the game, mostly atmosphere and themes than an actual real story. The backgrounds are quite nice and you'll run through forests, farms, labs, etc. There's quite a few water sections, IGN would probably hate this game lol.

A few things Iâ€™d say I can complain about (again, maybe not faults in and of themselves, but when look at side-by-side comparison with Limbo):
- Limbo has dozens of gruesome ways to die and it was super cool. Not so much here. I mean there are a few spectacular and grueling scenes, but not as many.
- Overall, puzzles are much simpler. Much closer to â€œfigure out how this mechanics workâ€, rather than Limboâ€™s â€œhit a perfect timingâ€. If Limbo had to be â€œbeatenâ€ (that <5 deaths achievement was real), INSIDE is rather â€œwalked throughâ€â€¦
- That plot twist that happens closer to the end of the game (you know it when you see it)... I donâ€™t knowâ€¦ Creative, for sureâ€¦ But it feels totally out of character, (being small and helpless in a hostile world)â€¦

Anyhow, it was a fun and memorable experience. Thumbs up!

Alright, where to start.

I guess i should first say that if you for some reason haven't seen or played Playdead's first game, "Limbo", you should really check it out, very similar to the structure Inside has, just going 6 years back in time since Inside's release.

I have a couple of things to say about this game, and i really did not structure this review whatsoever so i'm just going to spill everything how it is on my mind, the first thing i would like to say is that Inside beyond being just a 2.5D platformer is an experience that i would recommend to literally anyone, seriously, if you're checking out this game, buy it, the most interesting thing about this game without any doubt is it's visual story telling, i love how the misterious events of the game unfold on the background, leaving the player to think about what's really happening in the world around our misterious red shirt friend, the more you advance the more questions you will have up in your head, questions with no specific answer, the person playing formulates a meaning to the story of their own thought, which is a charm that i adore of this game.

I sometimes even forgot i was playing a somewhat conventional platformer, which speaking about platformers i also want to dive a bit into gameplay, Inside is a somewhat conventional platformer, however it does play a bit with it's own physics engine, introducing a couple of mechanics that are fun and keep the game interesting, fun and overall enjoyable, due to the game being relatively short, the player won't reach a limit where the mechanics get old and repetitive, keeping it's core gameplay fresh.

The last aspect of inside that i really want to talk about is it's visuals, in all honestly this game looks absolutely beautiful, i don't know how Playdead did it but this game is so aesthetically pleasing, every scenario in this game looks like it's been polished several times to look so gorgeous, real and organic.

So yeah this game is pretty god damn good, recommend buying it on a discount, but i mean i would still buy it at full price no prob.

[h1] Good, not Great [/h1]

I'm going to be very honest in this review, I have no idea why this game has as many 10/10's and "Masterpiece" ratings that it does. It definitely has some good going for it don't get me wrong, I am recommending it after all (only on a sale though), but there are some very obvious flaws and things that are so underdeveloped or basic that I'm shocked at how high the metacritic score for this game is. At the same time though, the atmosphere and setting are very, very, very well done. They absolutely carry this game from start to end, and I imagine it's why INSIDE has the scores that it does. I can absolutely see people overlooking its shortcomings and focusing only on the atmosphere the game creates. On top of this, the ending of the game is absolutely the best part of the game and is quite fantastic to be fair. Ending on such a high also probably contributes to the high scores but nonetheless, let''s go a bit more in depth to the different aspects of INSIDE.

[h1] Presentation [/h1]

The best part of INSIDE is absolutely its presentation. The world you travel through is dark and mysterious. Very rarely will a bright color appear on screen, and it absolutely nails the mood its going for. The game takes place on a 2D plane but there's fantastic depth to the settings and backdrops. you can see people in the background, and at times the camera will change its angle revealing more of the world, reminding you just how tiny and defenseless you are in this world. The death scenes are long, drawn out, and filled with gore. When you die you really do feel as if you've been brutally murdered, with no hesitation or remorse. The lighting is for the most part very nice as well. At times it did seem to be a little too dark, making things hard to see but this was rare and never impacted gameplay too much. Sound wise, there is very little music, while I understand why they went this route, in order to really make you feel truly alone in this world, there were definitely times where I think some light atmospheric music could have gone a long way. The sound effects such as bones snapping, glass shattering, and dogs barking at you are all extremely well done and add a lot to the game. The game looks and sounds incredible.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

This is where a lot of people may disagree with me but I'm not here to please everyone, I'm here to be honest. The first 2/3 of this game are an absolute bore. First of all the movement speed is soooo slow. It feels like it takes forever to get anywhere in this game, which isn't helped by the fact that there are long stretches of walking in this game. These honestly feel like they are just here to pad out the time spent playing the game, since to be fair there's probably only about an hours worth of quality content in INSIDE and that might be pushing it to be honest. Up until the final few chapters the puzzles are so simplistic and underdeveloped that they might as well just not exist. I can't think of a single puzzle in the beginning of the game that I thought was worth my time. Luckily, as the game progresses the puzzles do get better, and by the end there are a few quality puzzles that while still weren't amazing or anything special were fine enough to not bother me. Unfortunately quite a few puzzles are recycled multiple times, and these are also some of the longer puzzles to do. They often involve running back and forth to avoid animals or staying in the  shadows to avoid light. These tend to be the weaker of the puzzles which makes them being repeated more frustrating. There are some secret collectibles scattered throughout the game to be found, and some of these are quite well hidden so there is some replayability if you look for that. Overall for a puzzle game, it mostly falls short for me. For a $20 game I would hope for a lot more puzzles, and for those puzzles to be of higher quality. At times you can really see the developers start to get creative and have some new ideas but these moments are far too rare sadly. Having said this I don't think the gameplay was the developers main priority. I think that honor would go to the story which we'll talk about next. 

[h2] Story [/h2]

There isn't one.


Ok for real though, INSIDE is one of those games that doesn't tell you anything. There isn't a single line of dialogue in this game, spoken or written. Telling an effective story like this is incredibly difficult, and ultimately I don't think INSIDE succeeds in this. Anything resembling a story is so loose and flimsy that you can watch 10 videos on Youtube explaining the meaning of the whole game and they could all be saying something completely different (I'm not joking, if you play the game and can't figure it out look up these videos on Youtube, each one is saying something different). Perhaps this is the whole point of INSIDE. That it's all open to interpretation and there is no one correct answer. If that's true than that's some bullsh!t. If this was a 3 dollar game that lasted an hour than sure, I can see it working. But it isn't. This is a $20 game full of filler because the developers couldn't come up with an actual story so they put together a vague outline of a vague story and filled it with beautiful scenery and a memorable ending so that the internet would start talking about it and make the game go viral. And it worked perfectly. If you enjoy vague stories that are incredibly open to interpretation than this is the perfect game for you. Unfortunately for me I prefer my stories to be actually stories with dialogue and that make sense. How you want to consume your video game stories will be the number 1 decider I think for if you enjoy this game or not. 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2] 

Ultimately, this game is all right. If you can get it on a good sale than go for it. It's fine enough for a couple bucks and has some good world building. Don't buy this expecting a great puzzle game though. There's more filler here than a Disney live action remake and the story is about as well done as one too. This game is in no way a masterpiece or the perfect 10/10 game people claim it is so don't go into it expecting that. There was a lot of potential here but the shortcomings prevent it from reaching the heights of other great games. If it looks interesting, wait for a sale. For more reviews, follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40795588/] curator page. [/url]

INSIDE was released a year earlier than Little Nightmares, but I've played Little Nightmares first. Still, I can't help but think that I could copy-paste most of my review of Little Nightmares for this game. Both games are truly great story rich games but somehow INSIDE stood out a bit more for me. It reminded me of the familiarly mysterious and horrifying dystopian environment of Little Nightmares.
Although, INSIDE offers a bizarre and confusing plot in a highly surreal world while providing the player unique puzzles to solve. While being chalk full of disgusting imagery, it also stands out due to the fact that the ending and the plot of the game keep the player thinking about what they just witnessed and experienced.
At first, I was hesitant to buy this game due to the short amount of time it takes to complete it. However, INSIDE is a perfect example that video games don't need endless campaigns to convey a thought-provoking story. Most importantly, it can deliver much more than other games in a short span of time.

Great atmosphere, sound design, music and gameplay. I came in knowing very little and thinking it would be mostly artistic and little game, but I was pleasantly surprised. The puzzles are clever and feels like they blend great with the story of the game.

If you also found this game on sale for like a dollar and some change than it is totally worth it, great puzzle game that actually requires some thinking. But it's definitely not worth the $20 price mark, they have a way to connect you very well with the main character but there's not really a plot, and the ending is not what anyone would expect. The music and the ambient sounds are really where the game shines, beautiful soundtrack and SFX as well, graphics are top of the line as well for an indie game. But if you want a game that will give you a few hours of enjoyment for $2 hopefully, then gladly buy it since you probably wont regret it.

Inside is a beautiful and artistic game set in a dystopian world of mind control. The level transition and design is amazing for a game designed in 3D using 2D platformer design in mind. The puzzles are not that hard but they are complex and can take you a few minutes to understand the solution. Brilliant atmosphere that keeps you engaged and wanting to push forward. There aren't the whole things in life that I feel are unforgivable but knowingly wasting somebody's time definitely is. It just so happens that the main tactic this game uses to extend its short length is knowingly wasting the player's time. 

This game will make you restart out of the blue for things you could not have predicted, it will make you repeat things three or four times, the list goes on.. 

With the padding I managed to beat this game in under 4 hours; without the padding I imagine I would have been able to beat it 2 or less hours. So, even if the game didn't blatantly waste my time there's no way it justifies its price tag. 

Not only will this game waste your time, the normal $20 price tag is an absolute literal scam given it's length. Regardless of this game's strengths, there is absolutely no way you can look past what it does that's just wrong. Save your $20, but more importantly, save your time for something that actually values it.

This is an easy review to make. I usually like to go over the positives, negatives and neutral points, but after playing I don't recall any negatives nor neutrals.
The game feels feels like a worthy upgrade to Limbo (the developers' previous game), which I constantly kept in mind when noticing every improvement and will now compare to.
The visual style noticeably better, but to be honest Limbo didn't have much going on in that department to begin with.
The world feels more lived and interesting, yet the atmosphere still captures that lonely feeling that the developers were going for.
The movement felt more fluid and didn't contribute negatively to the progression, something that did happen in my experience with Limbo a few times.
The game doesn't feel as unforgiving. Yes, you can screw up, but you'll know exactly what you did wrong and what you should do in the next attempt instead. In Limbo, sometimes you'd die unfairly for multiple reasons, one of which the afore mentioned controls.

This seems like I'm bashing Limbo but I do not mean it that way at all, Limbo is still a great game. I just mean to represent how much Inside is an improvement and why you should play it if you enjoyed Limbo.

Now that the comparison is over, I'll also add the positive that this game is pretty easy to complete all the achievements for, if you care about that sort of stuff.

Inside is probably my favorite game I've ever played. I've played it on all platforms now excluding the switch, and on every single platform Inside continues to completely surpass expectations. With a combined hour count of over 100 hours, I haven't ever once gotten sick of the environment, the mystery, the soundtrack, or anything about the game really. 

The Story:

The story is incredible. Actually its the lack thereof that is really incredible. Inside manages to take a 2.5D environment with absolutely no text and turn it into a mystery that slowly but surely expands over the course of the game. There isn't a single room that doesn't have something intriguing in the background (or foreground), and you can actually piece together the movie from the first couple areas alone, if you're looking hard enough. The amount of speculation the player can take away from the game's ending is also incredible, as it is all up to perception of the events during the game, and the buildup to the grand finale.

Audio + Visuals:

The art and sound that appears in the game embraces the player and drags them in. There's no choice. You are immersed whether you want to be or not.

Amazing game! I got it on sale for 90% off for the price of just under $3 and I have to say, I loved the post-apocalyptic/dystopic visuals, black, gray and white vibe, silent story line, and the amount of puzzles inside this game. There are so many themes in this game you can't stop thinking about, like oppression, elitism, power, control (ex. the test dummies)... and it got me thinking so much of the parasitic blob being in control of the boy in red or the test dummies and the blob being us, the players of the game. There's many theories and beliefs on forums or videos (Reddit, Quora, Youtube) about this wonderful game. But ugh, the long-haired mermaid creature thing gave me the chills every time I try to escape it. One of the best puzzle-platformer games I've ever played up to date, maybe up to the tier of the Portal series. Highly recommend.

The game didn't take long to complete, but I enjoyed it thoroughly.

A pretty phenomenal piece of art. This really feels an emotional and thematic exploration than a typical 'video game'. The style, sound design, and general atmosphere presented here are all excellent, creating a beautifully ugly, depressing, oppressed world. Players are given some, but not a huge amount of information regarding lore, and have to fill in the blanks. It cannot be emphasised enough how different this game is to any other, and again, it is more of a interactive art piece than your run-of-the-mill 2D platformer. 

It should be stated, however, that the price is definitely on the higher side compared to the roughly 2-3 hour experience that you will get, so if you are interested, maybe get this one on sale.
