I always make a very explicit distinction when it comes to judging games: whether they are a pleasant [i]experience[/i] and whether they are a good [i]game[/i]. INSIDE goes all out on the first, but doesn't do completely terrible on the second either.

INSIDE, without spoiling any of the content - is a journey filled with environmental puzzles. It usually recycles the same mechanics (in a good way, and often very cleverly). The low poly characters are offputting and bland, but compensated for by extremely cinematic lighting, beautiful camera angles and a generally very pretty decor (albeit macabre). The sound design is unimaginably good for an indie title. The procedural animations are very convincing. The physics are right on the money. The puzzles are subtle but never hard. It's nothing short of a stunning presentation I've seen attempted many times before, but never with this much grace.

As a game INSIDE is not great. A lot of the puzzles rely on "reacting on the spot", and if the situation is interpret wrong (often without proper feedback, it can be one of an option and if you fail well... you have to do it over). Some of the puzzles are difficult to make sense of without just trying a few things - and trial and error is a hard no for me when it comes to game design. It's not outright bad however; the puzzles are, as mentioned before, quite intriguing and tend to reuse mechanics used previously. This makes them easier to read in most cases.

INSIDE is a really noteworthy title as long as you aren't looking for a fair challenge of any kind. Go in to experience, not to win.

A poignant and very unsettling experience. 

It is a solid platform/puzzle game, with good graphics. Story-wise, you don't really understand what is going on, but you know something is very wrong. You play as a child, which makes all the dying in multiple horrible ways particularly unpleasant to watch. Because of all the mystery and puzzle-solving, it is very engaging, but I would not call it fun. The game leaves you somewhat scared and confused, much like a kid must feel if left to fend for itself in an hostile, uncaring world like in this game. It is an emotional ride, and what keeps you going is the mystery, which becomes increasingly more complex, and the urge to help the poor child reach safety and get some satisfying resolution [spoiler](which never happens)[/spoiler]. The game just gets weirder and weirder, and both endings leave you sad and wondering what it was all about. Fascinating and cryptic, like an abstract work of art.

Reality is sometimes really unpleasant, especially for some people, and this game reminds you of it. Not a game I would recommend if you are feeling down. But a very interesting emotional experience otherwise.

[code]Curator page here-->[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37670120/] DaRevieweD #35[/url]<-- [i]New review every Sunday[/i][/code]

Danish independent developer Playdead made quite the entrance with the premiere of "Limbo" in 2010. That was about a boy's journey in between the living and dead. As if that wasn't already engrossing, Playdead came up with the spiritual successor "INSIDE" half a decade later with a more ambiguous title! 

I played the demo on console before and woah I didn't understand it- that's a given as I knew there had to be underlying messages hidden way in there! I also reviewed the former when I was still writing much shorter, clustered reviews back then- so I regard this as a way to show how far both Playdead and well me, have progressed! Lets get right to it~  


[h1]"Breach The Surface"[/h1]

[u]The Gist:[/u]
A boy abruptly emerges from the woods. Where is he running from or maybe even heading towards? Along the way he runs into a desolate wastelands, other people being held captive and an organization that also wants to apprehend him. Before he realizes it, he's found himself within a string of experimentation and it seems there's no going back.

[spoiler] ! C-conspiracy? Could it just be that?[/spoiler]


[h1][+] PROS;[/h1]

[b](a) On The Run[/b]
If you've played Limbo, you'll feel right at home. It's a 2D platformer with a huge emphasis on puzzle solving in order to figure out how to get around obstacles. More cooler neat animations were added, that are delightful to look at! For instance, if the boy steps on the edge of an object, ledge or suddenly decides to quick turn after building momentum. And boy is he quite the swimmer, being able to dive and swim skillfully although he could use some more practice when it comes to holding his breath. 

There are also actions that he'll do by instinct and these are prominently displayed during stealth segments like crouching down, palm of his hand against the wall surface. You can tell a lot of work went into his movements alone and I really appreciate that!! Controlling him (poor choice of words) is always a treat~ 


[b](b) Classified[/b] 
Though the puzzles were not as migraine-inducing as Limbo, they were still unique and do not seem randomly thrown in. What I mean by this is they fit the cold and controlled environments that they were most likely actual assets and were at one point made specifically for scientific research. This boy is now repurposing these gadgets to his advantage. They may start off like your typical "drag crate to climb over something" but that quickly evolves into more ingeniously designed, could have been made by the Riddler- that I also had some trouble with (not as much as Limbo where I rage quit for months). 

There are also secret contraptions just menacingly stationed about, whose functions are not known but they're shaped awfully familiar.. Anyways, the chances of you stumbling into them are quite rare unless you're super observant and take advantage of the "E" key every chance you get. But the hints are in the achievements themselves (thankfully not hidden ones) and you can always effortlessly reload a checkpoint should you miss one. Then skip ahead back~ These are optional but they do lead to a strictly, mind-screwing alternate ending of sorts. Just let that set in.


[b](c) Fractured[/b] 
The story is probably 90% why you're even touching this game! It's THAT good!! As for the storytelling however, it could use some work. It's another silent protagonist and there are no conversations (not with words). What we do end up with is a very mysterious sci-fi plot and a utterly hostile world, devoid of hope. What follows next is merely my interpretation of what the title could mean and the whole point of the story; so chill and feel free to skip~ 

[spoiler]Now, meaning no.1 the boy (who's dressed in red) is actually a spy sent INTO to break out some...thing. That explains why he knows where to go and is kinda competent. Hence, the organization guarding the complex is aware of this and is constantly on the lookout. No.2 is related to the mind control aspect- to literally get INSIDE someone's head which is a big part of the puzzles. OR finally, it's about secrets and how "to get on the inside track" of something. There's an extraterrestrial being that could save the dying planet and so experiments are being performed on it. But they didn't anticipate interference from the boy who may or may not be controlled.[/spoiler]There's probably more outrageous or plausible (your call) angles to approach this. Mindblown!!


[b](d) Out of Bounds[/b] 
Now I'll breakdown what made this game scary! The many creative deaths and variety in animations of said dying aside, the horror is much subtler. One, notice the setting- a place that's abandoned caused perhaps by a fatal disease, the infamous global warming or[spoiler]alien invasion[/spoiler]. Heck maybe it's man-made, idk cuz what's presented are the after effects but not the before. Either way, we could have potentially been staring at our future and we didn't realize it, at worst didn't care *gulp*. 

Then there's the obligatory paranoid thought of a top-secretive research facility in the heart of the woods somewhere, away from civilization. Is it run by the government, are they doing it for the sake of mankind or towards an exploitative and personal gain? But with revelations of a [spoiler]device overriding free will, taming of a creature of sorts[/spoiler], it would point towards the latter and fitting of human nature. Finally, I couldn't help but shake the notion of a little bit of Marxist ideals in there. For one thing, it takes place in a work environment and then some of the workforce appear mindless to do the bidding of some higher power. Followed by the inevitable revolution of the oppressed. One last thought, I may be overreacting but where are all the children!!? 


[h1][-] CONS;[/h1]

[b](i) Does The Top Stop?[/b] 
I'll just say it- I didn't like the ending. Woah, that felt so liberating to get off my chest. In all seriousness it wasn't actually THAT bad, just let down. It probably requires a lot of thought but patience has never been my strong suit.[Spoiler]There are two endings; canon and alternate, or maybe they're reversed, IDK!![/spoiler]. The fact that it ends on a cliffhanger- a happy-ish note, whatever. 

But then you start to overthink it. Even something as simple as, who's good and evil for example??! You realize for example [spoiler]the final scene is similar to a certain staging area behind glass. Coincidence?[/spoiler]. This game is perhaps too rich for me to analyze and I despise it for that but it did nothing wrong (maybe that's what it wants of me). I didn't encounter any bugs and you heard how the story went. I know what I must do about the score.. but first.


[h1]"Deeper Than Ever"[/h1]

To recap, INSIDE may retain the core characteristics of what made Limbo a worldwide sensation; from the moderate graphics to potentially challenging platformer puzzles. However most apparent is the magnetic, mysterious plot to put that curiosity leash around you but it is a far cry from there on out. The story is even more interestingly convoluted and the title can bear many meanings. Whereas the ending of its predecessor could be hinted at, Inside leaves you hanging with uncertainty as you never really guess what the game will throw at you next.

Piled with the shock from progressively horrific happenings that unfold and a truly oppressive post-apocalyptic world, you cannot help but think of the worst! Perhaps most terrifying is the fact that we'll never (not definitively) get an answer as to what it actually meant- to peer into the developers' minds. You're still most welcome to try and you know there'a little part within you that will be dying to~ 

[h1]9.8/10[/h1]

[b]From the afterlife to a dystopian world- where will Playdead take us next? [i]SPACE?!....w-wait, for real?![/i][/b]

This game is excellent. The world it creates is deeply engaging despite, or perhaps because, things are never explained, only shown. You're immersed in the circumstances of the character and through them see and experience an internally consistent dystopia that is by turns baffling, horrifying, and compelling. The design makes effective use of visual tropes (hiding in the shadows, silhouetted by headlights, dilapidated urban rooftops, run-down rural farms, underwater vastness) to draw you in to a story and an environment that is simultaneously familiar and alien, relatable and unknowable.

The gameplay also deserves mention, as its puzzles are sufficiently challenging to sustain interest without being either too difficult or too repetitive. However, from the very simple controls to the side-scrolling 2D layout, the overarching design goal seems to have been to keep the player in the world rather than in their head. More than a game, this is a fully-realized work of experimental immersive art. I'm glad it exists.

Good game but not very stimulating or immersive. Good for a day or 2 max. You get tired of only doing puzzles very soon. Its cute, well executed and minimalistic but not something memorable or the type of experience i wish to have again anytime soon.

Rating it 9/10 - Inside is a masterpiece by all standards.

I'm thankful to have had the opportunity to play this masterpiece. It was an adventure which I won't forget easily.

Overall it is a very extremely well polished game and has mysterious lore behind it that keep me intrigued and keep me questioning of what is actually happening in the world that they're building here, what an experience!

I'll be brief in this review: you won't fully understand the story. Sometimes, you won't be doing much gameplay wise. And yes, ideas are recycled often. But the MOOD of this game is unparalleled. Exploring cities full of drones, chased by faceless men and hunted like prey, all in an environment that is strange and unfamiliar... all of this comes together to build an INSANE world of tension, darkness, and imagination. This game is an experience wrapped into a 3D platformer. Play it.

I picked this up in a recent sale, as quite honestly, I was drawn to the aesthetic and the artwork, and I'm glad I did. 

The blurb for the game gives little away, a bit like the game itself in terms of a clearly defined plot, but the objective itself is clear enough. 

When I started playing yesterday I wanted a game that wasn't too difficult, but interesting enough to keep my brain occupied - as I've not been in the best of headspace of late, and weirdly, this quirky, dark, and rather twisty game would be a good choice. Enough to keep me distracted and let my brain work a few things out while I focus on what the hell I've walked into...

I can honestly admit I've never been so morbidly curious as to how many different ways my character can die in a game!
Let's just say, no punches are pulled, and there's something weirdly fascinating about the combination of the visuals and the outcomes of failing, as well as an uneasy atmosphere to begin with. 

Like some of my favourite games, there is no dialogue - and to enhance the creep factor in Inside, music is also sparing. It's very much you and your thoughts against... the 'enemy'. I also like that the game is deliberately a bit vague - making it really multifaceted as to what you decide who and what the enemy is. (No spoilers, but let's just say I didn't expect to end the game the way I did!) 

I picked up on the achievements/secret puzzles a bit too late, as I didn't spot them, so there is replay value for me - I'm not a massive achievement hunter, but I did find the big 'secret' but it's dependent on earlier secrets being found... so will sort that out as I want to know what the outcome of that is. 

This is a game that could easily be completed in an evening - I don't rush through games and it took me just over four hours. 
I'd definitely recommend it if you see it on sale, and want something different for your evening, or if dark and twisty is your kind of game.

A wonderful, short but sweet platformer from the team that developed the similarly critically-acclaimed Limbo!

[u]PROS[/u]
- Because there aren't any dialogue/text/audio logs whatsoever, the game makes you focus on its beautifully-rendered backgrounds that are full of intriguing scenery which give you a sense of the world you're in and its many compelling mysteries. Sometimes less is better! [b]Show us, don't tell us[/b], and this is a perfect example of getting that right!
- Half of the game consists of solving its many unique, very creative and deceptively clever puzzles. I wish more games did puzzles like this!
- Towards the end of the game you're treated to some of the CRAZIEST, WTF, most FUN moments in video game history ever! The game is worth playing for this alone, for real!! XD

[u]CONS[/u]
- The only possibly negative thing about this game is that it can be completed in ~3 hours. But hey, if you're short on time and/or want something that's a lot of fun & won't stress you out then this is perfect!
Hard to put down.

Playdead's INSIDE is a game about humanity and the absence of free will. This entire game has layers and layers of poetic depth regarding how we as a species are reliably not in control, from the idea that we are nothing more than animals running off pure instinct, to the collective collaboration to achieve great feats only being our collective need to adapt to our world and move forward. How parasites control us, and how we can become the parasites. It is also rich with an ominous shadowy atmosphere, with this incredible setting of such awe and scope. The details of this world are left ambigious, to where your mind can only wander to fill in the blanks. All questions are not answered, and anyone that claims to have the answer is grasping at threads. This game is short, tight, visually gorgeous with some really eye opening questions, all told without a shred of dialogue and it ends on a note that will leave you utterly stunned. 10/10.

Very engaging, and the puzzles are just the right level of difficulty. Like Limbo, the game is dark and dreadful and compelling. Its violence can be disturbing, particularly because we care about the little character trying to free himself from his terrible location - yet this makes us want to continue all the more and run to freedom. The game is beautifully done and deeply gorgeous. The atmosphere and music is excellent. Strongly recommend.

2010â€™s seminal Limbo inaugurated a welcome era of vulnerable characters platforming left-to-right in menacing 2.5D worlds, including wonderful recent additions such as FAR: Lone Sails and Little Nightmares. A spiritual successor by Limbo developers Playdead, Inside is a worthy successor that graphically surpasses the original even if the gameplay is more of the same; another fine work of environmental storytelling with mostly slick, satisfying puzzles and platforming.

Slyly dumping an unnamed child-protagonist in starting forest; Inside soon veers into more dystopian territory. SPOILERS AHEAD. Menacing thugs and creepy malformed pigs are revealed to be the first outriders of a sinister, mind-controlling autocracy that seems to have seized power in a crumbling, post-collapse world. While thereâ€™s no antagonist as memorable as Limboâ€™s spider, a bananas twist in the gameâ€™s final act is easily as striking, even if its relation to what came previously appears tenuous. SPOILERS END. Indeed, Inside tells its story wordlessly and with a kind of arthouse portentousness that some players may find frustrating. The end is ambiguous, and if the game has any kind of overarching message or meaning, itâ€™s very much left up to the player to discern. 

Platforming is naturalistic and responsive, aided by wonderful animation, and the environment has clearly been play-tested and refined to Valve-like levels of polish. The 3D backdrops are more appealing than Limboâ€™s, as are the Schindlerâ€™s List-esque splashes of colour in a largely monochrome world. The puzzles are mostly satisfying, although I find this kind of gameâ€™s â€œguess-what-Iâ€™m-thinkingâ€ approach to problem-solving occasionally frustrating; with no room for creative solutions. In a couple of instances, I seemed to steer away from the correct path forward, and resorted to internet solutions to avoid severe frustration. But perhaps, dear reader, you are more intelligent than I. At the very least, extremely generous checkpointing keeps you from repeating more than any individual micro-challenge.

Clocking in at three to four hours, thirty dollary-dos may seem a little steep for an experience with limited replay value outside a few hidden collectables. With less free time than Iâ€™d like, however, I have no qualms recommending this kind of gaming amuse-bouche; especially one as well-crafted and evocative as Inside. You just might want to wait for a sale. A great jumping-on point for the growing family of Scandinavian atmosphere-drenched platformers, donâ€™t miss Limbo and FAR: Lone Sails if you enjoyed this, or for something cheerier the wonderful Steamworld Digs 1 and 2.

Loved this game !!

Loved this game from start to finish, INSIDE was a blast to play through till the end.

Visuals: 10/10, Might just be me but the city sections give me MASSIVE vibes of Half-Life 2 and Little Nightmares (despite the ladder being made after INSIDE) mashed together to create an very bleak and hopeless environment.  The factory levels give an pretty dark and almost souless feel to everything.  I just cant shut up about the visuals for both LIMBO and INSIDE.

Music: 7/10, Very melancholy in nature, didn't mind that much although at some points it got really good

Gameplay: 6/10, There were some points where the puzzles got a bit frustrating and annoying, Most puzzles are fine, but i strongly dislike the water and siren puzzles. Stealth is pretty good, the chase scenes are at a completely different level tho.  I absolutely love the chase scenes with the dogs and the humans,  Not sure if this is "spoilers" but the one chase scene with the people montioring the line with mind controlled humans you are in and letting the dog loose has so much tension and suspense. I would love to see more of it in the next game.

Sercets: 5/10, I'm that type of guy who typically doesnt like to go out of my way to get "sercets" and having to play a level over again just to get it, then to go to another level and rinse and repeat, Although the sercet ending is pretty good.

Overall, INSIDE was a very unique experience, so i give it a 8/10. You will love it for its visuals, i assure you that.

Can't wait for what Playdead is cooking up for its next game!

The spiritual successor to Limbo, almost better in every way too. This game is super atmospheric and dark, slightly unsettling, especially at certain parts. Alot of world building more than a story driven game. Also very much an inspiration to games that came after like Little Nightmares. After replaying it since 2017, I can say it's definitely one of my favorite puzzle games. 9/10

One of the best games I've ever played. Beautiful art, creative yet somewhat intuitive puzzles, I didn't have to resort to walkthroughs. The atmosphere is intense, sometimes I'd get extremely anxious and afraid - all that from a "2D" game. It says a lot. Loved it.

Unique gameplay, ambience, story and setting - hard to put your controller down. The puzzles are fresh, and well balanced, albeit shorter than I expected. Also only 1080p is supported which is a bummer, but definitely a must play.
MY FINGERS HURT SO BAD
cool puzzles, interesting world, only downside is a soundtrack that isn't as experimental as other aspects of the game

After trying and not liking LIMBO (at all) I was worried I wouldn't get on with this game but it is great! Nothing too demanding but compelling to play and get to the end, which doesn't take long at all. I had to go back to 100% the game and see the secret ending!

Inside is a very simple, yet intriguing game. The controls are very simple, the puzzles are quite obvious most of the time and the progression is literally going left. The story and the atmosphere however is everything but that. The story is incredibly mysterious and you could posibly solve it alone, if you'd pay very close attention to the details, but most likely, you'll need to watch a story explanation of some kind, if you want to know what exactly is going on.
